revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 20:34:55.000000000', 'message': 'add support for changing cinder perodic_interval

As discovered in tempest, when you create and delete volumes
quickly, and have a small volume storage pool, you can get cinder
scheduler to think you are "out of space" when you are not.

This is because cinder scheduler updates free space on it's
periodic job, which defaults to 60 seconds. We need control over
that value for the devstack gate otherwise we regularly get
overruns if we run too many volume tests quickly.

Work around for bug 1180976

Expect that this will get removed later if cinder gets a more
efficient way to update the scheduler for freed resources.

Change-Id: I20e52e66fcc94b224476cdd14c88bd6981b4e617
'}, {'created': '2013-05-16 22:06:07.000000000', 'message': 'add support for changing cinder perodic_interval

As discovered in tempest, when you create and delete volumes
quickly, and have a small volume storage pool, you can get cinder
scheduler to think you are "out of space" when you are not.

This is because cinder scheduler updates free space on it's
periodic job, which defaults to 60 seconds. We need control over
that value for the devstack gate otherwise we regularly get
overruns if we run too many volume tests quickly.

Work around for bug 1180976

Expect that this will get removed later if cinder gets a more
efficient way to update the scheduler for freed resources.

Also, don't be completely stupid about setting defaults....

Change-Id: I20e52e66fcc94b224476cdd14c88bd6981b4e617
'}]
commit_message:
add support for changing cinder perodic_interval

As discovered in tempest, when you create and delete volumes
quickly, and have a small volume storage pool, you can get cinder
scheduler to think you are "out of space" when you are not.

This is because cinder scheduler updates free space on it's
periodic job, which defaults to 60 seconds. We need control over
that value for the devstack gate otherwise we regularly get
overruns if we run too many volume tests quickly.

Work around for bug 1180976

Expect that this will get removed later if cinder gets a more
efficient way to update the scheduler for freed resources.

Also, don't be completely stupid about setting defaults....

Change-Id: I20e52e66fcc94b224476cdd14c88bd6981b4e617

[{'created': '2013-05-15 23:59:17.000000000', 'message': "Remove dead code.

While it is true that one *could* call ContainerBroker.get_info() with
include_metadata=True, it is also true that nobody actually does.

It's also true that the code path taken when include_metadata=True is
broken in the case of non-ASCII metadata keys
(e.g. X-Container-Meta-â˜ƒ: snowman), so leaving it around is just
asking for future pain.

Change-Id: I4931add4b8fb7c4f57820e52f182c21040d8db10
"}]
commit_message:
Remove dead code.

While it is true that one *could* call ContainerBroker.get_info() with
include_metadata=True, it is also true that nobody actually does.

It's also true that the code path taken when include_metadata=True is
broken in the case of non-ASCII metadata keys
(e.g. X-Container-Meta-â˜ƒ: snowman), so leaving it around is just
asking for future pain.

Change-Id: I4931add4b8fb7c4f57820e52f182c21040d8db10

commit_message:
set the admin_pass when creating the server

The feature is setting the admin_pass when creating the server,
it is supported by the python-novaclient, we are able to
see the parameter 'admin_pass' in the fun:
novaclient.v1_1.base.BootingManagerWithFind._boot().

The nova is also accepted this parameter 'admin_pass',
then it will inject the'admin_pass' to the image file system,
or nothing to do

Ensure to use keyword parameters in format string in create_instance.py

Implements: blueprint admin-password-for-server
Change-Id: I3a5fe4c7f48e21631f615510422c0a7dcf3c7d65

commit_message:
Add ca cert file support to cinder client requests

Allow for ca certificates file to be specified when doing cinder
client requests. Needed when using custom ca authorities.

Change-Id: Ib9aa15df2fc7d96cb8587c13769399e353c032c6
Fixes: bug #1179476

I looked into the multiple subnets question and it led me to a couple of discoveries.  First, I think it's better not to make this decision at a network level, since it seems possible to have a network with both static and dynamic subnets.  The latest patch set addresses that.

Second, multiple subnets are not going to be handled properly by the existing injection code, due to the following:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/model.py#L354

and

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/netutils.py#L75

I think fixing the latter problem is outside the scope of this change, but I will look into opening a new bug for it unless there's a reason I shouldn't."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-08 22:23:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-04-24 21:34:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If you're using DHCP, why would you have network info injection enabled in the first place?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-04-24 22:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The flat_injected configuration option is set on a per-compute node basis, but you might boot a VM there with both a dynamic and static network attached.  If you want to inject the static configuration, right now you also get the dynamic one, which doesn't make sense."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-02 15:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Restored

Russell, can you let me know if you see any problems with my explanation?  Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-05-06 19:18:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I find myself a little confused by this patch. I don't disagree that info shouldn't be injected into an instance when it should not. I understand your description as well, but what I don't understand is the valid configuration use-case where this actually happens. In nova-network, flat_injected is mostly considered if the FlatManager is being used. I think the actual bug here might be in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py. It's pulling in flat_injected from the configuration when it is building the network model even when it should not."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-06 19:39:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Brent, I don't disagree on that, but what I discovered while working on this change is that there is not a good way to determine on a network level whether flat_injected should be used or not.  This is because there could be both static and dynamic subnets on a given network, and since flat_injected is applied at a network level we can't make a good decision at that time.  The earlier patch sets actually tried to do that, but it just didn't work.

Note that I don't know whether anyone would actually configure their network that way, but Quantum will happily set it up that way if you ask it to, so I feel like it should be handled in a sane fashion.

This change could conceivably be made at the Quantum API level instead, but I think that would require adding an injected property to the subnets so we could mark them as not to be injected on an individual basis, which would end up touching the common code here anyway.  I don't see a real need to make the change Quantum-specific when it won't make sense to inject a dynamic configuration under any network driver.

Thanks for the feedback.  Let me know if you see any issues with my explanation."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-06 23:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-06 23:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

This does seem to be a quantum specific issue, so if you can make it cleaner by fixing it there as suggested by Brent, I would try that'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:24:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

As Russell pointed out, this is a flawed method of determining whether a network is dynamic.  Unfortunately, the only way I can see to do it properly is to add to the legacy network info data, which seems like a waste.

I'm thinking it might be easiest and cleanest just to remove the dependency on legacy network info in the injection code.  We're losing data when we do the conversion, and that makes it impossible for the Quantum driver to communicate whether a network should be injected or not.  Does anyone see any problems with that approach?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-07 21:01:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-07 21:50:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-07 21:55:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-07 21:56:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(Apologies in advance for the wall of text) Some notes on this latest patch set:

I couldn't remove the legacy nwinfo code because libvirt still requires it for the injection template.  Fixing that would require either a hack or a complete rework of libvirt to remove legacy nwinfo.

Because of the legacy nwinfo dependency, I can't put anything in the Quantum API to fix this.  Anything I set in Quantum code is going to be ignored by the legacy nwinfo conversion.

However, the legacy nwinfo code is setting dhcp_server to gateway when a network is static, which is not correct.  In a static network there is no DHCP server so we shouldn't be putting one in the network info.  Fixing this also fixes the bad assumption in my previous fix that gateway would only equal dhcp_server in static networks.

Also, I don't think this problem is strictly Quantum-specific.  The only reason nova-network doesn't see it is that nova-network doesn't support mixed environments - it's either all static or all dynamic.  Any other network driver that supported mixed environments would see the same problem Quantum is now, so even if I could make the change limited to Quantum I don't think that would be desirable.

Let me know if you disagree with any of the above.  Thanks."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-07 22:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Still doesn't seem like a safe change ..."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-10 21:36:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Russell.  I worry about the change in behavior.  If I understand this correctly, if someone was relying on the fact that a blank dhcp server address field meant to use the gateway as the dhcp server address.... this would break them."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-13 18:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Okay, thanks for the feedback.  IMHO anyone relying on that behavior is wrong anyway, but I see your point.

I think I have another approach to this change that you'll like better, so I'll try again when it's ready."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-13 23:11:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-13 23:15:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Don't inject settings for dynamic network

When using Quantum for networking and setting flat_injected to
inject network settings into the guest VM, Nova injects a static
network configuration for networks using DHCP. This change
checks for the existence of a dhcp server and, if found, does not
inject static settings for that network.

Due to limitations of the legacy network info, the fix only
applies when new-style network info is passed to the injection
template function.  The only code still passing in legacy
network info is in libvirt, and there is work ongoing to
remove that dependency.

Fixes bug 1163985
Fixes bug 1112659

Change-Id: I8d3f16bde22e1c6dc0d2432aa263e2b15ae5c93a

Fix header issue

baremetal_deploy_helper.py is not a python script which can not
be run directly, so there is no need to keep "#!/usr/bin/env python"
but change it to "# vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4"

Change-Id: Ic4957673605cd71dc19fc38a2626bdaa35d102c0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix header issue for baremetal_deploy_helper.py

Fix header issue

baremetal_deploy_helper.py is not a python script which can not
be run directly, so there is no need to keep "#!/usr/bin/env python"
but change it to "# vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4"

Change-Id: Ic4957673605cd71dc19fc38a2626bdaa35d102c0

Removed local patches

These patches make assumptions that are a bit too liberal.
As these cookbooks are more widely used, these should be
moved into a wrapper cookbook.

Adds dns_nameserver to OS::Quantum::Subnet.

You can specify list of dns_nameserver in template file when you creating new
subnet using Quantum resources.

commit_message:
Fixing depends in metadata.rb and Berksfile

Since renaming identity and image, we need to update
a variety of places, including the Berksfile and metadata.rb
files for all projects that refer to those cookbooks as
dependencies.

Change-Id: Id218e7f6c3d77622b5589722dcdc31c3ace17a13

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 18:32:57.000000000', 'message': 'Detach volume fails when using multipath iscsi

Enabled multipath for libvirt iscsi volume driver. Attach volume worked,
however, detach volume failed. It failed because it can't find multipath
device "/dev/mapper/xxxxxxxx" from connection_info and block device
mapping table.

The fix is to retrieve multipath device info dynamically at detach time.

Fixes: bug #1178893

Change-Id: I53a3888daef93b57bf7f57438f74cee05e794b52
(cherry picked from commit fc786dd469a15bda1b9d3c7bacf9f1771b9b9956)
'}]
commit_message:
Detach volume fails when using multipath iscsi

Enabled multipath for libvirt iscsi volume driver. Attach volume worked,
however, detach volume failed. It failed because it can't find multipath
device "/dev/mapper/xxxxxxxx" from connection_info and block device
mapping table.

The fix is to retrieve multipath device info dynamically at detach time.

Fixes: bug #1178893

Change-Id: I53a3888daef93b57bf7f57438f74cee05e794b52
(cherry picked from commit fc786dd469a15bda1b9d3c7bacf9f1771b9b9956)

[{'created': '2013-05-15 17:15:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix quantum security group driver to accept none for from/to_port

The quantum security group driver did not accept none values for
from_port/to_port which the nova security group api supports. This
patch allows None values to be passed in for those params and adds a unit test.

In addition the from/to_port responses would be different if using quantum
instead of nova. This patch fixes that and adds unit tests.

Fixes bug 1176027

Change-Id: Id57e253c9dd1787ee25fc5cbb562743692d7abe4
(cherry picked from commit 78e2e2128992527407f99743340692ef3be75210)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix quantum security group driver to accept none for from/to_port

The quantum security group driver did not accept none values for
from_port/to_port which the nova security group api supports. This
patch allows None values to be passed in for those params and adds a unit test.

In addition the from/to_port responses would be different if using quantum
instead of nova. This patch fixes that and adds unit tests.

Fixes bug 1176027

Change-Id: Id57e253c9dd1787ee25fc5cbb562743692d7abe4
(cherry picked from commit 78e2e2128992527407f99743340692ef3be75210)

commit_message:
Removed local patches

These patches make assumptions that are a bit too liberal.
As these cookbooks are more widely used, these should be
moved into a wrapper cookbook.

Change-Id: I5348876712418a520659aab606065e5a5b288d99

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 17:08:06.000000000', 'message': 'Raise InstanceInvalidState for double hard reboot

A hard reboot is not allowed if the instance task_state is
REBOOTING_HARD so check for that state and raise InstanceInvalidState.
This returns the correct status of 409 to the caller.

Previously the hard reboot would fail the the expected_task_state check
on db.instance_update_and_get_original which would log a traceback and
return a 500 to the caller.

Bug 1157237

Change-Id: Ifb6111790352da5c404289b218c50d8104384301
(cherry picked from commit 662a793056d4544c9c9d73fc21b99d77404537cc)
'}]
commit_message:
Raise InstanceInvalidState for double hard reboot

A hard reboot is not allowed if the instance task_state is
REBOOTING_HARD so check for that state and raise InstanceInvalidState.
This returns the correct status of 409 to the caller.

Previously the hard reboot would fail the the expected_task_state check
on db.instance_update_and_get_original which would log a traceback and
return a 500 to the caller.

Bug 1157237

Change-Id: Ifb6111790352da5c404289b218c50d8104384301
(cherry picked from commit 662a793056d4544c9c9d73fc21b99d77404537cc)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 08:47:24.000000000', 'message': "Mox should cleanup before stubs

Tests that define both Mox and Stubs may not receive a proper cleanup by the
`TestCase` base class. The reason is that the order in which the Mox and Stubs
are unset may not necessarily match-up with the order in which the tests
called them. For example:

Suppose we have a test that Stubs a method in its `setUp` and then Mox's that
same method in the test body:

    Stub: Original-Func -> Stubbed-Func
    Mox: Stubbed-Func -> Mocked-Func

Now when `TestCase` ultimately does its `cleanUp`, it will UnStub before
UnMocking:

    UnStub: Stubbed-Func -> Original-Func
    UnMox: Mocked-Func -> Stubbed-Func

Notice that generic cleanup has mistakingly left `Stubbed-Func` in place.

Given that Stubs and Mox can be performed in any order, the upshot here is
that the generic cleanup can't always be relied on.

The proposed solution has two parts: a best-practice change and a small
code-change.

The code-change is to reverse the current order to UnMox before UnStubbing.
While in theory the order is arbitrary, in practice, we have lots of Stubs in
`setUp` methods already, so UnMox'ing first makes sense (and it fixes a
current bug to boot!)

The best-practice change is to recommend that developers Stub-before-Mocking
if they're relying on the generic cleanup. If for whatever reason they need to
deivate, the cleanup is their responsibility.

Fixes bug 1180671

Change-Id: I42ab8b55026c0a133625a7cc81ed8b960e9d47d7
"}, {'created': '2013-05-16 18:17:49.000000000', 'message': "Mox should cleanup before stubs

Tests that define both Mox and Stubs may not receive a proper cleanup by the
`TestCase` base class. The reason is that the order in which the Mox and Stubs
are unset may not necessarily match-up with the order in which the tests
called them. For example:

Suppose we have a test that Stubs a method in its `setUp` and then Mox's that
same method in the test body:

    Stub: Original-Func -> Stubbed-Func
    Mox: Stubbed-Func -> Mocked-Func

Now when `TestCase` ultimately does its `cleanUp`, it will UnStub before
UnMocking:

    UnStub: Stubbed-Func -> Original-Func
    UnMox: Mocked-Func -> Stubbed-Func

Notice that generic cleanup has mistakingly left `Stubbed-Func` in place.

Given that Stubs and Mox can be performed in any order, the upshot here is
that the generic cleanup can't always be relied on.

The proposed solution has two parts: a best-practice change and a small
code-change.

The code-change is to reverse the current order to UnMox before UnStubbing.
While in theory the order is arbitrary, in practice, we have lots of Stubs in
`setUp` methods already, so UnMox'ing first makes sense (and it fixes a
current bug to boot!)

The best-practice change is to recommend against stubbing and mocking the same
function as well as to always place stubs before mocks when relying on the
generic cleanup. If a developers needs to deviate from this, cleanup of stubs
created after mocks are their responsibility.

Fixes bug 1180671

Change-Id: I42ab8b55026c0a133625a7cc81ed8b960e9d47d7
"}]
commit_message:
Mox should cleanup before stubs

Tests that define both Mox and Stubs may not receive a proper cleanup by the
`TestCase` base class. The reason is that the order in which the Mox and Stubs
are unset may not necessarily match-up with the order in which the tests
called them. For example:

Suppose we have a test that Stubs a method in its `setUp` and then Mox's that
same method in the test body:

    Stub: Original-Func -> Stubbed-Func
    Mox: Stubbed-Func -> Mocked-Func

Now when `TestCase` ultimately does its `cleanUp`, it will UnStub before
UnMocking:

    UnStub: Stubbed-Func -> Original-Func
    UnMox: Mocked-Func -> Stubbed-Func

Notice that generic cleanup has mistakingly left `Stubbed-Func` in place.

Given that Stubs and Mox can be performed in any order, the upshot here is
that the generic cleanup can't always be relied on.

The proposed solution has two parts: a best-practice change and a small
code-change.

The code-change is to reverse the current order to UnMox before UnStubbing.
While in theory the order is arbitrary, in practice, we have lots of Stubs in
`setUp` methods already, so UnMox'ing first makes sense (and it fixes a
current bug to boot!)

The best-practice change is to recommend against stubbing and mocking the same
function as well as to always place stubs before mocks when relying on the
generic cleanup. If a developers needs to deviate from this, cleanup of stubs
created after mocks are their responsibility.

Fixes bug 1180671

Change-Id: I42ab8b55026c0a133625a7cc81ed8b960e9d47d7

I agree with ctracey, we should bump the version to 2013.1.0'}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-05-15 17:06:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not a fan of the cookbook versioning matching what we are deploying.  Should the apache cookbook be versioned 2.2.22-6.0 ? IMO we should branch cookbooks for each release, and use semantic versioning.

I didn't update the version in this patch, b/c the feature is just the cookbook rename.  I didn't want to mash together a change such as this, since the versioning topic hasn't been decided."}, {'account_id': 1032, 'date': '2013-05-15 17:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Changed cookbook name to openstack-identity

Changed the cookbook to opentack-identity.  This involved changing
many attribute and lwrp references.  Also, corrected tests to use
the new cookbook name and attributes.

All tests are passing.

Change-Id: Idcc49431c9c9327066deaed520ceb82b86db3ea8

lookuping deleted domain.

Change-Id: I6c6f7d8a736c833488b6cb8e00530dc4138f1424
"}, {'created': '2013-05-16 01:52:10.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: Catch VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN in list_instances

commit_message:
libvirt: Catch VIR_ERR_NO_DOMAIN in list_instances

Commit 25f50d9a didn't catch the exact exception for
looking up deleted domain.

Partly fixes LP Bug #1032741.

Change-Id: I6c6f7d8a736c833488b6cb8e00530dc4138f1424

commit_message:
Reverse compare arguments in filters tests

When using assertEqual, the expected result should actually be the first
argument so any failures have 'expected' and 'actual' values printed
properly.

Change-Id: I34d16f298eb0bf62e2abaaf31e80911fa124dc24

commit_message:
Allow generator as input to utils.print_list.

Once the table is built, the length of the prettytable's internal array
is checked rather than re-iterrating over the input.

Adds tests for utils.print_list with list and generator input.

Change-Id: I4c0bd08bf0c943de42ad90d255a2d831c2e98828
Fixes: bug #1180059

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 11:20:17.000000000', 'message': 'Rename handle_snapshot and pass state

Rename handle_snapshot() to handle_snapshot_delete() to better reflect what
it needs to do (both take a snapshot of the resource and then delete the
resource). Also, pass the state of the resource prior to delete being
invoked, since the resource may want to use different error handling in the
snapshot phase depending on e.g. whether the resource was created
successfully or not.

Change-Id: I1e5aaab4f13e42333c1f2f39bfeb0ebf2ac89ed8
'}]
commit_message:
Rename handle_snapshot and pass state

Rename handle_snapshot() to handle_snapshot_delete() to better reflect what
it needs to do (both take a snapshot of the resource and then delete the
resource). Also, pass the state of the resource prior to delete being
invoked, since the resource may want to use different error handling in the
snapshot phase depending on e.g. whether the resource was created
successfully or not.

Change-Id: I1e5aaab4f13e42333c1f2f39bfeb0ebf2ac89ed8

'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-14 10:41:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

(4 inline comments)

Thanks for these cleanups, but I really, really hate these big "cleanup foo" patches which contain lots of logically unrelated changes, particularly when (as in this case) they don't only contain stylistic cleanups but also changes to the logic.

In this patch you're doing all these things:
- Remove identified_resource decorator
- Remove unused imports
- Modify client error-exit logic
- Add missing imports
- Fix Dependencies string representation (this needs a test btw)
- Clarify resolve_static_data usage docstring
- Cleanup quantum test skip logic

I know it's slightly more effort to break up into separate patches, but that's the way we prefer to work and IMO it's much lower risk than allowing patches like this.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-16 14:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We should not be testing quotas by trying to exhaust the limit by allocating all resources. The tests in tempest/tests/compute/admin/test_quotas.py
do this by setting the quota to 0 and then making sure a request fails. I think it might be better to add these tests to that file using the same methodology."}, {'account_id': 6724, 'date': '2013-04-30 15:47:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

On other hand, we have other quota tests in corresponding files: 
test_create_server_vcpu_quota_full in test_servers_whitebox
test_update_server_metadata_too_long in test_server_metadata
...
i don't know where is proper place for this test, but it's easier for me as tester to add test here (we have setup and teardown prepeared).

As for resources, i agree with you if it were RAM or CPUs. But Security Group won't take much.."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-04-30 15:55:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I don't have a strong opinion about the location of the test. But it is not very hard to set the quota and then restore after the test. Looping api calls based on a value read out of the configuration is a landmine we should avoid even if it is taking only 6 seconds now."}, {'account_id': 6724, 'date': '2013-04-30 20:44:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Adding negative test to check limits of Security Groups and rules

A negative test which verifies that creating security groups and rules cannot exeed limits.
Added tests:
test_security_groups_exceed_limit
test_security_groups_rules_exceed_limit

Change-Id: I5c49eb16750bce5dcaad4481e48ee3400cab4ce4

commit_message:
Changed coobook name to openstack-image

Changed the cookbook name to openstack-image, fixed all tests, and
addressed attributes. Also addressed calls to external services,
primarily keystone -> openstack-identity.

All tests pass.

Change-Id: I6338342a570000b3fb0ae610f1a1bb5aa15ae3e9

commit_message:
Remove the notifier and its dependencies from log.py

Move the code related to the publish error handler out of the
log module so its easier for other projects to consume it

Fixes LP #1179528

Change-Id: Ibf28ba17f81b5ddeda653f6a3501ecac18ffcd42

commit_message:
Copy the RHEL6 eventlet workaround from Oslo

Tests in oslo-incubator now need the horrendous hack to workaround an
issue with eventlet on RHEL6. We've moved the patch_tox_venv tool
and redhat-eventlet.patch into oslo-incubator, so add them to
openstack-common.conf.

Change-Id: I1acfec282b64d7582144b155119bedb1741db2f7

commit_message:
Detach volume fails when using multipath iscsi

Enabled multipath for libvirt iscsi volume driver. Attach volume worked,
however, detach volume failed. It failed because it can't find multipath
device "/dev/mapper/xxxxxxxx" from connection_info and block device
mapping table.

The fix is to retrieve multipath device info dynamically at detach time.

Fixes: bug #1178893

Change-Id: I53a3888daef93b57bf7f57438f74cee05e794b52

commit_message:
Architecture property updated in snapshot libvirt

During an instance snapshot if the architecture property is defined
in the image it is updated twice in the snapshot image.
The snapshot is created with the metadata values from the
"instance_system_metadata" table and then, if defined, the architecure
property is updated from the value in the base image in that moment.

There is no reason to treat this property differently from others.
Also, it didn't respect the "non_inheritable_image_properties" option.

This change removes the special behavior for the architecture property
in the libvirt driver during a snapshot.

Fixes: bug #1176173
Change-Id: Ic5b4e3d462c08df167e14522fa25a7cf857c6aad

commit_message:
Fix for missing multipath device name

Due to formatting changes in the multipath -l output
we were sometimes missing the device name for each of the
multipath devices which gave us a device of '/dev/'.  This
causes problems on detach.

Fixes Bug: #1180497

Change-Id: I6017dda149776624fac452140d3d0f5df3f5fd5a

(1 inline comment)

That first one shouldn't be a smoke test.

Also, what we really need is multi attrs.

So that a test can be set 'smoke' and 'gate' (as we'll want to add some more tags as well). Would you be able to do the plumbing for that as well."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-12 14:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-05-12 22:58:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

this is failing because nosetest seems to have troubles with setting multiple values to an attribute called "type"

using the same syntax (as per documentation) for an attribute called "tags" or "whatever" works as expected and I'm able to pick up the tests with "-a whatever=smoke"

what shall we do? rename the attribute name from type to tags?'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-05-13 10:10:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-13 10:54:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'll move my vote to +2 once I see the test results"}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-13 11:04:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok I'm not entirely clear with the how the new tags are going to be used, but at the moment the attr decorator only passes the smoke tag down to testtools if it is 'smoke'. This causes the testname to be mangled to append ['smoke']. 

If you're planning on using testr to do the filtering based on the mangled name then the decorator will need a bit of work. (see tempest/test.py)"}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-13 11:09:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Apologies for the bitsy comments, but also note that for testtools the decorator expects something of the form type='smoke' rather than just 'smoke'"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 11:31:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28907/3/check/gate-tempest-pep8/3267 : SUCCESS in 00:02:47

'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-05-13 21:45:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

we can't use the ('one', 'two') syntax, need to stick with type=['one', 'two'] , which requires changes in the tempest/test.py (see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tempest/+spec/convert-attr-to-testtools)"}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-05-15 13:45:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:33:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-05-03 21:13:42.000000000', 'message': 'Skip IPv6 addresses in cname_lookup middleware.

It already skips IPv4 addresses, and since IPv6 is the future of the
Internet*, we should probably do the right thing with those too.

* IPv6: Just two years away for over fifteen years!

Change-Id: I54f1db4e936fd38d05ac8b5c709efba76525b9d2
'}]
commit_message:
Skip IPv6 addresses in cname_lookup middleware.

It already skips IPv4 addresses, and since IPv6 is the future of the
Internet*, we should probably do the right thing with those too.

* IPv6: Just two years away for over fifteen years!

Change-Id: I54f1db4e936fd38d05ac8b5c709efba76525b9d2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 12:47:51.000000000', 'message': "blueprint cisco-plugin-exception-handling

Improvements to exception handling in the Cisco plugins. Changes
include:

- Added mapping of Cisco exceptions to HTTP codes
  (extension to FAULT_MAP).
- Removed several unused Cisco exception definitions.
- Added several new Cisco exceptions for fault conditions.
- Added several rollbacks for various sequential operations, e.g.:
  * Create port: Nexus sub-plugin fails after OVS sub-plugin success
  * Create port: Nexus switch conig fails after adding binding to
                 Nexus binding database
  * Delete port: OVS sub-plugin fails after Nexus sub-plugin success
- Delete Port: Reversed order of OVS/Nexus sub-plugin calls so that
  it is done in the reverse order as is done for create port.
- Removed several empty except/raise blocks
- Delete network: Removed call to Nexus sub-plugin delete_network,
  since that is a no-op.
- Removed a block of unused code in model's create_network method.
- Added several unit testcases, including patching of OVS, Cisco
  and Nexus config.
- Remove CISCO_TEST configuration from cisco plugin
  config .ini file.

Change-Id: Iabdf4842aa2f0b090a90e2c565848290832b5197

commit_message:
blueprint cisco-plugin-exception-handling

Improvements to exception handling in the Cisco plugins. Changes
include:

- Added mapping of Cisco exceptions to HTTP codes
  (extension to FAULT_MAP).
- Removed several unused Cisco exception definitions.
- Added several new Cisco exceptions for fault conditions.
- Added several rollbacks for various sequential operations, e.g.:
  * Create port: Nexus sub-plugin fails after OVS sub-plugin success
  * Create port: Nexus switch conig fails after adding binding to
                 Nexus binding database
  * Delete port: OVS sub-plugin fails after Nexus sub-plugin success
- Delete Port: Reversed order of OVS/Nexus sub-plugin calls so that
  it is done in the reverse order as is done for create port.
- Removed several empty except/raise blocks
- Delete network: Removed call to Nexus sub-plugin delete_network,
  since that is a no-op.
- Removed a block of unused code in model's create_network method.
- Added several unit testcases, including patching of OVS, Cisco
  and Nexus config.
- Remove CISCO_TEST configuration from cisco plugin
  config .ini file.

Change-Id: Iabdf4842aa2f0b090a90e2c565848290832b5197

Since md items are transferred via the headers, I expect them all to come encoded. Why than do we ever have a unicode in the md? 

How come we store unicode metadata?
There is no decode when storing md items. 
Would this not hide a bug instead of fixing it?
 :)"}, {'account_id': 6889, 'date': '2013-05-05 13:49:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6889, 'date': '2013-05-05 13:56:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@David Hadas Yes md arrives in ByteString but simplejson or json convert it to unicode when you performing a loads in db.py.
I've done some tests you can check to validate this behaviour here : http://paste.openstack.org/show/6KIfFZe1yyr2bv1hGJe5/

So I keep this modification in db.py and I have had some functionnal test in test_account.py and test_container.py."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-05 14:34:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Here's the output of my test run: http://paste.openstack.org/show/LGZLfCO5F9nh170gN1Jm/"}, {'account_id': 6889, 'date': '2013-05-13 10:22:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Samuel thx for the review but i'm bit in trouble with
this test on the account because as you I got a fail with this test but just one time, I was unable to reproduce it again even after many tries.

I work with devstack, my process to try and reproduce is as follow :
1. stack.sh a swift (without keystone)
2. get the review in /opt/stack/swift
3. unstack.sh && stack.sh
4. start func test with SWIFT_TEST_CONFIG_FILE=../sample.conf ./.functests
or
SWIFT_TEST_CONFIG_FILE=test/sample.conf nosetests test.functionalnosetests.test_account:TestAccount.test_unicode_metadata

Using this process I got it just one time, after an unstack && stack the test passes and i never see the problem again ...

So could you try to reproduce it and give me the exact procedure you used ?"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-05-13 13:15:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

btw: i could not reproduce this either (with tempauth). I don't think this has to be with devstack or not but I think fabien is working on trying to reproduce on swaio to make sure."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-13 22:31:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mine's a Swift All-In-One running Ubuntu 11.10. 

To run the tests, I basically do this:

    $ sudo python ./setup.py develop; ~/bin/startmain && ./.functests

That's about it."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:04:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I will note that Oneiric isn't officially supported by Swift, so if the functional tests pass for Lucid and Precise, I'll be fine with this change going in (and I'll go update my SAIO ;) )"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-14 00:14:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This was reproducible when I ran the whole set of functional tests as well. It was because the interpretation of key names wasn't consistent throughout the code. Here's what I did to fix it:

https://gist.github.com/anonymous/b3c4970ec6b93c9b67fe

Also, I updated the test to take 201 or 204 as success since if you run the specific test without ever having run another test, the first result is 201 since the account had just been created.

Note: This is a quick fix I did and I'm not guaranteeing all places that need to be fixed are -- just what I found with a quick perusal."}, {'account_id': 6889, 'date': '2013-05-15 15:35:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 16:26:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Looks good.

I noticed there's four places in the broker where metadata gets deserialized, and only two of them call utf8encodekeys().

The one in _reclaim() doesn't need it since the metadata isn't returned from that function anywhere. 

There's also a metadata-deserialization in get_info() that lacks a utf8encodekeys() call, but that code path is only taken if get_info() is called with include_metadata=True, which doesn't appear to be the case for any call in the entire Swift codebase. So, since that code's dead, it obviously doesn't need fixing.

So, I guess this looks good, and I'll go ahead and prune the dead code out of get_info() in a separate commit."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-05-16 11:53:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Metadata retrieving from sqlite must be str for key

Encode metadata key as utf8 if key is unicode when
retriving it from sqlite database.

Change-Id: I4ba11543d1bed17098b5e52dd768c75b403188a1
Fixes: bug #1172202

commit_message:
Pass the proper admin context to update_dhcp

Bug 1180111

Commit 14e2ed3ace769c4deaca3c48a2fa59863f637a5f introduced changes
to contexts passed around during resize. One of the calls to
update_dhcp was missed and was causing stack traces on
resize-revert.

Change-Id: Ib7bec51324c7bced009407af13a7fff7a724e020
(cherry picked from commit 42cc18da31ceb10ec0b26fe734e7556873f6fe71)

'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:22:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

If I understand correctly, the issue in the bug report is that these exceptions cause ugly log messages even though the error that causes them is not serious.  However, LOG.exception is still going to print the stack trace, and the exception is being re-raised, so whatever was logging the stack trace before is going to continue to do so.

I guess it seems to me that this change is actually going to cause uglier logging output than before.  Am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:22:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Okay, looks better to me.  The only question I still have is whether we should be logging these as errors if we're expecting them to happen during normal operation.  Maybe warnings would be better?"}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:22:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yeah, it was just a question that occurred to me when I was looking it over.  Since these timeouts can presumably also happen at unexpected times, I'm good with keeping it as an error."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 09:22:43.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Remove the term 'syspanel' from docs

Since the refactorization of syspanel occurred at
the very early Folsom days, the docs should reflect this too.

Cherry-picked from I8539b0b8bda2f63366c6de75b1a010f52f07fd0e

Fixes bug 1179873

Change-Id: I890c41048ad2cb9f44a1dacce01c570746ce27db

  https://github.com/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/453f4d2a

caused the ceilometer CLI to fail in all cases with:

commit_message:
Fix mis-scoped Client class breaking CLI

Fixes bug 1180439

The change in importation in this commit:

  https://github.com/openstack/python-ceilometerclient/commit/453f4d2a

caused the ceilometer CLI to fail in all cases with:

  'module' object has no attribute 'Client'

due to the mis-scoping of ceilometerclient.client.Client
as ceilometerclient.Client.

Change-Id: I5ec30bf74233f758519810629763ccb70bb7af87

[{'created': '2013-05-16 06:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add negative UT cases for subnet/GW create/update

When force_gateway_on_subnet is configured, ensure
that a GW with IP same as subnet, and BCAST GW IP
are rejected during subnet create. For subnet update,
ensure GW outside of subnet is rejected.

bug 1178675

Change-Id: Ice58f7e1be7966b247c165e52807405401e5a4ea
'}, {'created': '2013-05-16 06:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add negative UT cases for subnet/GW create/update

When force_gateway_on_subnet is configured, ensure
that a GW with IP same as subnet, and BCAST GW IP
are rejected during subnet create. For subnet update,
ensure GW outside of subnet is rejected.

bug 1178675

Change-Id: Ice58f7e1be7966b247c165e52807405401e5a4ea
'}]
commit_message:
Add negative UT cases for subnet/GW create/update

When force_gateway_on_subnet is configured, ensure
that a GW with IP same as subnet, and BCAST GW IP
are rejected during subnet create. For subnet update,
ensure GW outside of subnet is rejected.

bug 1178675

Change-Id: Ice58f7e1be7966b247c165e52807405401e5a4ea

commit_message:
relax amqplib and kombu version requirements

as nova did while ago.

this particular version of kombu doesn't work if newer msgpack happens
to be installed on the system.

bug 1178512

Change-Id: I2749623036723b5a772b1c4c01dc07437e421925

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 06:06:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix linuxbridge RPC message format

The linuxbridge, openvswitch, and hyperv plugins all use the same
basic RPC interface between their plugins and L2 agents. But the
attributes describing a virtual network passed from the plugin to the
agent over this interface differed for historical reasons. The
openvswitch and hyperv plugins each pass network_type,
physical_network, and segmentation_id attributes, whereas the
linuxbridge plugin previously passed vlan_id and physical_network
attributes, using special vlan_id values to indicate flat or local
network types.

This patch changes the linuxbridge plugin to pass network_type and
segmentation_id attributes instead of the vlan_id attribute, bringing
its message formats into sync with the other plugins. RPC
compatibility is required for blueprint modular-l2 so that the ml2
plugin can work with all three existing types of L2 agent. This RPC
message format change is also required for blueprint
vxlan-linuxbridge.

Unlike the vxlan-linuxbridge patch on which it is based (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/), this patch does not bump the
linuxbridge RPC version number, as the ml2 plugin will require all
three L2 agents to use the same RPC version. Instead, the updated
linuxbridge agent maintains compatibility with old linuxbridge plugins
by accepting either the old or new attributes. There is also a
configuration option, currently turned on by default, to enable the
updated linuxbridge plugin to pass the vlan_id attribute expected by
old linuxbridge agents along with the new attributes. These message
format compatibility mechanisms are intended to aid during upgrades,
and can eventually be removed.

Change-Id: I7cc1c9f96b09db6bab2c7d9f2b30b79fa4dab919
'}, {'created': '2013-05-16 06:06:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix linuxbridge RPC message format

plugin can work with all three existing types of L2 agent. This RPC
message format change is also required for blueprint
vxlan-linuxbridge.

Unlike the vxlan-linuxbridge patch on which it is based (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/), this patch does not bump the
linuxbridge RPC version number, as the ml2 plugin will require all
three L2 agents to use the same RPC version. Instead, the updated
linuxbridge agent maintains compatibility with old linuxbridge plugins
by accepting either the old or new attributes. There is also a
configuration option to enable the updated linuxbridge plugin to pass
the vlan_id attribute expected by old linuxbridge agents along with
the new attributes. These message format compatibility mechanisms are
intended to aid during upgrades, and can eventually be removed.

Change-Id: I7cc1c9f96b09db6bab2c7d9f2b30b79fa4dab919
'}]
commit_message:
Fix linuxbridge RPC message format

The linuxbridge, openvswitch, and hyperv plugins all use the same
basic RPC interface between their plugins and L2 agents. But the
attributes describing a virtual network passed from the plugin to the
agent over this interface differed for historical reasons. The
openvswitch and hyperv plugins each pass network_type,
physical_network, and segmentation_id attributes, whereas the
linuxbridge plugin previously passed vlan_id and physical_network
attributes, using special vlan_id values to indicate flat or local
network types.

This patch changes the linuxbridge plugin to pass network_type and
segmentation_id attributes instead of the vlan_id attribute, bringing
its message formats into sync with the other plugins. RPC
compatibility is required for blueprint modular-l2 so that the ml2
plugin can work with all three existing types of L2 agent. This RPC
message format change is also required for blueprint
vxlan-linuxbridge.

Unlike the vxlan-linuxbridge patch on which it is based (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/), this patch does not bump the
linuxbridge RPC version number, as the ml2 plugin will require all
three L2 agents to use the same RPC version. Instead, the updated
linuxbridge agent maintains compatibility with old linuxbridge plugins
by accepting either the old or new attributes. There is also a
configuration option, currently turned on by default, to enable the
updated linuxbridge plugin to pass the vlan_id attribute expected by
old linuxbridge agents along with the new attributes. These message
format compatibility mechanisms are intended to aid during upgrades,
and can eventually be removed.

Change-Id: I7cc1c9f96b09db6bab2c7d9f2b30b79fa4dab919

This change effectively makes use of VXLAN ports in the upstream Linux kernel. I'm curious if you've looked at the overlap with this review here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26516/

This adds support for the same thing into the Linux Bridge plugin. I think you should contact the author of that patch and see if you can reuse some of what is done there to enable the same functionality (making use of VXLAN ports in the upstream kernel as ports on an OVS bridge) with your patch here.

In addition, OVS 1.10 was just released with VXLAN support natively inside of it. There is a blueprint here I had opened a while back to add this support into the OVS plugin, and I'm getting started on that this week in fact. This will utilize the VXLAN implementation inside of OVS instead of the Linux kernel VXLAN ports.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-vxlan-lisp-tunnel"}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

It seems the ovs_driver just hooks network/port creation.
So can notifier (or rpc call) be used? Thus it can be used for any ovs-based
plugins.

The driver API is defined, but not all methods are used. Is it under design?
What about live-migration support?

naming: probably ovs_driver is misleading. I think ovs plugin is just chosen
for first candidate.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(14 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (13 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Responding to Isaku's comments:

Q: can notifier (or rpc call) be used?
A: No, because it would limit the hardware vendors to RPCs already available (AMQP mostly). In our case we may use any RPC vendor supports.

Q: what about live-migration support?
A: Live migration is not supported by nova+quantum (see migrate_instance_start() in nova network API), it is only supported by nova network API (discussion on quantum mailing list).

Q: The driver API is defined, but not all methods are used. Is it under design?
A: We should probably remove the get_tenant_network() from API, because it really does not make much sense. Other APIs are used."}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> > Hi satish. Regarding to RPC, I wasn't clear enough. HW doesn't > need to speak RPC directly. something like
quantum-server --RPC--> driver-agent -- what ever communication--> hw switch

Hi Isaku

We considered that, but it is considerably more efficient in having the hardware driver be a plugin extension of the OVSPlugin. This way its a direct function call into the hardware driver running in the same quantum-server process.

Also note that in the current plugin architecture, the segmentation id is allocated by each individual plugin (OVS/LB etc). So the hardware driver needs to necessarily layer underneath the OVSplugin.

This may be addressable in a more generic way with the revamped plugin architecture though.

Thanks
Satish"}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

Could you share how host and TOR works together?
In my understanding, if we use OVS plugin is vlan mode, TOR should be trunk mode.  How it will be change with this patch?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

IMO, host means physical host in another component in the OpenStack.
However, host means VM in this patch.. so we should change the naming of host.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

>Could you share how host and TOR works together? In my understanding, if we use OVS plugin is vlan mode, TOR should be trunk mode. How it will be change with this patch?

Yes - today in most OpenStack deployments we have seen, network administrators trunk "all vlans" on all ports connected to compute hosts. This is undesirable - due to flooding traffic not belonging to a particular tenant onto a port. Also it may be viewed as a potential security issue in data centers (tenant 1 can snoop on tenant 2 traffic because the switch trunks all vlans).

So what the patch does is to let OVSPlugin make the decision on which vlan is allocated for a particular quantum network. It then communicates this to a hardware vendor's driver(s). The hardware vendor driver communicates with the hardware switch(s) and trunks *only* the vlans for which VMs have been placed on that port.

This avoids unnecessary broadcast traffic from other vlans reaching those ports.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Fixed Jenkins build failures.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi Nachi,

Thanks for your comment. We meant a physical host when we introduced this patch. The idea is that the driver is told about the host where the VM is launched. The driver can then talk to the physical switch/switches and appropriately trunk the vlans based on this physical host information.

Regards,
Satish'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

What impact does this have on things using the core OVS plugin? The Cisco plugin is dependent on OVS in it's current architectural form. Does introducing this change mean we have to refit the entire plugin to this architecture and it doesn't look like we can do some of the complex orchestration we need with the extension. 

I agree with folks above, this belongs in the ML2 architecture."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

I think there are a few items which are conflated here. I don't believe that the usefulness of an approach to manipulate both physical and virtual switches in the same configuration workflow is in question. That said, probably the question that needs to be asked is what was the original intent of the OVS plugin? If it was only to manage the configuration of OVS, then making it aware of the physical switches probably breaks that intent.
Assuming that this was the intent, when trying to do something very similar in the Cisco plugin, we leveraged the OVS plugin as is (without any modifications), and built a sort of a meta-plugin around it to orchestrate between the physical and virtual switches.
Also, it might be a helpful practice (as is being generally followed) to keep core changes like those to a community part of the framework in a separate commit from those which are vendor specific."}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: No score

removing my -2
let's start the review and discussions on this driver
I personally did not get a good feeling on this BP from the community based on the summit presentation. However, I would like to hear from the rest of the core members. I would prefer to have the ML2 BP merged and then find out how this one could be integrated."}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

Yes, I did review your code.
My name is Edgar not Edger! ;-)
You should wait until ML2 get merged and then work on this idea, I think we should have an Object Model reflecting the functionality of the Physical Networking Infrastructure (PNI) vs. the Virtual Networking Infrastructure (VNI). What you have proposed will work as long as we donâ€™t extend Quantum domain but we want to extend it and this is why I said before â€œad-hocâ€
The idea is to have a general pluggable architecture for all potential PNI drivers out there such as CISCO NX-OS, Brocade, Arista, HP, Juniper, etc.. I am not telling you that proposal will not work with them; I am just highlighting that part.!
I foreseen Quantum able to perform all kind of networking configuration across PNI and VNI but obviously concatenate everything in the same monolithic plugin will not scale and will be quite complicated of extending. 
Finally, you mentioned that this solution can co-exist with ML2, well I think you are adding another driver inside a potential driver in ML2 proposal, donâ€™t you think there is something wrong?
These are just my ideas and point of view based on my work in Quantum, at the end of the day this is a work with a community and everybody will decide how to move forward.'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I completely disagree with this approach, even that it is minimally invasive, it is still a hook that will need to be maintained and  very ad-hoc for this use case with ToR switches. I recommend to wait until ML2 and see how we could extended without affecting the other drivers and also being able to expose all the future PNI (Physical Networking Infrastructure) extensions such as QoS, ACLs, SLAs, etc.."}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi,
I do not think that we should hold this fix for the ML2 plugin. This is something that is very useful and beneficial. When the ML2 is in branch we should make sure that it has the support that you guys have mentioned, but this should not be a blocker for this feature.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Based on the discussions at the summit, it does seem like supporting Arista's TOR switch use case via the MechanismDriver abstraction in the ml2 plugin should be a viable solution, and the Arista folks I spoke with were very interested in exploring that approach. Whether to merge this patch set in the mean time seems to be a question of timing. 

An updated WIP ml2 patch set will be posted this week for feedback, but this will not yet include usable MechanismDriver support. This version of the ml2 plugin will work with the existing openvswitch agent, supporting local, flat, and vlan networks. A corresponding devstack patch will also be posted.

I'm committed to getting the ml2 plugin merged for H-1 with full openvswitch and linuxbridge plugin parity (assuming neither of those changes too drastically). Following that milestone, it should be possible to implement the full MechanismDriver support needed to support Arista's use case in H-1, or in H-2 at the latest. 

I suggest, if possible, that we hold off on merging this patch for now, and evaluate the upcoming WIP ml2 patch to decide how well and how soon it will be able to support Arista's use case."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

I agree with Edgar. ML2 sounds right place'}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

Arvind, 

The way you phrase your question seems to imply that you have not had a chance to review the code/patch yet or have developed the understanding of this patch's impact on OVS PlugIn. Furthermore, you need to understand the impact of ML2 Plugin on OVS - it will completely deprecate it. 
Having said that please read Satish's reply about the impact of this patch on OVS PlugIn and then make a determination as to what impacts Cisco PlugIn - as your concern seems to center around the impact to Cisco PlugIn."}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree with Gary. This is a very useful feature and should not be blocked for ML2.  We reviewed the ML2 PlugIn code with Bob while in Portland.  It is a great work in progress and we will work with Bob to contribute to ML2 effort and make sure we have full integration with ML2 - if and when it become ready for prime time. Until then there is no reason to block this. 
This is a fully reviewed and tested code. In fact the customers are running it in their labs and are very happy with this. 
Thanks
-Sukhdev'}, {'account_id': 6558, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

Edger, 

Now I am completely confused by your comment - "very ad-hoc". How is this driver approach very ad-hoc where as the ML2 architecture has exactly same (or very similar driver approach) Would you please elaborate? 

"How could we extend without affecting the other drivers" - which drivers are you referring to? Would you please further elaborate? Again, have you had a chance to review/look at the code? which driver does this code impact? 

As to other extensions such as QoS, ACLs, SLAs, etc. is really an orthogonal issue and is not directly related to  basic L2 provisioning. 

This driver solution can co-exist with ML2 plugin - as long as OVS plugin exists. This common driver adapter layer can be used directly by ML2 plugin without any duplication - in fact, it makes ML2 job easier.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

Hi Kyle,
Looks like you did not get a chance to review the diff yet - there's no proprietary code or interface here.

What we have done is to extend the OVS plugin with a driver adapter layer. This is provided by a driver adapter library which lives in quantum/common. The driver adapter library loads a vendor plugin or even a list of vendor plugins to allow multiple vendors to share the quantum network configuration. 

All this is common, open-source code, which seems to us to be a useful addition to the OVSPlugin. The code added to OVSPlugin is minimal and can be easily adopted by other plugins (for example, the linuxbridge plugin).

At this point, we would like to thank Dan Wendlandt, for suggesting this architecture to us. We had started down the path of writing an Arista plugin just like every one else, but Dan guided us to do the right thing instead - and extend the OVSPlugin so that it shares its quantum network configuration through a driver interface.

We feel that this is a valuable enhancement to the stock OVSPlugin, and stands up as a good solution independent of the ML2 plugin. Its also extensively been tested with Folsom and Grizzly and running live in customer deployments as we speak.

Regards,
Satish"}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi Sumit,

Yes we are aware of the Cisco plugin design where it sub-classes the OVSPlugin and orchestrates the physical/virtual network. We had considered an identical design originally, but Dan pointed out to us that he did not want to us to add yet another vendor plugin into Quantum. There are too many out there already and the support burden goes up with each vendor plugin. We believe this is a wrong model to follow, and instead flipped the design on its head.

Instead, if you consider the fact that OVSPlugin and LinuxBridge plugin are the core plugins for orchestrating virtual networks, then, adding a hardware driver interface into these plugins for orchestrating physical networks makes sense. This way each vendor does not have to duplicate what you essentially did for the Cisco plugin.

With our solution, each vendor driver (instead of plugin) focusses purely on managing and orchestrating their devices, and the common virtual network provisioning remains in the core OVS plugin. This is very similar to the ML2 plugin. In fact, the ML2 plugin can use our driver adapter layer for interfacing with physical drivers.

In fact, OVSPlugin and LinuxBridge plugin are almost identical, and the ML2 plugin is essentially collapsing them to a single mechanism, which will deprecate OVS/LinuxBridge plugins.

Regards
Satish'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30: Restored'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

Hi Arvind,

As I mentioned above in the reply to Kyle, the change in OVSPlugin is very minimal (just 3-4 lines of calls to the generic driver adapter). If no vendor driver is configured, these calls become no-ops. 

So it works very seamlessly with OVSPlugin and just sharing the quantum network configuration with a driver.

Hope that makes it clear.

Regards,
Satish'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30.'}, {'account_id': 6715, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 30:

Agree with you folks. When we started working on this driver interface within the OVSPlugin, this seemed to be the most sensible option to solve our customers problems. Most of our customers deploy openvswitch, and we needed a real way to provision both the virtual switch and the physical top-of-the rack switch with the same vlan information.

In the light of the summit discussions, it does seem that the ML2 architecture would enable us to achieve this provisioning. So, we look forward to working with the ML2 team and re-work our driver into a ML2 Mechanism driver.

Looking forward to a ML2 patch-set which will enable us to start our work.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 31: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-16 06:03:08.000000000', 'message': "Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins

This patch describes a generic hardware driver interface which may be used within
the Quantum Plugins which will enable support for different hardware backends
for L2 network segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.). Currently only the
OVSPlugin has been modified to use this hardware driver interface, but in future
other plugins may be able to use this interface.

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce a hardware driver which will allow using vendor's hardware to be
used within Openstack, along with virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the Vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff also includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20

commit_message:
Generic hardware driver interface for Quantum Plugins

This patch describes a generic hardware driver interface which may be used within
the Quantum Plugins which will enable support for different hardware backends
for L2 network segregation (VLANs, tunneling, etc.). Currently only the
OVSPlugin has been modified to use this hardware driver interface, but in future
other plugins may be able to use this interface.

This may be useful for existing data centers with hardware switches which needs
to be used along with Openstack infrastructure. In this case a hardware vendor
may introduce a hardware driver which will allow using vendor's hardware to be
used within Openstack, along with virtual switches to provide L2 network
segregation.

This will allow automatic L2 network provisioning on the hardware devices
alongside with the Vswitch provisioning in the compute node hypervisors.

This diff also includes the source code for an Arista Driver which supports
provisioning of Arista TOR (top-of-the-rack) switches alongside with open
vswitches.

There is a related one line change needed in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py,
allocate_for_instance() to pass the hostname on which the instance was started to
Quantum create_port().

Implements: blueprint ovsplugin-hardware-devices
Change-Id: Ibccb032a433a81d9facdadce04840841ee4b0c20

commit_message:
Remove setuptools-git as run time dependency

Remove setuptools-git as a run time dependency since
it is only used to generate a tarball.

Change-Id: Idcbfd8e047340fe246ccb20e2f199fcce69ad43a
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Add a base workflow task management library + supporting utilities.

In order to perform basic workflow tasks there first needs
to be basic constructs that allow for tasks to be applied and
reverted and resources to be locked (so that they can not
be simulatenously used).

Change-Id: Ibf6013da923342062d0aee9e509da5e1dd2a7069
Implements: blueprint structured-state-management-core-library

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 13:25:01.000000000', 'message': "Speed up tests through more DB caching

Caches the result of a series of DB statements run on a connection,
then replays them for the next connection that runs the same series.

It is a work in progress and causes test failures still.

I gathered some stastics of similar sql statements executed by the
tests, and there are some good cases where caching the db results like
this should help.

For example, the same 8 statements may be executed in sequence by 101
different tests (this is an actual case found when testing this).
With the caching, it'll mean simply 8 integer in a dict lookups, instead
of actually executing the sql in sqlite.

If it turns out that it doesn't help too much the next step may be
intelligently storing the actual state of the DB (using sqlite backup
api) ..

Change-Id: Ie10dad1479b83e16fbd2f2902949931567b39784
"}]
commit_message:
Speed up tests through more DB caching

Caches the result of a series of DB statements run on a connection,
then replays them for the next connection that runs the same series.

It is a work in progress and causes test failures still.

I gathered some stastics of similar sql statements executed by the
tests, and there are some good cases where caching the db results like
this should help.

For example, the same 8 statements may be executed in sequence by 101
different tests (this is an actual case found when testing this).
With the caching, it'll mean simply 8 integer in a dict lookups, instead
of actually executing the sql in sqlite.

If it turns out that it doesn't help too much the next step may be
intelligently storing the actual state of the DB (using sqlite backup
api) ..

Change-Id: Ie10dad1479b83e16fbd2f2902949931567b39784

Fixes: bug: #1176101

resource tracker, that caused available resource counted the all
instances including error status one.

Fixes bug: 1169929

Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>'}]
commit_message:
Wrong memory and storage computing in resource tracer

There is an error in available resource computing logic within nova
resource tracker, that caused available resource counted the all
instances including error status one.

Fixes bug: 1169929

Change-Id: Ibebddc31461e691816d828c53465a0d81b7128a5
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Fix endpoints[0] hard coded problem in novaclient/v1_1/shell.py function
do_endpoints

Changes: read os_region_name from args, if os_region_name is empty,
print all endpoints. else only print matched endpoints.

Fix bug 1169051

Change-Id: I3d2a804066197f5fd4995ce35271be513ef58681

commit_message:
Move bin/swift to an entrypoint.

It makes it easier for all of the tools to do their jobs when the code
is inside of the swiftclient package.

Change-Id: I8de85d7dc6f4a14574c7f1beb63e9640f17146e1

Can you elaborate on why this is better?  What was there seemed fine to me, and it's a good bit simpler ..."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-01 02:18:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This is more pythonic in what way? It uses more python?

I think the complexity hugely outweighs any potential benefit."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-01 02:20:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-05-01 04:34:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My thought was that if say we moved this property extension to utils.py (sometime) then the amount of code that is duplicated to do this lazy loading activity is reduced overall. Thus the functions become smaller with logic that is elsewhere to do the lazy loading via this new property.

Other major python libraries have similar functionality, https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid/blob/master/pyramid/decorator.py and https://pypi.python.org/pypi/lazy so my thought was that it seems like we could benefit from something similar. But maybe you guys don't agree."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-05-01 04:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Zope also has this, https://pypi.python.org/pypi/zope.cachedescriptors/3.5.1 so it seems like something pretty common.'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-05-01 04:50:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Django also has similar stuff, https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/utils/functional.py so maybe if its pythonic enough for those libraries it should be pythonic enough for nova?'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-05-01 19:36:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-01 19:37:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Do not merge

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-01 20:21:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

[{'created': '2013-05-01 01:35:39.000000000', 'message': 'Use a property decorator to lazily load the apis.

Instead of having special per instance logic to load the
api objects we should prefer to use the more pythonic
extension to the standard @property to lazily load and
return the properties when they are first accessed.

Change-Id: I6656f77c1cf19a484607de662b6f25fa02e0bad3
'}, {'created': '2013-05-01 19:36:28.000000000', 'message': 'Use a property decorator to lazily load the apis.

Instead of having special per instance logic to load the
api objects we should prefer to use the more pythonic
extension to the standard @property to lazily load and
return the properties when they are first accessed.

Change-Id: I6656f77c1cf19a484607de662b6f25fa02e0bad3
'}]
commit_message:
Use a property decorator to lazily load the apis.

Instead of having special per instance logic to load the
api objects we should prefer to use the more pythonic
extension to the standard @property to lazily load and
return the properties when they are first accessed.

Change-Id: I6656f77c1cf19a484607de662b6f25fa02e0bad3

commit_message:
Move tests/ dir into swiftclient/.

tests is not actually a top-level module. There is one of those in the
Python source tree, in fact. These are tests for swiftclient, which
means from a codepath perspective, they code in them belongs to the
swiftclient module.

Change-Id: Id4c0242925ffe14430d115fc797efd770fd0aa11

subject: Implementation of replication servers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 866, 'name': 'Chmouel Boudjnah', 'email': 'chmouel@chmouel.com', 'username': 'chmouel'}, {'_account_id': 917, 'name': 'Chuck Thier', 'email': 'cthier@gmail.com', 'username': 'cthier'}, {'_account_id': 1216, 'name': 'gholt', 'email': 'z-launchpad@brim.net', 'username': 'gholt'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2448, 'name': 'Diane Fleming', 'email': 'dfleming@austin.rr.com', 'username': 'diane-fleming'}, {'_account_id': 2622, 'name': 'Samuel Merritt', 'email': 'sam@swiftstack.com', 'username': 'torgomatic'}, {'_account_id': 2696, 'name': 'Darrell Bishop', 'email': 'dbishop@nvidia.com', 'username': 'darrellb'}, {'_account_id': 4108, 'name': 'David Hadas', 'email': 'davidh@il.ibm.com', 'username': 'david-hadas'}, {'_account_id': 6198, 'name': 'Peter Portante', 'email': 'peter.a.portante@gmail.com', 'username': 'peter-a-portante'}, {'_account_id': 6577, 'name': 'Sergey Kraynev', 'email': 'sergejyit@gmail.com', 'username': 'skraynev'}, {'_account_id': 6677, 'name': 'Oleg Gelbukh', 'email': 'ogelbukh@mirantis.com', 'username': 'gelbuhos'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-14 12:23:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

"}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-01-14 13:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-01-14 13:51:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful
