- http://logs.openstack.org/19618/2/check/gate-devstack-vm-quantum/3292 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-14 18:30:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I haven't examined the patch yet, but it'll definitely need some documentation updates (which may already be there?) and the commit should include the string "DocImpact".'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-14 20:13:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm not a big fan of a whole new set of replication servers for this. Why can't the existing servers be used and just listen on all interfaces (which I bet is what most folks do anyway)?"}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-01-18 11:57:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's absolutely possible to have storage-servers answering REPCLIATE request on dedicated network. Replication servers are optional.
Separation of replication-servers into processes of their own was suggested by John during our initial discussion of the proposal. In our understanding, security is primary concern, given we have WAN-accessible replication network. In this case, it may be reasonable to have limited function server running in separate process to listen on this public address."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-01-20 16:18:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

why don't you bind to all interfaces like gholt suggest and iptables/firewall the ip/port you don't want to have it accessed to please the security folks?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-01-20 17:21:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@gholt, Chmouel:

If I had an all-in-one node deployment (nodes running both proxy-server and backend storage servers), I'd rather not have my backend servers binding to 0.0.0.0, relying only on iptables (or whatever) to keep traffic out of my backend server(s) on the client-exposed interface.  In this case, I'd prefer separate servers binding only to their proper interface.

It seems like having the additional replication servers be optional allows the above deployment, while still allowing other deployments to have a separate replication network with only normal backend servers bound to 0.0.0.0.

We'd need existing deployments to be "left alone" and for separate replication network and/or separate replication servers to be fully "opt-in", of course.  But is having the choice between "existing, no separate replication network", "separate replication network overlaid with 0.0.0.0 binding", and "separate replication network with separate replication servers" a bad thing?'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-22 00:54:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'll keep my -1 but obviously it just takes two +2s to override. ;-)

I don't see this separation of processes as allowing any truly better security. If you have access to REPLICATE or you have access to PUT, DELETE you pretty much can do the same damage. Granted, only having access to REPLICATE means you can't GET things, but that's about all the separation I see. And, in its place, I see more configs to maintain, a bit more memory used, more processes to monitor, and more lines of code to accrue more bugs."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-22 01:09:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, I didn't think about folks with publicly routable backend servers and the fact that you can't bind to multiple interfaces with backend services right now. Are there really folks like that? That seems dangerous just generally. I guess I'll leave my -1 but make it softer... Maybe a -0.5?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-01-22 01:18:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

For the moment, I'm going to ignore the question of whether or not separate replication servers are desirable or not. I need more time to think about it.

However, this implementation of replication servers could be much simpler. Instead of 3 new subclasses, I'd rather see a middleware that only allows the REPLICATE verb. Then, instead of a bunch of new scripts in bin/ and 3 new config files and 3 new virtually-identical classes, this reduces to 3 new config files.

Essentially, to get a REPLICATE-only object server, I want a normal object server with a piece of middleware. That seems like the simplest thing that could possibly work."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-22 20:28:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hmm, good idea Sam. But what about instead just having the existing servers configurable as to what methods they will respond to -- without extra middleware to accomplish that?

If you want to run 2 object-servers for instance, you'd replace /etc/swift/object-server.conf with /etc/swift/object-server/1.conf and 2.conf and make sure to specify the -c 1|2 switch on your swift-init calls.

?"}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-01-24 18:43:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@gholt: That capability was added with 'allowed_methods' in our patch. In following versions we can convert this var into configuration parameter."}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-01-25 09:29:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@gholt

Regarding running 2 instances of *-server with different configs: we'll trade simplicity of /bin/ scripts for complexity of init scripts (i.e. swift/common/manager.py). Swift init script attempts to determine a name of configuration file and PID file for the process based on the name of the process, so we need to hack it significantly to make it run 2 proccesses with the same name (e.g. 2 instances of object-server).

Please, correct me if I'm getting this wrong."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-01-25 16:06:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

swift-init should already support multiple configs since most of us use it that way daily on our saios (swift all-in-one setups for development).'}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-01-25 17:39:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yes, you're right, that's my mistake. Please, disregard the last comment. 

We will start working on new patch set at the next week, aiming to move 'allowed_methods' to configuration and discard additional servers from /bin/."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-02-02 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-02-08 09:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-02-08 16:11:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-02-08 17:22:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/19618/3/check/gate-swift-docs/1328 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19618/3/check/gate-swift-pep8/1471 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19618/3/check/gate-swift-python26/1575 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/19618/3/check/gate-swift-python27/1578 : SUCCESS

'}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-03-08 07:47:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

Please change the CLI to not use a comma as the way to hint that a replication IP is added. a comma suggests that this is an alternative IP to be used as in multi-homing. Since we plan to contribute a ptach for multi-homing right after 1.8 is released, it would make the CLI highly confusing since both the ip used by teh proxy and the one used for replication could be multi-homed.  


Use: 'swift-ring-builder object.builder add z3-127.0.0.1:6030 replicate 127.0.0.1:6070 /sdb3 1'  instead"}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-03-08 08:07:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: (1 inline comment)

This patch handles two possible cases -  either replication/port are defined in the ring or not.

The implementation handles these two cases in many different places, inseat of a centralized point. This complicates the code and makes it less readable. 

I suggest that the ring will hide all this complexity by ensuring that every device always have a replication_ip and replication_port (if no such ip or port was provided by the user or read from the ring file, it will be set to the device ip/port by the ring while the ring is being read). Thereafter, the code will need to handle only one case since there will always be a replication ip and port.'}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-03-11 11:37:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

David, thanks for thorough review and useful feedback. We will review the logic of reading ring data to ensure that replication parameters are assigned in one place, if this fits in release schedule. Otherwise, we can submit separate patch once release is out to fix the code style.

Regarding swift-ring-builder command format, could you please point at some explaination of multi-homing feature? This would help us to understand how exactly our proposed format affects the feature, and try to accomodate to ensure compatibility. Unfortunately, adding spaces in current device format will break the description string in separate arguments. This is definitely doable, but once again may affect the release schedule.

Note that we're planning to implement option to use argparse syntax in swift-ring-builder. Does this align with your feature requirements?"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-11 17:36:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

It's funny you should mention optparse; when I was adding regions, I got irritated enough with the device DSL that I hacked up some optparse support for "swift-ring-builder- add".

I'd been holding off on pushing it because it depends on another pending change (the regions one), but I'll go push it now so you guys can see it. Feel free to just steal the code wholesale if you think it would help.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-11 17:37:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

optparse code is at https://review.openstack.org/24091'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-03-16 09:14:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-03-16 09:42:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

ip1:port1[,ip2:port[,ip3:port]][Rip_r1:port_r1[,ip_r2:port_r]]

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-26 15:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: (4 inline comments)

Seems good overall to me, but why the change from "allowed_methods = x,y,z" to "replication_server = t|f"? Now there's no way to make a the non-replication server refuse REPLICATE requests if desired.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-26 15:25:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

Oh, I guess replication_server = True would eventually mean allowed_methods = REPLICATE,REPLICATION automatically? I can see that. But maybe it's settings could be true, false, and "only".

true = all methods allowed

false = all methods except REPLICATE (and eventually REPLICATION)

only = REPLICATE (and eventually REPLICATION) only

Anybody else have thoughts on this?'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-28 19:32:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

@gholt, that change fell out of the discussion at the Summit.

What's the desire in preventing replication-related verbs getting handled in the non-replication-only (normal) daemons?  It's true that nothing /should/ be trying to use those daemons for replication, but would it hurt anything for them to try and answer?

I'm just wondering if a more complicated config setting here is worth it.  It may be... I'm kind of on the fence."}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-04-29 08:22:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

Gregory, Darrel

This change was discussed and approved at summit. However, as @gholt pointed out, current implementation (True disables answering to anything besides REPLICATE, False enables handling of all requests, False is a default) does not seems complete. We probably want to retain the ability to serve all request types, as this is what Swift does now. But we also want to have an option to disable handling of replication requests to ensure that misconfiguration won't go unnoticed (i.e. deployer wants to segregate replication traffic, but due incorrect ip address assignment his storage servers still answer to REPLICATE on standard node ip). I think the following scheme might be used. 

Flag replication_server takes following values:
* True - only REPLICATE (and eventually REPLICATION) verb is recognized and handled.
* False - all verbs except REPLICATE are recognized and handled.
* None - all verbs are recognized and handled (the default behavior).
Thus we won't break anything in existing deployments and (hopefully) keep clear semantics of the flag.

Any thoughts on this?"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-04-29 13:33:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

I'm definitely good with that."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-29 14:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: (1 inline comment)

To be clear, when you say "None", which combination of the following are included?

 * replication_server not specified in config at all
 * replication_server = none
 * replication_server = None
 * replication_server = n
 * replication_server = nooon

That last one is a deployer's typo.  Regardless of the exact answer, we need to make sure it's clear in relevant documentation (like comments in the -sample configs, release notes, etc.) what deployers need to do or should not do to retain the current semantics.

swift.common.utils.config_true_value() does a good job distinguishing between "true" (case-insensitive membership in a broad vocabulary of truthiness) and "false" (everything else).  Are there existing good examples of tri-state config values?'}, {'account_id': 6677, 'date': '2013-04-30 11:49:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

Darrell, by 'None' value I meant primarily the first case, flag not in configuration file and effectively undefined. This would be a default case for deployers who upgrade release version without updating configuration files, for example."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-04-30 15:32:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

Oleg,
That's cool.  Can you make sure the -sample config files and relevant documentation make it clear that the setting is tri-state and one of the states (the default one) may only be selected by NOT specifying the config setting at all?  In other words, there is no way to say "do the default behavior", you can only achieve that by not saying anything.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-07 14:52:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

Ping!'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-05-07 16:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

I'm reexamining the code to see if I can figure out why."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-14 14:44:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

Ah, I put the original probe tests from master back in and they ran at normal speed, so it is something to do with the probe test changes you made that make them take almost twice as long. Is there a good reason for this, or an unintended side effect?'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-05-14 14:45:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

@gholt: It's normal behavior for new added test. If you want reexamining code, you will need watch this file -  test/probe/test_replication_servers_working.py"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-14 15:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29:

Ah okay, I see. I'm going to look into that test much more closely; I've must've completely scanned over it before.

A quick look and it seems too fragile, dependent on local configuration, like /srv/[1-4] file systems, 60s timings and such. You'll notice the other tests start a subset of servers and do writes to the proper ip:ports, bring up all servers and run single pass replicators, check the previously down servers for the data, etc, etc. Seldom scanning or altering the file system directly and not waiting for cycles/passes that can be configuration dependent (using the "once" modes instead). Those that do hit the file system directly use the config files to figure out where the file should be with the 'devices' value, etc.

Aside from that, this quick change brought that test from 193.188s to 51.147s.

https://gist.github.com/anonymous/fdd2bb610002f8df59db'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:42:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 30.'}, {'account_id': 6577, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:45:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 30:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-01-14 11:35:29.000000000', 'message': 'Implementation of replication servers

Support separate replication ip address:
- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication processe uses new function now.

Replication network parameters:
- Replication network fields (replication_ip, replication_port)
  support was added to device dictionary in swift-ring-builder script.
- Changes were made to support new fields in search, show and set_info
  functions.

Implementation of replication servers:
- Separate replication servers were implemented.
- Starting scripts and configs for replication servers were added.
- Algorithm of selecting config file for *-replicator were
  changed.
- Allowed_methods attribute was added in account-, container-,
  object-server.

Change-Id: Ie9af5bdcdf9241c355e36053ca4adfe49dc35bd0
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

"}, {'created': '2013-05-13 11:29:33.000000000', 'message': 'Implementation of replication servers

Support separate replication ip address:
- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication process uses new function now.

Replication network parameters:
- Replication network fields (replication_ip, replication_port)
  support was added to device dictionary in swift-ring-builder script.
- Changes were made to support new fields in search, show and set_info
  functions.

Implementation of replication servers:
- Separate replication servers use the same code as normal replication
  servers, but with replication_server parameter = True.  When using a
  separate replication network, the non-replication servers set
  replication_server = False.  When there is no separate replication
  network (the default case), replication_server is not included in the config.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ie9af5bdcdf9241c355e36053ca4adfe49dc35bd0
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

commit_message:
Implementation of replication servers

Support separate replication ip address:
- Added new function in utils. This function provides ability
  to select separate IP address for replication service.
- Db_replicator and object replicators were changed.
  Replication process uses new function now.

Replication network parameters:
- Replication network fields (replication_ip, replication_port)
  support was added to device dictionary in swift-ring-builder script.
- Changes were made to support new fields in search, show and set_info
  functions.

Implementation of replication servers:
- Separate replication servers use the same code as normal replication
  servers, but with replication_server parameter = True.  When using a
  separate replication network, the non-replication servers set
  replication_server = False.  When there is no separate replication
  network (the default case), replication_server is not included in the config.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ie9af5bdcdf9241c355e36053ca4adfe49dc35bd0
Implements: blueprint dedicated-replication-network

commit_message:
solidfire: Make sure src_uuid is passed correctly

src_uuid wasn't passed correctly as an attribute because
the variable was wrongly quoted and couldn't be interpolated.

Fixes: bug #1180611
Change-Id: If22dda162a28138cf447ce12bbe061f623e6d076

commit_message:
Restore test dependency on Ming

Add Ming to the dependency list so we get MIM for in-memory
testing with the storage API.

Fixes bug 1176017

Change-Id: Ib1d87cab4b7616af354c4b0f937eb734b9dc9d1a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-16 02:09:27.000000000', 'message': "Remove calls to policy.check from plugin logic

Blueprint make-authz-orthogonal

This patch implements part #3 of this blueprint, according to its
specification.
It does so by allowing the view generator in the API layer to strip
off fields which do not satify authorization policies.
Also, some checks in unit tests for plugins relied on the
capability of the plugin to invoke directly the policy engine.
This checks have been removed and replaced by equivalent unit tests.
Finally, this patch required changes to most test cases for API
extensions in order to ensure the resource attribute map was
updated with the extension's attributes

Change-Id: I1ef94a8a628d34697254b68d7a539bd1c636876e

commit_message:
Remove calls to policy.check from plugin logic

Blueprint make-authz-orthogonal

This patch implements part #3 of this blueprint, according to its
specification.
It does so by allowing the view generator in the API layer to strip
off fields which do not satify authorization policies.
Also, some checks in unit tests for plugins relied on the
capability of the plugin to invoke directly the policy engine.
This checks have been removed and replaced by equivalent unit tests.
Finally, this patch required changes to most test cases for API
extensions in order to ensure the resource attribute map was
updated with the extension's attributes

Change-Id: I1ef94a8a628d34697254b68d7a539bd1c636876e

commit_message:
Deprecating old dot path locations for Folsom configs

In grizzly, we made a lot of structure changes. This deprecates the old
locations so the dot paths in old configs still work but give warnings
in the logs of what needs to be updated.

Fixes: bug #1168573
Change-Id: I7b1754b0e59a923afa623871fc3be07362bf1bdc

commit_message:
Set the default pipline config file for tests

Some of the tests that use a pipeline as a side-effect
(mostly the API tests, now that we create a pipline
automatically in the Pecan hook) only ran if there was
a config file in the production location. This change
resets the default for the pipeline_cfg_file option
to a location that is valid while the tests are running,
even if there is no configuration file in /etc/ceilometer.

Change-Id: I1164df85fd65002660d48d8d76cbfc4a3664f0ea
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-14 07:30:08.000000000', 'message': "Update KillFilter to stop at '\0' for readlink() function.

Python's readlink() implementation doesn't stop at '\0' when reading
file path. Thus after dnsmasq upgrade, it may return something like
'/usr/sbin/dnsmasq\03453 (deleted)', while C's or Shell's readlink()
return '/usr/sbin/dnsmasq'. This patch fixes this problem by cutting
the readlink() results with '\0', so that KillFilter could get correct
path.

Bug 1179793

Change-Id: I7354941e0508e019c8c9b63b87ad39f52ccb51ca

commit_message:
Update KillFilter to stop at '\0' for readlink() function.

Python's readlink() implementation doesn't stop at '\0' when reading
file path. Thus after dnsmasq upgrade, it may return something like
'/usr/sbin/dnsmasq\03453 (deleted)', while C's or Shell's readlink()
return '/usr/sbin/dnsmasq'. This patch fixes this problem by cutting
the readlink() results with '\0', so that KillFilter could get correct
path.

Bug 1179793

Change-Id: I7354941e0508e019c8c9b63b87ad39f52ccb51ca

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 20:41:43.000000000', 'message': "Support capping message versions in the client.

When doing a rolling upgrade, we need to be able to tell all rpc clients
to hold off on sending newer versions of messages until all nodes
understand the new message version.  This patch adds the oslo component
of this.

It's quite simple.  The rpc proxy just stores the version cap and will
raise an exception if code ever tries to send a message that exceeds
this cap.

Allowing the cap to be configured and generating different types of
messages based on the configured value is the hard part here, but that
is left up to the project using the rpc library.

Implements blueprint rpc-version-control.

Change-Id: Ia69db03a80dc3b1c63d52c7e163ea3cfec80c882
"}]
commit_message:
Support capping message versions in the client.

When doing a rolling upgrade, we need to be able to tell all rpc clients
to hold off on sending newer versions of messages until all nodes
understand the new message version.  This patch adds the oslo component
of this.

It's quite simple.  The rpc proxy just stores the version cap and will
raise an exception if code ever tries to send a message that exceeds
this cap.

Allowing the cap to be configured and generating different types of
messages based on the configured value is the hard part here, but that
is left up to the project using the rpc library.

Implements blueprint rpc-version-control.

Change-Id: Ia69db03a80dc3b1c63d52c7e163ea3cfec80c882

commit_message:

so it's not an acceptable change as written.

commit_message:
NetApp server tunneling fix.

NetApp vserver/vfiler api tunneling in concurrent requests
can cause routing request to incorrect servers in race conditions.
This fixes the api and driver for the mentioned situations.

bug 1176759

Change-Id: Id283822e4d1553daed4e6d690ec36f2edfbcf2b4

Sync rpc from oslo.

I just want to have this in sync so that pulling in a feature I'm working
on comes in without unrelated changes

[{'created': '2013-05-15 11:51:05.000000000', 'message': "Implement cloned volume for the RBD driver

This adds the support for cloned volume to the RBD driver. This is perform by the
create option --source-volid. Since the clone is pure copy of a volume,
we don't use the clone capability from RBD and simply copy the source
image.

Change-Id: I3b73bc77b74767ffe3583422f56b3603594589ce
Implements: blueprint implement-cloned-volume-for-rbd
"}]
commit_message:
Implement cloned volume for the RBD driver

This adds the support for cloned volume to the RBD driver. This is perform by the
create option --source-volid. Since the clone is pure copy of a volume,
we don't use the clone capability from RBD and simply copy the source
image.

Change-Id: I3b73bc77b74767ffe3583422f56b3603594589ce
Implements: blueprint implement-cloned-volume-for-rbd

commit_message:
Hide lock_prefix argument using synchronized_with_prefix()

The lockfile module has a new convenience API which sets the lockfile prefix
Using this API, the prefix is not required everytime synchronized is used.

Change-Id: I033fa1d2ed071651609ac2be0a5a16eb3fda6c33

Change-Id: I1d3f9127ddd793a905527660b64ffe8c28f20f1d
'}, {'created': '2013-05-15 07:40:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed do_create() in v2 shell.

Previously when creating a volume v2 shell was able to create
it but then failed to display volume properties. Instead of that
it displayed a non-informative error message. This patch fixes
the problem.

Change-Id: I1d3f9127ddd793a905527660b64ffe8c28f20f1d
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed do_create() in v2 shell.

Previously when creating a volume v2 shell was able to create
it but then failed to display volume properties. Instead of that
it displayed a non-informative error message. This patch fixes
the problem.

Change-Id: I1d3f9127ddd793a905527660b64ffe8c28f20f1d

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-07 23:51:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

max_deletes_per_request in the conf sample doesn't agree with the new default?

max_failed_files in the conf sample should be max_failed_extractions?

yield_frequency should be in the conf sample?

If I make a static large object, then delete one of its segments, then get that slo, it just hangs. Shouldn't it terminate the connection? Not sure if there's a clean way to do that and you gave up on it for now or if it was just an oversight. Maybe raising an exception other than StopIteration would do it?"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-05-07 23:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Oh, just noticed the "manifiest" typo in swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py though that's no biggie. commit_message:
Add a rabbitmq-server element with Heat support.

Allows specifying users to create and feeding back passwords for those
users to wait conditions via cfn-signal.

Change-Id: Ief8993976ce0f48bcf6ebaecc4879a5209170beb

commit_message:
Fix missing pieces filled in by boot-stack.

Boot-stack accidentally installs nova-common along with novnc, which
took care of these things accidentally.

Fixes bug #1180241

Change-Id: Ibe58734ccc0efef6e953a3a3bb67d16707cf2898

commit_message:
Fix for running /etc/rc.local on Fedora

With systemd rc.local lives in /etc/rc.d and is only run
if the rc-local service is enabled.

This change creates a /etc/rc.d/rc.local symlink, and modifies img-functions
prepare_first_boot to tolerate an initially missing /etc/rc.local.

Fixes bug #1179674

Change-Id: I7e6102b62224950c1de5d48205dc4feff60f9389

Trigger SELinux autorelabel on first boot.

This adds about 30 seconds to my local boot time.

Fixes bug #1179730

FixedIp.address, because it is used in a tests later.

blueprint test-db-api

'}]
commit_message:
Add missing tests for db.fixed_ip_*(). functions.

Added new tests for fixed_ip*() functions.
Function fixed_ip_create() should return FixedIp instance rather than
FixedIp.address, because it is used in a tests later.
Fix calls of fixed_ip_create() respectively.

blueprint test-db-api

Change-Id: Id5e9d4486605bde9d9fd1e631d868603a7a7c604

commit_message:
Perform mount check after REST params valid on PUT

All the other methods (POST, GET, HEAD, DELETE and REPLICATE) first
validate the REST parameters and headers before performing the mount
check. Do the same for PUT.

Change-Id: I6e5f34cc65b57662b7f88224ca0e1501787e0f43
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 22:13:17.000000000', 'message': "install redhat-lsb before pre-install.d baseline-tools

baseline-tools expects lsb_release (although tolerates it not being there)

Order needs to be 01-override-yum-arch, 02-lsb, 03-baseline-tools
hence the renames.

Possibly lsb_release isn't cared enough about to do this.

Change-Id: I03abffb1ab2f560e746ba4ffd407605de31f4930
"}]
commit_message:
install redhat-lsb before pre-install.d baseline-tools

baseline-tools expects lsb_release (although tolerates it not being there)

Order needs to be 01-override-yum-arch, 02-lsb, 03-baseline-tools
hence the renames.

Possibly lsb_release isn't cared enough about to do this.

Change-Id: I03abffb1ab2f560e746ba4ffd407605de31f4930

commit_message:
install redhat-lsb-core instead of redhat-lsb

The later pulls in most of a desktop. The former still pulls in a lot
but significantly less, and still provides lsb_release.

Change-Id: Ie27310f01c037b4a10feb5e380e6f5c4ecf21364

'}, {'account_id': 5545, 'date': '2013-05-14 14:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-05-14 15:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2013-05-14 15:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-14 15:56:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not actually convinced of the need for this at all. Almost all of these are just outputs echoing the Properties that went in, and the rest don't actually seem useful in a template.

The purpose of Fn::GetAtt isn't to replace the OpenStack API, it's to provide access to it for things within the template that need it. Can anybody suggest any use case for any of these attributes? The non-existence of any equivalents for the AWS::EC2::Volume resource type suggests that there isn't one."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 17:55:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28672/8/check/gate-heat-pep8/2964 : SUCCESS in 00:02:20

'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2013-05-15 03:34:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm in favor of exposing whatever attributes the API returns for native resource types. Even when there is no obvious use case within a template, an attribute could be exposed in the Outputs section for any number of legitimate (or nefarious) purposes."}, {'account_id': 7135, 'date': '2013-05-15 07:33:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:57:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Steve, to Zane's point, anything that is just a straight copy from the Properties of a resource can just be straight copied to wherever Fn::GetAtt would be used to extract it.

Only things that can conceivably change or are generated outright by cinder should be exposed.

However, I think its conceivable that any of these might change out of band of Heat, or be generated, so +2."}, {'account_id': 6488, 'date': '2013-05-15 21:57:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Approved

commit_message:
Clean up VPC unit tests

 - Ensure that stacks are cleaned up on failure.
 - Add a test for the case where an something other than a valid reference
   is passed as the GroupSet.
 - Add a test for the case where no GroupSet is passed.

Ref bug #1164913

Change-Id: I7637ed7969f23662643756da4a49627a2b40de20

[{'created': '2013-05-14 23:50:17.000000000', 'message': 'Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console

Python logging is configured with a stream handler and should
also replicate the previous logging to 0600 /var/log/heat-provision.log

By logging to a stream handler cloud-init will write to its log,
which will show up in the server console log. This means that heat
provisioning can now be monitored without needing to log in with:

nova console-log <servername>

This change also touches the file /var/lib/heat-cfntools/provision-finished
instead of also writing a datestamp to it, which is redundant.

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d

commit_message:
Use python logging for loguserdata.py, log to console

Python logging is configured with a stream handler and should
also replicate the previous logging to 0600 /var/log/heat-provision.log

By logging to a stream handler cloud-init will write to its log,
which will show up in the server console log. This means that heat
provisioning can now be monitored without needing to log in with:

nova console-log <servername>

This change also touches the file /var/lib/heat-cfntools/provision-finished
instead of also writing a datestamp to it, which is redundant.

Change-Id: Id0312bd2216a83753df601b17ad16d5355cdb11d

[{'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-05-10 17:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-05-10 17:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-05-10 17:40:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2013-05-11 00:20:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Does this work if the two instances with floating IPs are on the same host? I thought that if they can see each other via layer 2 then they won't go through the host's routing and therefore never hit the NAT rules on the way out..."}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2013-05-13 18:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

There is actually a bug in the current implementation when two instances are on the same compute node, but there is no network component on that host (e.g. non-multi-host, standalone compute node). The issue is as described in the "Redirection and Reflection" section of http://www.openbsd.org/faq/pf/rdr.html. The additional iptable rule added by this change effectively completes the implementation of the "RDR-TO and NAT-TO Combination" described at the bottom of that page.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-14 01:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 17:08:02.000000000', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances on the same
private network to communicate with each other using their floating-ips
in a more consistent fashion. The rule checks if a connection is between
a member of a fixed network with another member of the same fixed
network and a DNAT has occurred. This logic is depending on the initial
DNAT'ing to keep traffic on a private network, so any changes to the
former may require alteration to this code as well. Note that this will
only work for interaction between two servers that both have floating
IPs assigned to them.

The patch addresses this issue by ensuring the target server "sees" an
address that must follow the reverse routing as ensuring that the source
address on the returning packets match the expected target host.

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
'}, {'created': '2013-05-10 17:16:54.000000000', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

private network to communicate with each other using their floating-ips
in a more consistent fashion. The rule checks if a connection is between
a member of a fixed network with another member of the same fixed
network and a DNAT has occurred. This logic is depending on the initial
DNAT'ing to keep traffic on a private network, so any changes to the
former may require alteration to this code as well. Note that this will
only work for interaction between two servers that both have floating
IPs assigned to them.

The patch addresses this issue by ensuring the target server "sees" an
address that must follow the reverse routing as ensuring that the source
address on the returning packets match the expected target host.

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136
'}, {'created': '2013-05-10 17:32:09.000000000', 'message': 'Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances that have an
assigned floating IP to communicate with other instances in the same
OpenStack deployment, security group rules permitting. The patch
allows members of the same private network to communicate with each
other using their floating-ips in a more consistent fashion. The rule
also addresses the situation where the target is on another private
network.

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's
floating-IP, the "sees" the correct reply address and the reverse
route follows the same path that an actual external connection would
take. The SNAT ONLY occurs if a DNAT occurred before hand, allowing
communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully
private and internal. The limitation is of course if a DNAT occurs for
other reasons, there may be issues.

Resolves bug 1178745

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136

commit_message:
Reverse path SNAT for DNAT floating-ip.

This patch applies a reverse SNAT rule to allow instances that have an
assigned floating IP to communicate with other instances in the same
OpenStack deployment, security group rules permitting. The patch
allows members of the same private network to communicate with each
other using their floating-ips in a more consistent fashion. The rule
also addresses the situation where the target is on another private
network.

This will only work for interaction between two servers that both have
floating IPs assigned to them.

Specifically, this patch solves the problem where a target server
"sees" the private address of the client. By SNAT'ing to the client's
floating-IP, the "sees" the correct reply address and the reverse
route follows the same path that an actual external connection would
take. The SNAT ONLY occurs if a DNAT occurred before hand, allowing
communication on private networks using private IPs to remain fully
private and internal. The limitation is of course if a DNAT occurs for
other reasons, there may be issues.

Resolves bug 1178745

Change-Id: I55b7131cff5fd5a2ebf826945370d4d550e74136

commit_message:
Fix quantum security group driver to accept none for from/to_port

The quantum security group driver did not accept none values for
from_port/to_port which the nova security group api supports. This
patch allows None values to be passed in for those params and adds a unit test.

In addition the from/to_port responses would be different if using quantum
instead of nova. This patch fixes that and adds unit tests.

Fixes bug 1176027

Change-Id: Id57e253c9dd1787ee25fc5cbb562743692d7abe4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-15 09:21:40.000000000', 'message': "Cells: Don't allow active -> build

Adds support for passing 'expected_vm_state' in an instance_update dict
much like the current support for 'expected_task_state'.

For cells, when the API cell receives an instance update containing a
vm_state of BUILDING, raise an exception if the instance is in some
other state.  This addresses out-of-order messaging issues that can
cause an instance to appear to have a huge delay going ACTIVE.  (A
periodic task run can later heal the state, but it can take a long
while)

Fixes bug 1180283

Change-Id: I64252b30e2596812f3b84da64b1fc8681661d7f8
"}]
commit_message:
Cells: Don't allow active -> build

Adds support for passing 'expected_vm_state' in an instance_update dict
much like the current support for 'expected_task_state'.

For cells, when the API cell receives an instance update containing a
vm_state of BUILDING, raise an exception if the instance is in some
other state.  This addresses out-of-order messaging issues that can
cause an instance to appear to have a huge delay going ACTIVE.  (A
periodic task run can later heal the state, but it can take a long
while)

Fixes bug 1180283

Change-Id: I64252b30e2596812f3b84da64b1fc8681661d7f8

commit_message:
Allow the HTTPClient consumer to pass endpoint_type.

The default endpoint_type is None.  With this default, the
ServiceCatalog class -- called by HTTPClient -- chooses adminURL.
This change allows the consumer to pass publicURL, internalURL or some
other endpoint type to override this default behavior.

Fixes: Bug #1176197
Change-Id: I974f0e19caf4fa4fc28ced11e819e803458bd482

commit_message:
make test non executable, otherwise nose skips it

when reading tempest run logs the following can currently be seen:

: INFO: Ignoring files matching ['^\\.', '^_', '^setup\\.py$']
nose.selector: INFO: .../test_endpoints.py is executable; skipped

chmod the files so they get run.

Change-Id: I5e3edb07eec7390877e9ac18b14974730e19088f

commit_message:
Move WaitCondition polling to check_create_complete()

Rather than poll in a loop inside handle_create(), use
check_create_complete() to check the status of the WaitCondition.

Change-Id: I63dc6ec6aeedf3238123334722f86a0f1205f306

From a quick look at this, it appears to be a non backwards copmatible API change.  Am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-04-29 21:31:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Well, take a close look at the changes made to the API outputs; I would say that, at least in the XML case, there is clearly a bug, and this is a reasonable way of resolving that problem.  That said, it probably wouldn't be that difficult to alter the API changes to continue to include the data, and just add an appropriate fix to the XML template to correct that issueâ€¦"}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-04-30 11:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I wouldn't say there is any Nova API change here: the magor change is in nova.volume.cinder.API class which is nothing more than refactoring. As for changed templates - this is what Cinder actually retuns on create snapshot request: http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-block-storage/2.0/content/Create_Snapshot.html (see volume_id is a string, not a dict)

So I think it was a small bug in tests - https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/api/openstack/fakes.py#L604 - here you can see that stub_snapshot_create accepts volume_id while cinder.API.create_snapshot accepted volume object before my change. Thus it creates stub snapshot and assigns volume dict to the "volume_id" attribute. I think this bug forced to use "wrong" templates.'}, {'account_id': 5948, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-30 14:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Refactor nova.volume.cinder.API to reduce roundtrips with Cinder

Make cinder.API methods accept volume_id instead of the whole volume object.
This will remove redundant roundtrip to get the volume before
passing it to other methods as in fact they only need the id.

Fixes bug 1172297

Change-Id: I5e7f944c1c29b2f211ece2ef86c0959c81e806df

[{'created': '2013-05-08 15:30:16.000000000', 'message': "Extract get AZ of instance code into common module.

Since get an instance's availability zone logic may used for many modules,
so move it from extend API into helper module `nova.availability_zones`.
And add some tests for the new method.

When testing, memorycache.get_client() got no servers, it will default use a
fake client. So no need to stub it.

part of bp: different-availability-zone-filter

commit_message:
Extract getting instance's AZ into a helper module.

An instance's availability zone logic may used by many modules,
so move it from extend API into helper module `nova.availability_zones`.
Also add some tests for the new method.

part of bp: different-availability-zone-filter

Change-Id: I5916a0b09d5dddec338e8e36503953720dfd6bcd

[{'created': '2013-05-15 01:33:54.000000000', 'message': "Booting a test image doesn't work from documentation

THe documentation registers an image with glance with the name
cirros-0.3-x86_64, but the nova boot command attempts to boot
cirros-0.3.0-x86_64.  This results in nova being unable to find
the image in glance with an error such as:

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ nova boot --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64 --flavor m1.small --key_name test my-first-server
ERROR: No image with a name or ID of 'cirros-0.3.0-x86_64' exists.

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ glance image-show cirros-0.3-x86_64
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| Property         | Value                                |
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| checksum         | 50bdc35edb03a38d91b1b071afb20a3c     |
| container_format | bare                                 |
| created_at       | 2013-05-15T01:01:54                  |
| deleted          | False                                |
| disk_format      | qcow2                                |
| id               | 4a190ba0-0767-4152-81ce-a6fb4fc52590 |
| is_public        | True                                 |
| min_disk         | 0                                    |
| min_ram          | 0                                    |
| name             | cirros-0.3-x86_64                    |
| owner            | 6d3ba9f84d294238a0f56f4989fbf595     |
| protected        | False                                |
| size             | 9761280                              |
| status           | active                               |
| updated_at       | 2013-05-15T01:01:54                  |
+------------------+--------------------------------------+

This patch documents registering wtih the full x.y.z
version cirros-0.3.0.

Change-Id: I2070d6425d03a99ce11046188d980a30fdf3cde6
"}]
commit_message:
Booting a test image doesn't work from documentation

THe documentation registers an image with glance with the name
cirros-0.3-x86_64, but the nova boot command attempts to boot
cirros-0.3.0-x86_64.  This results in nova being unable to find
the image in glance with an error such as:

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ nova boot --image cirros-0.3.0-x86_64 --flavor m1.small --key_name test my-first-server
ERROR: No image with a name or ID of 'cirros-0.3.0-x86_64' exists.

[user@machine ~(keystone_admin)]$ glance image-show cirros-0.3-x86_64
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| Property         | Value                                |
+------------------+--------------------------------------+
| checksum         | 50bdc35edb03a38d91b1b071afb20a3c     |
| container_format | bare                                 |
| created_at       | 2013-05-15T01:01:54                  |
| deleted          | False                                |
| disk_format      | qcow2                                |
| id               | 4a190ba0-0767-4152-81ce-a6fb4fc52590 |
| is_public        | True                                 |
| min_disk         | 0                                    |
| min_ram          | 0                                    |
| name             | cirros-0.3-x86_64                    |
| owner            | 6d3ba9f84d294238a0f56f4989fbf595     |
| protected        | False                                |
| size             | 9761280                              |

commit_message:
Fix local_settings.py on distributions

On RHEL, Fedora, Scientific Linux, CentOS, etc., the file
/etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings.py (from Ubuntu)
is named /etc/openstack-dashboard/local_settings

Fixes bug 1179837

Change-Id: Ia91e6954e9589506823d9b5f8c44877b1d0d488f

commit_message:
Adds GlusterFS Driver

This patch adds a manifest that configures Cinder to use GlusterFS
as a volume driver.

Change-Id: Ifb874a5c792ac416ec6567bbd70ab291820a04d0

The destination check in live migration will fetch the image
information from glance and it will throw ImageNotFound if
the instance is booted from volume since there is no image id

'}]
commit_message:
Pass None to image if booted from volume in live migration

The destination check in live migration will fetch the image
information from glance and it will throw ImageNotFound if
the instance is booted from volume since there is no image id
on the instance

Fix bug 1170596

Conflicts:

	nova/scheduler/driver.py

Change-Id: Ie683a3ca5d6430c52ead77b41f98fbcb4114ea1e

I have a quick question about using snapshot_attached_here() (see comment).

Also, it looks like there is a race condition with this check. Since the VM isn't shutdown, the resize may still fail later on since there may be more data on the disk when the resize actually happens compared to when the snapshot is taken.

It doesn't appear that this race condition is taken into consideration at all."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-03-26 19:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-03-26 19:42:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Holding off on approving until Johannes's question and observations can be addressedâ€¦"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-03-26 21:10:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

I think the race condition is a non-issue, because this is just an upfront test to reduce VM downtime in the case of the user request a size that is too small for their instance. If the disk usage crosses the threshold by the time the resize happens, the existing error handling kicks in, leaving it no worse than it is already, in that edge case. I want to avoid shutting down the users server before checking (in case it is a 'pet' server rather than those cattle ones), and doing a second upfront check after shutting down seems like overkill, given the resize down filesystem call fails with a useful error message.

Not sure about the snapshot_attached_here call, its not the same use case, but maybe I should worry about vhd chain state after the snapshot is deleted, i will take a closer look in the morning. I really just want to call clone, but without shutting down."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-03-27 09:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Not approving because it sounds like you might tweak this further in the morning.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-03-27 12:01:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

I think we can wait to worry about coalesce on failure until the next patch in this series I am drafting, where I look at adding some rollback into the resize operation, and make use of the new instance actions API to avoid the error state where possible:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25127/'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-02 13:50:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-02 13:50:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-02 18:43:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The more I think about this patch the less I'm a fan of it.

Ultimately the big problem is that too much data on the disk leaves the instance in an error state, which can't be recovered from easily. However, this patch doesn't address that failure.

I'm worried that this patch is likely to cause false negatives since it snapshots a live running system and then expects e2fsck to be able to repair any possible inconsistencies in the filesystem.

The only advantage seems to be to fail faster, which I'm generally a fan of, but in this case I'm not convinced that adding a second code path which generates the same failure is worth the extra code and the possible false negative failures."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-03 08:57:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

So, this leaves the instance in an error state, but leaves the instance running. I have a change coming that uses instance actions to avoid the error state for these two up front checks.

But you do make a good point about false positives. A reboot should allow a user to get past the false positive, and it seems to generally underestimate report than overestimate. However, I am don't really now how often that will occur. At a minium I should ignore the check if it can't fix filesystem errors found or if the minimum file system call errors, and fallback to the old behaviour.

If I relax the requirement to keep the users instance up, I could look at doing a full blown rollback for this particular case. Restore original VM name and start the VM back up, then use instance actions to report the failure. But that is more long winded, adds more complexity to the code, and worst gives more downtime for the user.

What do you think is best?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2013-04-03 15:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

We already have a revert for migrations. I think we should lean on that.

I'm fine with downtime for users. They already decided to accept downtime when they chose to resize the instance.

It's a small shame there's downtime if the resize can't possibly succeed, but maybe the user should check they don't have too much data before they start a resize then?

If we can solve the revert from error, then I think that will solve the biggest problem, the one the user can't do anything about when it happens."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-04-05 15:35:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-05 15:38:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Doesn't seem to work

VM is still running, but will be left in the Error state.

to the Error state, this will be a future change.

given their current disk usage, the operation fails gracefully.

Fix for bug 1155066

This change adds some rollback into the resize disk down
code within xenapi, and reports a better error message
when the disk is too big to resize down.

On a successful rollback, the user is notified of the error
by the instance actions, rather than leaving
the server in the error state.

The user is then free up enough space to allow the resize to
happen correctly.

Change-Id: Ibad568ab3cfb9caaf4fe002572c8cda973d501a7

commit_message:
xenapi: ensure vdi is not too big when resizing down

Fix for bug 1155066

This change adds some rollback into the resize disk down
code within xenapi, and reports a better error message
when the disk is too big to resize down.

On a successful rollback, the user is notified of the error
by the instance actions, rather than leaving
the server in the error state.

The user is then able to free up some disk space such that
the resize can work correctly.

Change-Id: Ibad568ab3cfb9caaf4fe002572c8cda973d501a7

In some cases 'Start-Program' hung due to stdout buffer overflow.
Fixed by invoking ReadToEnd method every second while process is running.

commit_message:
'Start-Program' function fix.

In some cases 'Start-Program' hung due to stdout buffer overflow.
Fixed by invoking ReadToEnd method every second while process is running.

Also a few improvements were made.

Change-Id: I025fc842d4c42acac5ae8038bd6a0602652ad777

commit_message:
Handle IPMI transient failures better.

Sometimes, IPMI "power status" doesn't return either "on" or "off".
When this happens, the IPMI driver shouldn't assume what the state is,
and the baremetal driver shouldn't assume that NOSTATE means SHUTDOWN.

This patch also improves the doc strings for the IPMI driver.

Fix bug 1178378.

Change-Id: I54a5e6309f68ab8e5601e65039366d7d87c03478

[{'created': '2013-05-03 22:49:31.000000000', 'message': "Redirects requests from /v# to /v#/ with correct Location header

This is a continuous fix to bug #1166957

VersionNegotiationFilter pops off the version string of PATH_INFO,
the popped segment is pushed onto SCRIPT_NAME, which results in
dual version strings (e.g. '/v1/v1/') in the 'Location' header
of a redirect response. This may result in a further 404 error
if the http client will automatically follow the returned
redirect.

Fix this problem by adding a private method which does not
push the popped segment onto SCRIPT_NAME.

Change-Id: Ie0c244af38534dde2058828fbff840a845cc7c90
Fixes: bug #1175815
"}, {'created': '2013-05-08 21:16:52.000000000', 'message': "Redirects requests from /v# to /v#/ with correct Location header

of a redirect response. This may result in a further 404 error
if the http client will automatically follow the returned
redirect.

Fix this problem by adding a private method which does not

commit_message:
Redirects requests from /v# to /v#/ with correct Location header

This is a continuous fix to bug #1166957

VersionNegotiationFilter pops off the version string of PATH_INFO,
the popped segment is pushed onto SCRIPT_NAME, which results in
dual version strings (e.g. '/v1/v1/') in the 'Location' header
of a redirect response. This may result in a further 404 error
if the http client will automatically follow the returned
redirect.

Fix this problem by adding a private method which does not
push the popped segment onto SCRIPT_NAME.

Change-Id: Ie0c244af38534dde2058828fbff840a845cc7c90
Fixes: bug #1175815

commit_message:
Document keystone_authtoken section

It's necessary to document how to configure the keystone_authtoken
section in the ceilometer.conf file so clients can authenticate
against the API server.

Fixes bug: 1177765

Change-Id: I93b45a7e65546246bbf1af795be5887e9a80c1fa

messages:

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/1/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/2260 : SUCCESS in 00:01:00
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28299/1/check/gate-ceilometer-docs/1067/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:03:19

'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-05-10 05:54:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-05-10 06:01:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

Does this means we want to remove the CM listeners and have other openstack services directly publish their data into ceilometer DB? 

Does cross project RPC call means nova need to know CM's message bus configuration(i.e. ip/addr/topic/exchange, etc.)?"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-05-10 12:35:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

For now, we're not going to remove anything. Cross project RPC isn't possible (yet), so this could be see as a way to publish metris to other systems directly without passing via the collector. Maybe in the future we could remove the notification-listening code that reemits meters from the notifier, but we'll see. :)"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-05-10 12:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 12:40:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/2310 : SUCCESS in 00:00:56
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28299/2/check/gate-ceilometer-docs/1117/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 00:03:30
- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/2243 : SUCCESS in 00:04:08
- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/2245 : SUCCESS in 00:02:45
'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-05-10 12:44:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-13 20:28:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure how I feel about this change. It turns one outgoing notification into N outgoing ceilometer messages at the nova end of the message bus. It seems like it would be more efficient to change the collector to convert the single notification into sample data and then store it directly, instead of making another rpc call to send the sample data back to the collector."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2013-05-14 09:17:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Doug: you're thinking too small. :-)
Think about the case "I want to publish Nova counters to a UDP listener".

Currently you have to do:
nova -> notification on RPC -> ceilometer-collector -> pipeline -> UDP

With such a notifier, you can do:
nova -> pipeline -> UDP

And avoids loading your AMQP bus uselessly.

Then, we can even change our workflow from:

nova -> notification on RPC -> ceilometer-collector -> pipeline -> record_meter on RPC -> ceilometer-collector stores in database

To:
nova -> pipeline -> record_meter on RPC -> ceilometer-collector stores in database


Which is exactly what you describe, but this notifier would cover much more case. It's not possible yet to do the latter change, because we can do RPC call cross-project (remind the recent thread), but some day, that could be handy.

And that still doesn't disallow you to use the standard RPC mechanism if you want to. :)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:10:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

OK, I'm convinced."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:10:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-15 14:14:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/28299/2/gate/gate-ceilometer-docs/1184/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 29s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/gate/gate-ceilometer-pep8/2377 : SUCCESS in 3m 36s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/gate/gate-ceilometer-python26/2311 : SUCCESS in 3m 41s
- http://logs.openstack.org/28299/2/gate/gate-ceilometer-python27/2312 : SUCCESS in 3m 05s
'}]

the collector, avoiding an entire round-trip of the data in their
notification form.

Currently, our only pulisher (ceilometer.publisher.meter) relies on
openstack.common.rpc which doesn't allow cross project RPC calls, so
it's no possible to use this publisher for now. But I'm confident this
limitation will be bypassed soon as we redesign the RPC API.

We will also add other methods to publish soon (HTTP, UDPâ€¦) that will be

Blueprint: oslo-multi-publisher

Change-Id: Ie639b2fdd3dce24680285ce91f1a024fcfb3b5d0
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
"}, {'created': '2013-05-10 12:36:00.000000000', 'message': "Add a direct Ceilometer notifier

the collector, avoiding an entire round-trip of the data in their

commit_message:
Add a direct Ceilometer notifier

This adds a notifier driver for Oslo that will send directly samples to
the collector, avoiding an entire round-trip of the data in their
notification form.

Currently, our only pulisher (ceilometer.publisher.meter) relies on
openstack.common.rpc which doesn't allow cross project RPC calls, so
it's no possible to use this publisher for now. But I'm confident this
limitation will be bypassed soon as we redesign the RPC API.

We will also add other methods to publish soon (HTTP, UDPâ€¦) that will be
usable with this notifier driver.

Blueprint: oslo-multi-publisher

Change-Id: Ie639b2fdd3dce24680285ce91f1a024fcfb3b5d0
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Fix NetworkInterface when GroupSet not specified

If the (optional) GroupSet property is not specified in the template, then
self.properties.get('GroupSet') will return None, which is not iterable.

Ref bug #1164913

Change-Id: I3021fc1c783c356a528c0dcf914601ff32c4c4fa

[{'created': '2013-05-14 20:55:04.000000000', 'message': 'Pass the proper admin context to update_dhcp

Bug 1180111

Commit 14e2ed3ace769c4deaca3c48a2fa59863f637a5f introduced changes

commit_message:
Pass the proper admin context to update_dhcp

Bug 1180111

Commit 14e2ed3ace769c4deaca3c48a2fa59863f637a5f introduced changes
to contexts passed around during resize. One of the calls to
update_dhcp was missed and was causing stack traces on
resize-revert.

Change-Id: Ib7bec51324c7bced009407af13a7fff7a724e020

commit_message:
Fix config setting references in API tests

These tests are being skipped in the CI system because
we aren't installing Ming. I'm working on a separate
patch to restore Ming to the dependency list for tests,
and while preparing for that I found that these tests
break when Ming is installed.

Change-Id: I4604bbde0c92109b4e2a88f1492793d75c5c0e4d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

Some cleanups include:
 - Add flavor sub-commands into README.rst
 - is_int() and is_float() to check integer and float respectively
 - Remove check_uuid_like() because it isn't used
 - Remove parameter cs in some _print_XXX functions because cs is
   not used

Change-Id: If47ce557d33db05f53e382f0670f436e05a340b7
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
"}, {'created': '2013-05-15 07:56:17.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup some flavor commands

Some cleanups include:
 - Add flavor sub-commands into README.rst
 - Check flavor ID when creating a flavor
 - Remove check_uuid_like() because it isn't used
 - Remove parameter cs in some _print_XXX functions because cs is
   not used

Change-Id: If47ce557d33db05f53e382f0670f436e05a340b7

commit_message:
Cleanup some flavor commands

Some cleanups include:
 - Add flavor sub-commands into README.rst
 - Check flavor ID when creating a flavor
 - Remove check_uuid_like() because it isn't used
 - Remove parameter cs in some _print_XXX functions because cs is
   not used

Change-Id: If47ce557d33db05f53e382f0670f436e05a340b7
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Do not run heat/tools/nova_create_flavors.sh

This script takes a long time to run which will affect tempest
run times. Instead of running this, example templates will be modified
to align with the default heat flavors.

Change-Id: I588b1da9f5a02de3bf64ac8011d75c7d5432ef26

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but whitespace content has changed.'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2013-05-08 20:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 21:18:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28606/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/15106 : SUCCESS in 00:44:20
- http://logs.openstack.org/28606/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/14821 : FAILURE in 00:45:51 (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28606/3/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/21355 : SUCCESS in 00:20:57
- http://logs.openstack.org/28606/3/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/2853 : SUCCESS in 00:26:41 (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 7350, 'date': '2013-05-08 21:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Without this change, such a scenario could happen :

1) A first run of stash.sh runs with success, all services are up and running, /var/log/apache2/horizon_error.log gets created, the tail -f /var/log/apache2/horizon_error.log runs fine

2) The user decides to stop devstack. (unstack.sh). Without this commit /var/log/apache2/horizon_error.log still exists

3) The user installs another webserver on its computer (such as nginx) or makes something that would prevent apache2 from starting again

4) The user wants to rerun devstack. Apache2 will fail to start because of 3) but since horizon_error.log is still here the file $SERVICE_DIR/$SCREEN_NAME/horizon.failure will not be touched. In the end, stack.sh output will be "everything is fine" which is not the case.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-09 15:15:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Clean up horizon apache logs on unstack

It feels like the right think to do. Moreover it will avoid to display
horizon errors from a previous devstack run that would be displayed because
of the tail -f in start_horizon()

Change-Id: Id1ab272e60e0733a4feef3b85029f438f2273cb0

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-09 14:13:06.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: Ubuntu installation repository/proxy fix

Get rid of UBUNTU_INST_REPOSITORY, use UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_HOSTNAME and
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_DIRECTORY instead. User can also specify
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_PROXY to utilize a proxy for the OpenStack VM
installation. The answer file will be edited to contain the specified
values. Also get rid of the magic, undocumented MIRROR variable.

This is related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: Ic9fc564c4ad0f43e2e536854335ebe14791d0255
'}, {'created': '2013-05-14 10:41:29.000000000', 'message': 'xenapi: Ubuntu installation repository/proxy fix

Get rid of UBUNTU_INST_REPOSITORY, use UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_HOSTNAME and
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_DIRECTORY instead. User can also specify
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_PROXY to utilize a proxy for the OpenStack VM
installation. The answer file will be edited to contain the specified
values. Also get rid of the magic, undocumented MIRROR variable.

This is related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: Ic9fc564c4ad0f43e2e536854335ebe14791d0255
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Ubuntu installation repository/proxy fix

Get rid of UBUNTU_INST_REPOSITORY, use UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_HOSTNAME and
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_DIRECTORY instead. User can also specify
UBUNTU_INST_HTTP_PROXY to utilize a proxy for the OpenStack VM
installation. The answer file will be edited to contain the specified
values. Also get rid of the magic, undocumented MIRROR variable.

This is related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: Ic9fc564c4ad0f43e2e536854335ebe14791d0255

commit_message:
Add missing unique constraint to KeyPair model.

Added a missing unique constraint ("name", "user_id") to KeyPair model
(this constraint was in db schema but not in model definition).

blueprint db-enforce-unique-keys

Change-Id: Id231bca256e0cb39fcd8068acc7039240326fde2

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 13:17:15.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize db.instance_floating_address_get_all method

Optimize db.instance_floating_address_get_all
Was:
Get FixedIps with corresponding instance_uuid
For each FixedIp get associated FloatIp (N request)
Now:
Get only list of FixedIps ids
Get all corresponding FloatingIp with one query (select in)
Get only addresses from FloatingIps (because we are using only it)

Add temporary test for db.instance_floating_address_get_all to
ensure that it works as expected.

Change-Id: Id3c515de0ca35707bbfe46b991c2d7cf591e431b
'}]
commit_message:
Optimize db.instance_floating_address_get_all method

Optimize db.instance_floating_address_get_all
Was:
Get FixedIps with corresponding instance_uuid
For each FixedIp get associated FloatIp (N request)
Now:
Get only list of FixedIps ids
Get all corresponding FloatingIp with one query (select in)
Get only addresses from FloatingIps (because we are using only it)

Add temporary test for db.instance_floating_address_get_all to
ensure that it works as expected.

Change-Id: Id3c515de0ca35707bbfe46b991c2d7cf591e431b

commit_message:
Use Oslo's `bool_from_string`

Oslo provides an equivalent implmentation of `bool_from_str` so we
should switch the code to use that instead.

Change-Id: I382f23af2468e276ae4342dff18cf06e1c24b755

commit_message:
Remove "#!/usr/bin/env python" from .py files under nova/cmd

Fix bug 1178543

Now in Havana, all nova service script start up logic are moved to
nova/cmd and those files are not simply python script but python
files, so there is no need to still keep "#!/usr/bin/env python"
for those files since they won't be run directly as scripts.

Change-Id: Ic102215dc0200ec1f6b47951bef31d58b08022ef

commit_message:
Remove setuptools-git as run time dependency

Remove setuptools-git as a run time dependency since
it is only used to generate a tarball.

Change-Id: I713edd2b3f4af094a481277b43fbb0753eb18da5
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Rework to_primitive functionality.

1. Simplify the main to_primitive loop by using
   individual helper functions to help in serializing certain
   values and use these helper functions in the main serialization
   loop
2. Keep track of the items that were already converted
   so that we can raise an exception when an object is
   being operated on that is cyclic and raise an exception
   if this occurs
3. Raise an exception when we hit the maximum recursion depth instead
   of returning '?', this will help in determining which cases actually
   cause this problem, allowing the users of this library to fix there
   calls instead of having the library arbitrarily return '?'
4. Don't allow max_depth to be < 0

Change-Id: I30c608186442a7ceee605d59e56d1b22c4b72af7

I know that devstack wouldn't work with selinux on at the moment, but we can add TODO's to enable this use case, which may come handy in the future."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-03 10:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-03 20:26:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Do not merge

A while back some folks did a good bit of work to make DevStack usable with selinux on Fedora.  Has that bitrotted and doesn't work any more?

I'm not against disabling it but if it is just a matter of fixing one specific thing I'd rather fix it than throw away the previous work.

Of course, if we fix it we'll need someone to champion keeping it working.  It isn't something we test regularly.  Obviously.  So did I just talk myself into a corner?"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-04 03:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> A while back some folks did a good bit of work to make DevStack usable with selinux on Fedora. Has that bitrotted and doesn't work any more?

i guess so, unless I'm missing something

> I'm not against disabling it but if it is just a matter of fixing one specific thing I'd rather fix it than throw away the previous work.

There's at least two issues [1].  I'm not going to argue it wouldn't be better to have selinux working, but it's blocking some people using "vanilla" [2] devstack right now, which i think is more valuable than full selinux compatibility.  I see selinux as more of a deployment issue 

> Of course, if we fix it we'll need someone to champion keeping it working. It isn't something we test regularly. Obviously. So did I just talk myself into a corner?

As I've mentioned before Red Hat have some devstack CI jobs running.  In the future, I could see us turning it on there and getting that sort of continuous testing.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1175444
[2] by that, I mean "it just works" rather than "check it out, but make sure you do a,b,c before you start, etc"'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-05-09 19:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I would prefer that if you must turn of enforcing to do it only on RHEL6.  I ran a default install on F18 yesterday with enforcing enabled and it ran as expected.

Go ahead and use bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/devstack/+bug/1175444 to track the RHEL6 work.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:05:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Disable selinux for RHEL6

selinux locks down httpd which causes various issues for Horizon
working from git checkouts.  Dealing with selinux is more a deployment
than a development issue, so we just disable it for devstack.

Change-Id: I1e61f34e812360dafacd3b3288e66bc9cc5f1648
Fixes: 1175444

Thanks for this, it is a great start.

I would like the properties schema to map exactly to the underlying cinder api, so SnapshotId instead of snapshot_id etc.

To me the point of native resource types is to demonstrate that heat resources are just very thin wrappers over openstack APIs

This might mean that it is better for Volume to subclass CinderVolume, or for there to be two separate classes which share code only through static utility functions'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2013-05-09 08:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2013-05-09 08:40:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Steve, what is our policy on what the property names should match up to? It could be:

1) The JSON input to the OpenStack API
2) The CLI input to the python-*client
3) The internal name used for API calls to python-*client

commit_message:
Implement OS::Cinder::Volume

It creates a new resource type allowing to pass cinder specific
arguments in the template.

Change-Id: I1e8512892fdc7f141f91580bfca4e370b0740a56

commit_message:
Cleans up the l3 agent manifest

This patch makes the following changes to the l3 agent manifest:

  * Adds a doc header
  * Removes the auth parameters
  * Removes the metadata IP parameter as its no longer used
  * Sets router and gateway IDs to undef values
  * Adds some tests

Change-Id: Ia36141fdb9433c629c7945cc1774b549bdff4c69

commit_message:
Fix up hacking ignores a bit.

Add more explicit ignores to tox.ini hacking ignores until
we have a chance to fix up the imports and docstring errors
we've been ignoring.  This should give us everything we had
in the past (ie alphabetical import checks).

Also, update run_tests.sh to call flake8 and not the hacking.py
that is no longer there.

Change-Id: I6c82e958002255fd9f527b06bf0a68d148cc681e
