As EC2 api can be disabled by removing it from enabled_apis
in nova::api, this patch adds the ability to not configure
the EC2 service and endpoint in keystone.

Change-Id: I97790cc44418a00696cf294158ce47511fdc1918
'}]
commit_message:
Add ability to not configure EC2 endpoint

As EC2 api can be disabled by removing it from enabled_apis
in nova::api, this patch adds the ability to not configure
the EC2 service and endpoint in keystone.

Change-Id: I97790cc44418a00696cf294158ce47511fdc1918

commit_message:
Add 't', 'y', and `strict` to `bool_from_string`

't' and 'y' are commonly used for booleans as well, and since it's used in
Nova already, probably makes sense to add common support for it.

`strict` allows callers to detect anonmolous values so they can be handled
separately. This is particularly useful when parsing input from API calls
where bad values might result in 4XX errors instead of being treated as False.

Change-Id: I6218a1895f72cfbfd81776602e63ca3d093475e0

commit_message:
Split nova into nova-compute and nova-api.

This still puts baremetal specific things into nova-compute, but those
things can be split out later.

Change-Id: If7bb06cbfe0b60d514e089a721069316794327a7

commit_message:
Avoid race condition with 1 second sleep.

Upstart will return from 'start xxx' immediately upon forking. We still
need to run start-stop-daemon, change users, exec again, and then run
the python code to get to listen() before the service is actually ready.
This all should take < 1s, but the sleep is just a stopgap until we have
a better way to track "is the service ready" in upstart.

Fixes bug #1179766

Change-Id: I3842e572c940e833cb3036b67df0ee71fe5bb129

commit_message:
Cleanups for create-flavor

Instead of setting defaults values to None in the signature and then setting
the *real* default in the function body, it's more concise/readable to set the
value in the signature itself (when dealing with immutable types).

Along with this, the handling of `memory_mb` and `vcpus` was detangled so the
attributes were handled in one place and not across both the non-negative and
positive int checks.

Change-Id: I1c06768c2fd076adc8c0a647a492dabb67b7bf79

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-14 03:40:58.000000000', 'message': 'Fix a bug in print_list and sort flavor to print

Because sort_index = 0 by default, "if sort_index is not None" doesn't make any sense.
Here sort_index should be None by default, which means "donot want to sort".
And sort flavor by VCPU, mem and root disk as Horizon view does, which makes command view clear.

Change-Id: I823ab75eb7a92bdc426dd96a3d1e56f187118729
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-14 05:25:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the default parameter in print_list

Because sort_index = 0 by default, "if sort_index is not None" doesn't
make any sense.
Here sort_index should be None by default, which means "donot want to
sort".

Change-Id: I823ab75eb7a92bdc426dd96a3d1e56f187118729
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the default parameter in print_list

Because sort_index = 0 by default, "if sort_index is not None" doesn't
make any sense.
Here sort_index should be None by default, which means "donot want to
sort".

Change-Id: I823ab75eb7a92bdc426dd96a3d1e56f187118729
Signed-off-by: Shane Wang <shane.wang@intel.com>

[{'created': '2013-05-14 00:26:43.000000000', 'message': 'Cleanup create flavor tests

In preparation for some refactoring and additional features to the create
flavor method, this patch cleanups the existing tests by:

* Moving flavor create tests out to their own class

* Adding more coverage around boundary conditions

* Making tests more orthogonal (not testing that `root_gb` was set correctly in
  multiple tests, for example)

Change-Id: I82acadc19d2713406c3be01a104ccd64377098ed
'}]
commit_message:
Cleanup create flavor tests

In preparation for some refactoring and additional features to the create
flavor method, this patch cleanups the existing tests by:

* Moving flavor create tests out to their own class

* Adding more coverage around boundary conditions

* Making tests more orthogonal (not testing that `root_gb` was set correctly in
  multiple tests, for example)

Change-Id: I82acadc19d2713406c3be01a104ccd64377098ed

commit_message:
Fix response from snapshot create stub

A change from Oleg highlighted that the current snapshot create
stub is broken because it passes a full volume for the volume_id
paramter.

Fix the stub and the api_samples output, but also add unit test
checks which would have caught this.

Change-Id: Id006e3995c7696aa8f061a2b96123ea27e4b6d3f
Co-authored-by: Oleg Bondarev <obondarev@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Move iscsi helpers to brick directory.

This patch moves the iscsi helpers to the brick
directory.  We're doing this to enable the ability
to have a module/library of core block storage
functionality to use in other OpenStack projects.

After this the next step is to separate out the LVM
and iSCSI code in drivers/lvm.py and then to actually
have the Cinder LVM driver use the new brick LVM module.

Change-Id: I4f8f8b54e801ab63994b5953956c041d8db91fad

commit_message:
Change Heat instance_user to heat-admin.

Default is 'ec2-user', which is more than a little inappropriate.

Change-Id: I1ea29d1436a74cf365e7a7d70c7f5f9735baf5ca

[{'created': '2013-04-23 16:15:46.000000000', 'message': "Implement Registry's Client V2

The patch implements Registry's v2 Client.

Some notes:
* The implementation uses __getattr__ to map method's calls to remote
  RPC methods.
* The client supports both bulk and single calls.
* Client is based on the base HTTPClient

About Exceptions:
* If raise_exc == True, the client will try to re-raise the remote
  exception. If the server raised an unknown exception, it will be
  re-raised as RPCException in the client side.

Implements blueprint registry-api-v2

Change-Id: I98757c2272c68301373c1a3af96c4d06cb63cc97

commit_message:
Implement Registry's Client V2

The patch implements Registry's v2 Client.

Some notes:
* The implementation uses __getattr__ to map method's calls to remote
  RPC methods.
* The client supports both bulk and single calls.
* Client is based on the base HTTPClient

About Exceptions:
* If raise_exc == True, the client will try to re-raise the remote
  exception. If the server raised an unknown exception, it will be
  re-raised as RPCException in the client side.

Implements blueprint registry-api-v2

Change-Id: I98757c2272c68301373c1a3af96c4d06cb63cc97

This looks good but I'm not sure if api is the best location for this? 

Ryan has a patch coming up that includes the nova-side of quantum metadata as well as the other relevant nova.conf quantum stuff all packaged together. Once his puppet-quantum patch goes through, it should be uploaded."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-03 16:23:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I have made the changes here because only nova::api need this but perhaps nova::network::quantum can be a better place.

It is difficult to imagine all quantum use cases :)

fyi: remember that some quantum stuff already exists in nova: nova::compute::quantum and nova::network::quantum

I will wait and review the Ryan patch, I'm sure I will cover my use case :)

Thx"}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-03 16:24:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I completely agree.

Sure, let's compare solutions and see which is the better one to pursue."}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-03 16:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

one comment / clarification request.'}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-07 08:52:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-07 14:22:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Why are you choosing the api manifest to add these options? I'm curious about when these options would be used but the options contained in nova::network::quantum would not be used?"}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2013-05-07 14:40:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Because this option is only needed by nova-api, but now I think nova::network::quantum is a better place to handle this, it is more intuitive. If you agree I will update the change to move this stuff in nova::network::quantum.'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-07 14:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think you are right that it should go in nova-api. This way, a shared secret is not accidentally added to nova.conf files that aren't running nova-api and therefore the risk of spreading a shared secret is kept low.

But can you remove the if conditional and just add it to the other nova_config options? "if" will only work if the value is always undef. Once it is set to a non-empty value, changing it back to "undef" won't actually remove the line.

We're working on modifying the inifile providers so "undef" will correctly purge the line from the config file.'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-09 05:40:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I want to clarify that last statement.

I do not think it is reasonable for undef to indicate that something needs to be merged. In the Puppet resource model, that is indicated by ensure => absent. I think the best way to support this is with purging.'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-09 05:43:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

sorry, to finish that point, it could be possible to use undef for this, but it woudl look like:

if $foo {
  nova_config { 'some_var': value => $foo }
} else {
  nova_config { 'some_var': ensure => absent }
}"}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-09 05:44:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

just to clarify, b/c the comments reach a few different conclusions. Do folks want to merge this or move it to nova::network::quantum ?'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 14:00:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Re this patch: I'd like this to go in nova-api and not nova::network::quantum for reasons in the last comment I made.

Re undef and purging: this is probably a larger debatable topic. I think there needs to be a way to purge an existing line without the need for ensure => absent. If this is not a good solution, we need to restructure all manifests. Global / manifest-level purging is a bit too destructive, IMO. Sometimes package-level defaults are satisfactory.

The issue I see is that if a default value is false or '', it is printed that way in the ini file. undef is the only other option and that will cause Nova to ignore the value altogether. This works well if you never use the parameter, but as soon as you do, you can't go back to not using it."}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-05-09 23:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-10 00:48:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

commit_message:
Add ming as a test requirement

Ming is an ORM layer for Mongo. The package also
includes MIM, and in-memory MongoDB-compatible
driver. Ceilometer uses MIM for testing.

Addresses bug 1176017

Change-Id: I8882ffc7ecf9306acc4cc8bc21ccdb84718d8883
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-02-15 21:07:29.000000000', 'message': "Add ability to create a volume from an image

Currently there is no way to get data onto a volume through the
dashboard without taking manual steps in a guest. It's possible to
create a volume from a snapshot, but there's no way to get data onto a
volume to create the snapshot in the first place. Creating a volume
from an image is particularly useful when booting from a volume. This
was implemented in cinder and nova-volume in Folsom. Expose this to
dashboard users as well.

Create a new action for this on the images panel, reusing the 'Create
Volume' form. Also make this possible from the volumes panel, by
adding a 'source type' field to the 'Create Volume' form. This lets
users choose among blank (the default), snapshot, and image, hiding
the lists of snapshots and images when the corresponding source type
is not selected, similar to the 'image type' field in the 'Launch
Instance' workflow.

Use the same infrastructure as creating from a snapshot to update the
size and name based on the image size and name.

Extract the image listing code out of the instance panel, into a
generic utility module. Also add some size conversion functions, since
image sizes are reported by glance in bytes, while volumes are
specified in gigabytes.

volume to create the snapshot in the first place. Creating a volume
from an image is particularly useful when booting from a volume. This
was implemented in cinder and nova-volume in Folsom. Expose this to
dashboard users as well.

Create a new action for this on the images panel, reusing the 'Create
Volume' form. Also make this possible from the volumes panel, by
adding a 'source type' field to the 'Create Volume' form. This lets
users choose among blank (the default), snapshot, and image, hiding
the lists of snapshots and images when the corresponding source type
is not selected, similar to the 'image type' field in the 'Launch

size and name based on the image size and name.

generic utility module. Also add some size conversion functions, since
image sizes are reported by glance in bytes, while volumes are
specified in gigabytes.

Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
Add ability to create a volume from an image

Currently there is no way to get data onto a volume through the
dashboard without taking manual steps in a guest. It's possible to
create a volume from a snapshot, but there's no way to get data onto a
volume to create the snapshot in the first place. Creating a volume
from an image is particularly useful when booting from a volume. This
was implemented in cinder and nova-volume in Folsom. Expose this to
dashboard users as well.

Create a new action for this on the images panel, reusing the 'Create
Volume' form. Also make this possible from the volumes panel, by
adding a 'source type' field to the 'Create Volume' form. This lets
users choose among no source (the default), snapshot, and image, hiding
the lists of snapshots and images when the corresponding source type
is not selected, similar to the 'image type' field in the 'Launch
Instance' workflow.

Use the same infrastructure as creating from a snapshot to update the
size and name based on the image size and name.

Extract the image listing code out of the instance panel, into a
generic utility module. Also add a size conversion function, since
image sizes are reported by glance in bytes, while volumes are
specified in gigabytes.

Change-Id: I8314ab011734d80d5f611b338ed6e2538e6bab7e
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Continuing the conversation raised inline:

The current implementation is still a little wonky -- if you set API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE = API_RESULT_LIMIT, Horizon really has no way of knowing if what you've pulled down is paginated or not, so it just goes with the "safe" option and puts a "More" link up, even if the next page returns 0 rows.

If the more button is switched to a "Facebook-style" add-rows-to-the-table-ad-infinitum, this becomes somewhat of a non-issue.  If a "Back" button and page numbers are added, it will likely be incumbent on the implementor to refactor this code to make that work.  But all of that seems more like something that should be in a blueprint for a new feature than a bug fix.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-13 15:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

I think the -1 score is a touch unfair in that case.'}, {'account_id': 5623, 'date': '2013-05-13 17:36:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

The first issue about the API limit was just a bad call on my part.  Which I tried to explain in previous comments.

The indentation turns out to be a browser rendering issue.  I pulled the patch and it looks fine in vi.  Chrome not so much.  I haven't seen chrome mis-render the indentation before.  My apologies.  That was the only issue I saw, and it was a tools issue on my part.

commit_message:
Make pagination tunable through the settings panel

This patch set expands on the fine work done in https://review.openstack.org/26022

It makes the number of items displayed a per-user tunable through
the "Settings" panel and a session cookie, with the default/max
values being the values set in django.conf.settings

Fixes Bug: 1046915
Change-Id: I38ef4845d46bce62e44209865885aff8eb0bac83

commit_message:
Changes generic error message in horizon.modals.js

The former error message guided user to try an activity again
that either has no chance of success or might even be harmful.

Fixes: bug #1177518
Change-Id: I082ff0fd033b34895621929c8325b272c3c3ce29

commit_message:
Copy the RHEL6 eventlet workaround from Oslo

Tests in oslo-incubator now need the horrendous hack to workaround an
issue with eventlet on RHEL6. We've moved the patch_tox_venv tool
and redhat-eventlet.patch into oslo-incubator, so add them to
openstack-common.conf.

Change-Id: I1acfec282b64d7582144b155119bedb1741db2f7

commit_message:
Add element to force Linux to stay in text mode.

A typical distro kernel will quickly change into a graphical screenmode
after loading the relevant kernel modules. This element applies kernel
commandline parameters to force Linux to remain in text mode, so it can
be more easily intercepted by Lights Out Management hardware, such as
HP's iLO.

Change-Id: I03210f421058413974cb02b18cf13d08594da3e0

commit_message:
Allow ports to be created on networks that do not exist in NVP

If a network exists in the quantum database but not in NVP we should allow
someone to create a port on this network and set the status to ERROR. The
reason for this is if one deletes a network from NVP and when the dhcp agent
goes to create it's dhcp port on this network an error will be raised to the
agent and it will enter a constant state of resyncing.

This patch also adds a unit test for update_port() for the same situation.

Fixes bug 1179327

Change-Id: Ie77fc48d11644b820c0cc3b3fa341856e36f8511

subject: get_security_groups now creates default security group
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 447, 'name': 'dan wendlandt', 'email': 'dan@nicira.com', 'username': 'danwent'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 841, 'name': 'Akihiro Motoki', 'email': 'amotoki@gmail.com', 'username': 'amotoki'}, {'_account_id': 1653, 'name': 'garyk', 'email': 'gkotton@vmware.com', 'username': 'garyk'}, {'_account_id': 2031, 'name': 'Nachi Ueno', 'email': 'nati.ueno@gmail.com', 'username': 'nati-ueno'}, {'_account_id': 2035, 'name': 'Maru Newby', 'email': 'marun@redhat.com', 'username': 'maru'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 4395, 'name': 'Aaron Rosen', 'email': 'aaronorosen@gmail.com', 'username': 'arosen'}, {'_account_id': 6610, 'name': 'Zhenguo Niu', 'email': 'Niu.ZGlinux@gmail.com', 'username': 'niu-zglinux'}, {'_account_id': 6659, 'name': 'Paul Michali', 'email': 'pc@michali.net', 'username': 'pcm'}, {'_account_id': 6670, 'name': 'Amir Sadoughi', 'email': 'amir.sadoughi@rackspace.com', 'username': 'amir-sadoughi'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-quantum-pep8/6555 : SUCCESS
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-quantum-docs/5789/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-quantum-python26/6164 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-quantum-python26-rhel6/440 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-quantum-python27/6175 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/19988 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I tend to agree with Matt on the side effects of GET operations.
However, I think that a better solution for default security groups would have an extend much bigger than this one - which I guess should be backported to grizzly.

Even if I don't like this, I might be tempted to say it's ok, provided that a blueprint for reviewing how the default security groups are handled by quantum is filed, target, and supported by a core def.

On another note, I might argue that in my opinion the default security group to apply here is not the one of the tenant booting the vm, but the one of the tenant who owns the shared network; this unless we are saying that by default we want to enforce L3 isolation among tenants on shared networks.

If we are going to enforce this logic however the required change won't be simple too, and will probably involve a patch on the nova side."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"Because nova does it that way" is a broken window. If I would have noticed it in Nova, I would have put a -2 on it there. I consider this to be technical debt on Nova's part, and introducing it here deliberately sets a dangerous precedent IMO.

As is, I would like to see us get away from something like this. Every user *should* have a default group, yes, but my gut reaction is things should fail if we're expecting a default and it's not defined. If we're not ok with that, I'd rather special case a system wide default that be applied to a new tenant. GET's should be idempotent. 

Failing *that*, I would want to see an orchestration service that can detect users created in keystone and do things we think are necessary.

I'd like to see any of those before I saw side-effects intentionally coded into a getter.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Well, there's a difference between idempotent and "idempotent" ;-) In this case, we're creating data on a get. It always looks the same to the end user, so I see your point, but I'm not sure we can really, truthfully say they're the same thing.

When it comes to debugging, they can make things difficult. Like I mentioned earlier, I'm concerned about the precedent they set for others coming into the project. I mean, I can't stop you, I'm just not a fan of deliberately introducing side-effects.  I'll abstain from this'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm really against side-effects unless they're absolutely unavoidable. Some of the nastiest bugs center around them. Is there any way this can be refactored? I'd actually prefer an error to creating state on the fly like this."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

That could work :-)'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I have mixed feeling about this one :)'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why can't the default group be created when the shared network is created?  Having what looks like an accessor (get_security_groups) create data is generally a bad idea for both conceptual and technical reasons."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

@Amir -- that's how nova does it as well. Why shouldn't the read operation do it? Every user should by default have a default security group so we need to do it this way (since we don't get notifications each new user created via keystone)."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Matt -- The other solution I can think of is that in nova/network/quantumv2/api.py when nova quries quantum for it's security gruops in order to match up security group names with their uuids. We could ignore the default security group and if quantum didn't return one drop it off on the port create request because quantum will automatically create this default security group and put the port in it. What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Matt --- this is actually idempotent. If a user runs GET they will see the same thing each time. IMHO I think we should make this change this way and not the other way around that i suggested in nova. Does this change your mind at all?'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Because the security groups map to tenants and all tenants can connect to the shared net. The root of the problem is when booting a vm though nova --security_groups default. In nova/network/quantumv2/api.py it queries quantum for it's security groups in order to do name -> id lookup and if this security group doesn't exist and exception is raised there."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/2/check/gate-quantum-pep8/6721 : SUCCESS in 00:01:48

- http://logs.openstack.org/27792/2/gate/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/22389 : SUCCESS in 00:20:47
'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just for information: are you going to implement the idea you agreed with Matt in this patch or another patch?'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Just like I don't like side effects, or things which happen magically.

However, we have a broken use case at the moment, and we should restore that use case, so I might agree that this is the quickest thing to do, even if rather dirty. 

I don't think what Nachi proposes is feasible, or at least not with the current infrastructure.

I am ok with approving it, but in general we should come up with a better handling of things which are created by default.

+1 to allow a bit more discussion before +2'ing it."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I am ok to approving this approach. From the point of view of fixing the problem in Grizzly release,
we should keep the change smaller and this approach is less risky.

The good side effect is that users can customize rules of the default security
group before creating a port. Previously when a user want to use only a shared
network, a user cannot customize rule of default sg in advance.


In the long term, IMO we need a general infrastructure to do appropriate processing
based on an event on other projects such as tenant creation/deletion.
Creation of default security group is a good example.
We also need to know deletion of a tenant to remove the default security group.
The same thing applies to deletion of per-tenant quota.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

OK it looks like enough discussion here'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm ok with this patch but still have concerns.

IMO, the right approach is,

-On boot
 quantum checks all tenant and check if default security group for each tenant is created.
- On service
  get notification of creation of tenant creation. and create default security group"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Hi Salvatore

I'm also OK for this patch,
also IMO, I have same thought with you.

In future, we need some infrastructure to handle per tenant basis default resources.
My suggestion was one of way to do it."}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-05-14 18:43:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Salv I was not going to implement the change in nova because this will fix it here. The change in nova just special cases the default security group when booting a vm and imo isn't the right way to handle this. commit_message:
get_security_groups now creates default security group

If one called get_security_groups() previously the default security
group would not be created until the tenant created a network. This
exposed a bug when an admin creates a shared network and a tenant tried
to boot a vm on it without having any networks.

Fixes bug 1171997

Change-Id: I899203424c03353a1ee6567c9ddbaecd7dc25001

commit_message:
Add System Tests

This patch adds the System level testing framework &
the initial set of tests for Marconi.This will allow
developers to run the system tests (regression suite for
Marconi system level tests), against local Marconi server.

Refer tests/system/README.rst file for details on
how to add new tests and run the existing tests.

Change-Id: If748f1c78ced8b55cf457b09c980cae2427faeca
Implements: blueprint system-tests

the system tests.

Implements blueprint: system-tests

commit_message:
Permits a list of values for the "type=" tests attribute

The changes to the decorator simply call testtools.testcase.attr
multiple times in case type= is a list. Retains compatibility with
testr too.

Change-Id: I3d850b10f7cb8b7df69df3e583698c3d4f25bdbc
Implements: blueprint convert-attr-to-testtools

[{'created': '2013-05-14 00:50:15.000000000', 'message': 'Clean up tenants created in test_users.py

Test_list_user_projects in test_users.py creates a tenant but
the tenant is not deleted at the end of the test.
This patch makes the tenant be deleted by adding addCleanup.

Fixes bug: 1179739

Change-Id: Ifc361363f74dcc43286e5fbdb582adf7f452dacc
'}]
commit_message:
Clean up tenants created in test_users.py

Test_list_user_projects in test_users.py creates a tenant but
the tenant is not deleted at the end of the test.
This patch makes the tenant be deleted by adding addCleanup.

Fixes bug: 1179739

Change-Id: Ifc361363f74dcc43286e5fbdb582adf7f452dacc

commit_message:
Add apport install to Quantum element

Quantum element sliently fails when building on raring with the error
noted on the bug report.

Fixes bug 1179652
Authored-by: Chris Krelle <nobodycam@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ic10a44bef8b6650f7313a851f0fc2466b6a0b669

commit_message:
Create an LVM utility to use for local storage.

This adds a simple LVM class for performing local
LVM operations.  The idea is that an LVM object
is instantiated based on a volume group, init
can be used to instantiate and query an existing
volume group, or create a new one if given a list
of PV's to use in creation.

See BP for information on where this is going and
how it will be used in Cinder and hopefully other
projects.

Implements blueprint: local-lvm-storage-utils

Change-Id: Iddde92af18f2317edc5f4583b2113c2b8117a4fe

Thank you for review again. I replied them.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-10 14:42:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

Thanks, added a couple more comments.  I think this could be fine performance wise for smaller cells.

Leaving the -1 for now for the exception handling.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-10 21:12:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Agree with Brian's comment about exception logging.  Also if we have concern for large deployments perhaps we should update the docstring in the driver explaining the issue.  or file a bug and ref it there.  Something we can point to when a user complains about it."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-11 00:58:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-11 01:11:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't really get why we need this third kind of driver - on a small system the db driver works fine and on a large system the speed of each rpc calls is going to be a problem.

I'd like to understand better a specific scenario where this is shown to be an improvement before we add more complexity into the code"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-05-11 03:44:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 659, 'date': '2013-05-11 15:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for many reviews.
Some people pointed a latency problem of is_up() and its improvement will be complex.
Is rpc-based service heartbeat NG?'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-13 18:21:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

It sounds like the issues here arise from the fact that this servicegroup driver polls the all the nodes when a servicegroup API is made, instead of the nodes peridocically sending keep-alives to the servicegroup API, so when a user uses the servicegroup API it can check a local cache or DB etc.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2013-05-13 19:38:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: No score

Agreed, that would be a better implementation.'}, {'account_id': 659, 'date': '2013-05-14 13:45:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

IMO, mc servicegroup driver is better than rpc-based one with cache. It's simple, lightweight, non-blocking, scalable and DB friendly.

Thank you for many reviews."}]

commit_message:
Add Service heartbeat driver with RPC.

This patch adds nova.servicegroup.drivers.rpc, a service
heartbeat driver using nova RPC. You can reduce DB updates
with it.

blueprint rpc-based-servicegroup-driver

Change-Id: If812bf9400c1ec2d028c6bc1ad39fe302a38578c

I see the benefit of the change as it is but I was wondering about a simpler approach of just allowing the user to specify a list of zones to always be disabled and hidden from non-admin users.

My use case is that we have a number of defined AZs (say az1 & az2) and we also use a different default AZ (nova) because we don't ever want to risk a new host being in the wrong zone (and we can't move it into the right zone until its service is registered, so it has to start somewhere - hence the default).  Now that means that I will always also have a zone "nova" listed to users, normally showing as "not available" (as we start new services disabled), but it could become available if an operator enables the service before we have a chance to configure it into its real zone.

Being able to always hide "nova" and the internal zone (and maybe always being able to force them to remain not available) would be cleaner, simpler and more general than just hiding the internal zone. 

I was thinking of a flag with a default value along the lines of:

disabled_availability_zones=internal'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-04-29 19:32:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Phil, I like your idea but I think that is a separate patch.  This is a backport to stable/grizzly to fix a specific bug.  And what you are proposing sounds like something for Havana.'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-04-29 20:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

agree with jog0 on this one.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-29 20:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Fix bug in os-availability-zone extension.

Fixes bug 1167956.
The call to get the list of availability zones (GET V2/os-availability-zone)
doesn't hide internal availability zone if all services in that zone are
disabled.

Change-Id: I2c49ad68c2ee5ddea0536dfa770f649fbb392b63
(cherry picked from commit 7172fdc2bf4061039fe34cdb97e442c073a7570a)

[{'created': '2013-05-03 15:33:03.000000000', 'message': "Fix key error when create lpar instance failed

With existing code, when create lpar instance
failed, it throws a key error because the parameter
is not being passed to PowerVMLPARCreationFailed
function in exception module.

The fix for this is that in module operator, passing
the 'instance_name' to the called function in exception
module.

Fixes bug 1173303
Change-Id: I688eecf7b649b67ca62f72d6d33fd7cd774047c3
(cherry picked from commit cccca7a4531cdad88655c27533f63c590a5ddfa1)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix key error when create lpar instance failed

With existing code, when create lpar instance
failed, it throws a key error because the parameter
is not being passed to PowerVMLPARCreationFailed
function in exception module.

The fix for this is that in module operator, passing
the 'instance_name' to the called function in exception
module.

Fixes bug 1173303
Change-Id: I688eecf7b649b67ca62f72d6d33fd7cd774047c3
(cherry picked from commit cccca7a4531cdad88655c27533f63c590a5ddfa1)

LGTM, although I would like to see a comment below about exactly why this is needed for Grizzly'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-09 01:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Joe,

We have a team doing DB2 testing on stable/grizzly and we've had some performance issues with the way that we have DB2 setup (separate databases for each project, e.g. keystone, nova, etc).  They are looking at creating a single database for all of the projects.  As part of that testing, they ran into a problem which is fixed by this change.  This is the email from the tester:

"I am looking at a system that we have been using for testing. All the VMs
have been deleted and the deleted records have been archived to the
shadow_xx tables. However, the database table 'instance_system_metadata'
still has 151,836 rows with 'deleted=0'.  It seems that the code insert
about 10+ rows into this table every time a new VM is deployed, but I don't
see where/when these records get marked 'deleted=1' even after the VMs have
been deleted. Please comment."

Thanks,

Matt'}, {'account_id': 1313, 'date': '2013-05-09 02:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Delete InstanceSystemMetadata on instance deletion

Thanks to no-db-compute only pre-delete instance data is used in
notifications. So now we can go back to deleting InstanceSystemMetadata
when an instance is deleted.

Fixes bug 1153827

Change-Id: Ic66b998cde2a15a24f302f08c34753a8b57da73d
(cherry picked from commit 17bca438954638d74035d560e826a26a532b3ea3)

commit_message:
Initial commit of common library cookbook

Contains common library routines and recipes that
all other OpenStack service cookbooks use, including
routines for finding endpoints, passwords, roles,
and building URIs.

Contains a default recipe that sets up the APT
repository locations as well as ChefSpec tests
that cover the cookbook code.

This is designed for the Grizzly packages of OpenStack.

Change-Id: I2f33339418742f7f64cc848d14ad481b45811795

commit_message:
heat-cfn : Make error with missing auth details more obvious

Exit with an error message describing the missing auth details
instead of failing with cryptic "Name or service not known" error
when credentials etc are missing

fixes bug #1154759

Yes, you should only update lockutils. See https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo#Syncing_Code_from_Incubator'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-14 07:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Mark, well actually this is what I did.

And a bunch of modules were updated and these two were newly added. I discarded the other updated modules but these I added just in case.

I'll delete them since they didn't exist in the first place."}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2013-05-14 07:04:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-14 07:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Hide lock_prefix argument using synchronized_with_prefix()

The lockfile module has a new convenience API which sets the lockfile prefix.
Using this API, the prefix is not required everytime synchronized is used.

Change-Id: Iac1cfcc83b59108164de924d20127c1cf4dd7dcd

commit_message:
Enable parsing of Identity Service V3 catalog.

In Keystone V3, the service catalog in the token response
has been split into multiple entries per service. This change
checks the version of the Identity Service and performs the
appropriate parsing of the catalog.

Core code for Keystone V3 authentication are in openstack_auth.

TODO: Move to auto-detection of API versions when it is available.

Implements blueprint login-domain-support

Change-Id: I69073e5744def037caf522b1123755668887cfd9

commit_message:
Make flake8 deps consistent with other projects.

Make the flake8 dependencies consistent with openstack/requirements and
the other OpenStack projects.

Fixes bug 1172444.

Change-Id: I04bd814ad51cf53a3fa0026028a36de461da45d4

This patch imports oslo's log module. I modified it since it depends on
oslo's notifier which has many other dependencies Marconi doesn't need.

commit_message:
Use oslo's log

This patch imports oslo's log module. I modified it since it depends on
oslo's notifier which has many other dependencies Marconi doesn't need.

There's sort of an issue with gunicorn, it seems that once
log.setup('marconi') is called, gunicorn starts logging twice each
message.

Change-Id: I85e8354b7af9b67ea1f87e54b3b73250d4a1115a

commit_message:
Ensure an error message in LBaaS is displayed once.

Fixes bug 1160920

This commit also changes the following:
- Fixes wrong messages like 'Added Monitor "Add Monitor".'
  in AddMonitor and AddMember.
- Moves validation for cookie_name in handle() in AddVip class
  to clean() method.
- Improves an error message for member check in AddMember action
  and removes an unused member check in handle().
- Make LBaaS forms modal.
- Changes all lowercase and capitalized "vip" to "VIP".

Change-Id: I96f76d2f2177c0789ae4e939484f3965ba93d86c

commit_message:
Adds d3.js library and reworked quota infographics

The d3.js library is now added and the quota infographics
have been redone to use d3.

Added a reusable animated d3 pie chart that is now used to
display the quota infographics.

Reworked the progress bars (horizon.quota.js) so that project
quotas when creating a new Instance / Volume display a progress bar
in D3. Also changed progress bar for adding a floating ip so that
it shows that 1 will be used up on create just like adding a new volume.

Change-Id: I2930c3c80736e50d3f38c001aac1918e1932be5e
Implements: blueprint d3

Fix meter_publisher in setup.cfg

This seems to have been a merge issue between the pbr patch and
the moving of the MeterPublisher code.

commit_message:
Reference database OptGoup names in lowercase

To have consistent option group name format across projects,
oslo.config now normalizes all non lowercase group names to lowercase
when loading conf files.
Thus conf files are backwards compatible but option group references
in the code must now use lowercase before we update oslo.config.
This patch replaces all 'DATABASE' references to 'database'

Fixes bug #1179778

Change-Id: I85a1ca33d2b8879487fd816a4499ec505fea97db

I have somme comments inline. They're about enhancing this patch, because I think this is exactly what we need for addressing the need of allowing a single plugin to provide multiple services.

On the other hand, this is not quite I had in mind for the blueprint. To be more precise, it is a part of it, but not everything.
The intention is to stop using the extension middleware for core services api, and leverage the work you're doing here in the API router. Plus there are a few extra items which you'll find on the blueprint whiteboard.

Still, this work is valuable. We can merge this patch as part of this blueprint, or you can change the tracker to a bug report. I'm fine either way. commit_message:
Add ability for core plugin to implement advanced services

implements blueprint api-core-for-services

Add check for supported_extension_aliases in QuantumManager.
If core plugin supports certain service extension, then core plugin is
stored in service_plugins for the service type of this extension
so corresponding extension could set it as a controller for REST calls.

Change-Id: I9c883491f6f13770371e3444e7c17bd2164a7c07

[{'created': '2013-05-08 12:53:04.000000000', 'message': "Add CINDER_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other cinder
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. in cinder.flags). This is broken and inefficient,
but fixing it involves adding something like spinx's l_() function and
would be very invaisve.

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

commit_message:
Add CINDER_LOCALEDIR env variable

Part of fixing bug #995287

Syncs these two commits from oslo-incubator:

  Support overriding oslo localedir too
  Add a gettextutils.install() helper function

to get a new gettextutils.install() function which allows the default
localedir to be overwritten via an environment variable.

Note that gettextutils.install() must be called before any other cinder
modules are imported since some modules attempt to translate strings
at import time (e.g. in cinder.flags). This is broken and inefficient,
but fixing it involves adding something like sphinx's l_() function and
would be very invaisve.

Change-Id: I86562b3a65d371673bb21f7179eecc7602bc0775

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 06:10:35.000000000', 'message': 'Catch volume create exception

Catch InvalidInput exception from cinder when the parameters
are invalid such as an invalid size. Currently the exception
is not caught which results in a 400 Bad Request correctly being
returned, but also leaving a traceback in the logs. Correctly
catching the exception and explicitly raising an HTTPBadRequest
removes the production of the traceback

Fixes bug #1098048

Change-Id: Ia66e67f302cf20e96417f4ff3c1430b755a4a861
'}]
commit_message:
Catch volume create exception

Catch InvalidInput exception from cinder when the parameters
are invalid such as an invalid size. Currently the exception
is not caught which results in a 400 Bad Request correctly being
returned, but also leaving a traceback in the logs. Correctly
catching the exception and explicitly raising an HTTPBadRequest
removes the production of the traceback

Fixes bug #1098048

Change-Id: Ia66e67f302cf20e96417f4ff3c1430b755a4a861

commit_message:
Fix a typo to define Debian's service provider.

Plus, the special case being Ubuntu, set a special service provider on
Ubuntu and keep undef for Debian, which is the way it behaved because of
the typo :)

Change-Id: I724ac07c96de6b9242721fb2915805024646c769

(2 inline comments)

I disagree with this approach (as I pointed out in the previous patch set, but I guess my point didn't really come across) mainly due to:

* Using metadata stored in cinder will not used anywhere but in live migration if we accept this patch - this seems backwards and trigger happy way to introduce it into Nova.

I would prefer to see this patch go in as patch-set 1 which fixes an obvious bug, and see separate work on introducing Cinder metadata when booting from volume.

I am also generally against code that absolutely requires data to be there (like metadata), and think artificially providing it just so that it can be passed to the scheduler is not a good way forward."}, {'account_id': 2258, 'date': '2013-05-08 20:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 20:58:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Pass None to image if booted from volume in live migration

The destination check in live migration will fetch the image
information from glance and it will throw ImageNotFound if
the instance is booted from volume since there is no image id
on the instance

Fix bug 1170596

Change-Id: Ie683a3ca5d6430c52ead77b41f98fbcb4114ea1e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 20:06:50.000000000', 'message': 'Raise InstanceInvalidState for double hard reboot

A hard reboot is not allowed if the instance task_state is
REBOOTING_HARD so check for that state and raise InstanceInvalidState.
This returns the correct status of 409 to the caller.

Previously the hard reboot would fail the the expected_task_state check
on db.instance_update_and_get_original which would log a traceback and
return a 500 to the caller.

Bug 1157237

Change-Id: Ifb6111790352da5c404289b218c50d8104384301
'}]
commit_message:
Raise InstanceInvalidState for double hard reboot

A hard reboot is not allowed if the instance task_state is
REBOOTING_HARD so check for that state and raise InstanceInvalidState.
This returns the correct status of 409 to the caller.

Previously the hard reboot would fail the the expected_task_state check
on db.instance_update_and_get_original which would log a traceback and
return a 500 to the caller.

Bug 1157237

Change-Id: Ifb6111790352da5c404289b218c50d8104384301

commit_message:
Improve message and logging for corrupt VHD footers

 * Handles the output of vhd-util check a bit more intelligently.
 * Changes it to use LOG like in other modules
 * Adds a necessary import (errno)

Change-Id: I75d6b9e081159bc29732a721deb7a557e5f2ee06

commit_message:
Adds useful debug logging to filter_scheduler

On a large system (>500 hosts) the amount of logging
information if everything is at DEBUG is vasts, due to
the number of hosts checked for each filter

However at the moment some useful information is only
available within the filter's debug entrys (such as
parts of the request_spec).   Also instance uuids are
not logged making it hard to search for instance entries.

This set of changes allows it to be used in a very
large install with debug turned off for everything
except nova.filters

Specifically:
 - Log.Info the instance_uuids at the start of schedule
 - Log.debug the request_spec at the start of schedule
 - Log.debug hosts in weighted order
 - Log.info which host has been allocated to a specific
   instance_uuid
 - Log.debug how many hosts are returned by each filter

To get a count from each filter nova.filters had to be
changed to generate a list after each filter rather than
building a recursive generator object.   Although this
new approach is less elegant it does provide simple and
useful insight into the behaviour of the filters, and s
the impact on execution time on a system with several
hundred hosts and 10 filters was negligible

Change-Id: Ibbdd14f87b1dfd3cee8bf3cf6388e40b474e530a

commit_message:
Make sure that hypervisor nodename is set correctly in FakeDriver

This resolves an issue where the wrong host name is used when
executing some sample_api tests individually.

Resolves bug 1177802.

Change-Id: I29af026e29ff8c70bb6b4c81f1bdf28cdea11140

commit_message:
Fix run_tests.sh usage of tools/colorizer.py.

* run_tests.sh: tools/colorizer.py expects subunit v1 and not v2.
Convert the subunit stream to v1 if subunit-2to1 is present (this
indicates v2 of subunit is being used) before passing the output on to
tools/colorizer.py.

Fixes bug #1168516

Change-Id: I6be917181fa8d18764db89e741190964546d0632

a DB query will be enough.

(cherry picked from commit 0fee496538a36e7db5b7e2c7e5bbd5cff2aedd53)

commit_message:
Fetch routers ports for metadata access from DB

Bug 1176963

There is no need to retrieve the ports from the NVP backend, so
a DB query will be enough.

Change-Id: If3529cc5694434e8cdc9d21a4043f94212146d2d
(cherry picked from commit 0fee496538a36e7db5b7e2c7e5bbd5cff2aedd53)

The root cause of this issue is qpid doesn't transform the qpid timestamp type back to python datetime type correct, there is a issue opened in qpid community, I think we should waiting their explanation before determine to fix it in this way. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/QPID-4804"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-04 19:34:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think any of the RPC code turns the date strings back to datetime automagically.  On the manager side, I believe you need to deal with this manually ATM...  I'd prefer not to add this bloat to RPC.  We can potentially clean all of this up with the new 'internal objects' work.

Also:  check out nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py:convert_datetimes().  (I believe that was added to solve this problem)"}, {'account_id': 7040, 'date': '2013-05-06 11:13:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: No score

Please check the qpid client codec010.py for datetime and timestamp transform, I don't think add some if else code is a good fix unless the qpid will not fix it."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-14 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-01 16:53:52.000000000', 'message': "Convert qpid.datatypes.timestamp to datetime object

When using qpid as AMQP, the datetime object in the RPC
will become qpid.datatypes.timestamp and it will cause
problems when inserting into database, and when updating
the result of instance_usage_audit, it can't find the record
and raise instance_usage_audit not running error from
sqlalchemy api

Fix bug 1173893

Change-Id: I4bbfe354d59e697c33d05f3c5e8ba6c86cb34188

Change-Id: I4bbfe354d59e697c33d05f3c5e8ba6c86cb34188
"}, {'created': '2013-05-02 13:48:54.000000000', 'message': "Convert datetime via timeutils before send the rpc

When using qpid as AMQP, the datetime object in the RPC
will become qpid.datatypes.timestamp and it will cause
problems when inserting into database, and when updating
the result of instance_usage_audit, it can't find the record
and raise instance_usage_audit not running error from
sqlalchemy api

Fix bug 1173893

Change-Id: I4bbfe354d59e697c33d05f3c5e8ba6c86cb34188
"}]
commit_message:
Convert datetime via timeutils before send the rpc

When using qpid as AMQP, the datetime object in the RPC
will become qpid.datatypes.timestamp and it will cause
problems when inserting into database, and when updating
the result of instance_usage_audit, it can't find the record
and raise instance_usage_audit not running error from
sqlalchemy api

Fix bug 1173893

Change-Id: I4bbfe354d59e697c33d05f3c5e8ba6c86cb34188

Still to do:

commit_message:
Pulls in oslo-incubator scheduler filters and weights

Syncs openstack.common.scheduler changes from oslo-incubator

Changes HostScheduler to use the new oslo-incubator bases for filters
and weights.

Creates entrypoints for all the plugins.

Still to do:

 * Get tests passing
 * See some or all of test_filters should be moved to oslo-incubator
 * See if we can use the 'availability_zone_filter' from openstack.common
 * See if we can use the 'json_filter' from openstack.common

blueprint entrypoints-plugins

Change-Id: Ib13298f8014ba2dc56aba8eadad1278715fbc18e

commit_message:
register ldap.user_enabled_default as an int

This allows you to specify user_enabled_default = 512 (as it's used for
masking) rather than "512" (string)

Change-Id: I74de54ac0859e15618916fd5b774ba6198a3b20c

I believe this is failing tests because eventlet tries to import dns, and if it succeeds, replaces socket.getaddrinfo with one that does not understand ipv6.

Since this change adds the dns module, that code path is now active (but was not before).  See here:

https://bitbucket.org/eventlet/eventlet/src/ff0975b811798df014c5995765418b143f8d2243/eventlet/green/socket.py?at=default#cl-14

It looks like one could set EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS=yes in the environment to get the old behavior back while still importing the dns module.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-03-27 00:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-27 01:26:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Doesn't seem to work

[{'created': '2013-03-22 22:35:12.000000000', 'message': 'Support sending dynamic DNS updates.

DocImpact: there is a new DNS update driver, which supports sending
dynamic DNS updates to DNS servers that support such things, for
example bind.

Configuring this in my test environment required setting the following
flag values:

instance_dns_manager = nova.network.dyndns.DynamicDNS
instance_dns_domain = dyn.home.stillhq.com
dynamic_dns_domains = dyn.home.stillhq.com
dynamic_dns_server = 192.168.1.20
dynamic_dns_key_name = test
dynamic_dns_secret = Wr1784mFhyTP9nqXIkWpRw==

You also need to configure the domain with the nova client:

nova dns-create-private-domain dyn.home.stillhq.com

Change-Id: Ic70a844f5fdde289eabd39596dc7671816755bbd

commit_message:
Support sending dynamic DNS updates.

DocImpact: there is a new DNS update driver, which supports sending
dynamic DNS updates to DNS servers that support such things, for
example bind.

Configuring this in my test environment required setting the following
flag values:

instance_dns_manager = nova.network.dyndns.DynamicDNS
instance_dns_domain = dyn.example.com
dynamic_dns_domains = dyn.example.com
dynamic_dns_server = 192.168.1.20
dynamic_dns_key_name = test
dynamic_dns_secret = Wr1784mFhyTP9nqXIkWpRw==

You also need to configure the domain with the nova client:

nova dns-create-private-domain dyn.example.com

Progresses blueprint dynamic-dns.

Change-Id: Ic70a844f5fdde289eabd39596dc7671816755bbd

Fixes: bug #1179671

commit_message:
solidfire: Add ability to override account prefix

The SolidFire account is created with a prefix based on the hostname
of the host running cinder-volume. This prevents cinder-volume from
being run in an active/active setup.

This patch introduces a new configuration option sf_account_prefix
to override the prefix used when a SolidFire account is created.

If sf_account_prefix is empty, no prefix will be added to
the SolidFire account name when created.

The default value is still the hostname.

Change-Id: I3b974789ea3e749cc8696b69754023ad76155179
Fixes: bug #1179671

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 12:53:04.000000000', 'message': "Remove gettext.install() from cinder/__init__.py

The gettext.install() function installs a builtin _() function which
translates a string in the translation domain supplied to the install()
function. If gettext.install() is called multiple times, it's the last
call to the function which wins and the last supplied translation domain
which is used e.g.

 >>> import os
 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'
 >>> import gettext
 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
  nç„¡åŠ¹ãª syslog ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£
 >>> gettext.install('cinder', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/nova/cinder/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 Invalid syslog facility

Usually this function is called early on in a toplevel script and we
assume that no other code will call it and override the installed _().
However, in Cinder, we have taken a shortcut to avoid having to call it
explicitly from each script and instead call it from cinder/__init__.py.

This shortcut would be perfectly fine if we were absolutely sure that
nova modules would never be imported from another program. It's probably
quite incorrect for a program to use cinder code (indeed, if we wanted
to support this, Cinder code shouldn't use the default _() function) but
nevertheless there are some corner cases where it happens. For example,
the keystoneclient auth_token middleware tries to import cfg from
cinder.openstack and this in turn causes gettext.install('cinder') in
other projects like glance or quantum.

To avoid any doubt here, let's just rip out the shortcut and always
call gettext.install() from the top-level script.

However, there's a bit of an annoying detail here - by default,
nosetests starts in the current directly and tries to import all modules
it finds to look for tests. Without the _() builtin installed, importing
some modules like cinder.flags will fail.

Since it only ever makes sense to load tests from the cinder/tests dir,
we can ask nose to do that by using the --tests argument via setup.cfg.

Note, this means that if you previously did this:

  $> tox -- cinder.tests.foo cinder.tests.bar

then you must now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests cinder.tests.foo,cinder.tests.bar

Change-Id: If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a
"}, {'created': '2013-05-13 02:45:49.000000000', 'message': "Remove gettext.install() from cinder/__init__.py

The gettext.install() function installs a builtin _() function which

which is used e.g.

 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'

 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')

commit_message:
Remove gettext.install() from cinder/__init__.py

The gettext.install() function installs a builtin _() function which
translates a string in the translation domain supplied to the install()
function. If gettext.install() is called multiple times, it's the last
call to the function which wins and the last supplied translation domain
which is used e.g.

 >>> import os
 >>> os.environ['LANG'] = 'ja.UTF-8'
 >>> import gettext
 >>> gettext.install('keystone', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/keystone/keystone/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
  nç„¡åŠ¹ãª syslog ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚·ãƒªãƒ†ã‚£
 >>> gettext.install('cinder', unicode=1, localedir='/opt/stack/nova/cinder/locale')
 >>> print _('Invalid syslog facility')
 Invalid syslog facility

Usually this function is called early on in a toplevel script and we
assume that no other code will call it and override the installed _().
However, in Cinder, we have taken a shortcut to avoid having to call it
explicitly from each script and instead call it from cinder/__init__.py.

This shortcut would be perfectly fine if we were absolutely sure that
nova modules would never be imported from another program. It's probably
quite incorrect for a program to use cinder code (indeed, if we wanted
to support this, Cinder code shouldn't use the default _() function) but
nevertheless there are some corner cases where it happens. For example,
the keystoneclient auth_token middleware tries to import cfg from
cinder.openstack and this in turn causes gettext.install('cinder') in
other projects like glance or quantum.

To avoid any doubt here, let's just rip out the shortcut and always
call gettext.install() from the top-level script.

However, there's a bit of an annoying detail here - by default,
nosetests starts in the current directly and tries to import all modules
it finds to look for tests. Without the _() builtin installed, importing
some modules like cinder.flags will fail.

Since it only ever makes sense to load tests from the cinder/tests dir,
we can ask nose to do that by using the --tests argument via setup.cfg.

Note, this means that if you previously did this:

  $> tox -- cinder.tests.foo cinder.tests.bar

then you must now do this:

  $> tox -- --tests cinder.tests.foo,cinder.tests.bar

Change-Id: If4125d6bcbde63df95de129ac5c83b4a6d6f130a

commit_message:
Use `bool_from_str` in Flavor `_get_is_public`

Now that Nova is using Oslo's `bool_from_str`, it makes sense to use that in
Flavor's `_get_is_public` function (which was renamed `_parse_is_public`
because, for testing purposes, it no longer directly pulls the `is_public`
value from the Request's parameters).

Change-Id: Ic778066c5c7a3b1abfbb2373eb56882d2cca5708

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 07:09:51.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-05-13 07:54:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Too late I guess.. but I agree with Russel's comment. Instead of setting cpuset in nova.conf, the admin could just do it directly in cgroups config (cpuset of the libvritd group). Same admin effort, but much more elegant and efficient, with zero extra complexity or code."}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-05-13 08:19:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

@Alex
I don't agree with you very much, a simple situation is that the compute host doesn't install cgroup, they may need to upgrade the host kernel to enable cgroup, this is not efficient.
And this patch just giving us a new choice, the admin can enable it by adding a new config entry in nova.conf, this is also a very efficient method to deploy a large environment, or just ignore it by doing nothing(or implement the same function by using cgroup as your suggestion)."}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-05-13 10:34:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

@Wangpan: as far as I understand , this feature will not work without cgroups being configured underneath. The implementation is basically passes down the cpuset via libvirt to cgroups. Isn't it the case?"}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2013-05-13 10:46:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

> Too late I guess.. but I agree with Russel's comment.
> Instead of setting cpuset in nova.conf, the admin could
> just do it directly in cgroups config (cpuset of the
> libvritd group).

No you can't do that. You cannot assume that the VM's cgroups are located below the cgroup holding libvirtd. This kind of layout is not something that is guaranteed by libvirt and indeed it is no longer the case in current libvirt releases. As of libvirt 1.0.5, all VMs cgroups live immediately under /machine regardless of where libvirtd is, and this location is now user configurable to any alternative location on a per-VM basis. So if Nova wants to prevent VMs running on certain vCPUs, then it is correct to set this in the VM XML"}, {'account_id': 4468, 'date': '2013-05-14 03:09:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I looked into the libvirt qemu driver codes, and found it pinned vcpus by function 'virProcessInfoSetAffinity', and this function used  system call 'sched_setaffinity', I can't find where the cgroup is needed, and Xen driver doesn't need cgroup, too. If I'm wrong, correct me pls."}]

commit_message:
Add cpuset attr to vcpu conf in libvirt xml

Currently the instances can use all of the pcpu of compute node, the
host may become slow when vcpus of instances are busy, so we need to
pin vcpus to the specific pcpus of host instead of all pcpus.
Also added a cache of total vcpus num in libvirt driver here.

DocImpact: please refer to the bp page.
Implements blueprint: instance-vcpu-pin
Change-Id: I6b6e805c15b249cc5e7517e26619d79bb0183de8

subject: Add syslog support
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28729/1/check/gate-puppet-nova-puppet-unit-2.6/93 : SUCCESS in 00:01:55
- http://logs.openstack.org/28729/1/check/gate-puppet-nova-puppet-unit-2.7/93 : SUCCESS in 00:02:02
- http://logs.openstack.org/28729/1/check/gate-puppet-nova-puppet-unit-3.0/93 : SUCCESS in 00:00:56
- http://logs.openstack.org/28729/1/check/gate-puppet-nova-puppet-unit-3.1/93 : SUCCESS in 00:00:56
'}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:18:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Now we're getting into the realm of "every single nova.conf option as a parameter".

IMO, the only parameters that should go in the modules are those that have an effect on other modules, provide core functionality, or are manipulated in the code itself. Everything else is "extra" and the user is free to define their own with nova_config outside of the module.

With syslog as an example, I've been using syslog and OpenStack for months, but defined outside of the module.

This is my opinion and it was tried to be enforced back on github. I'd like to hear other thoughts about this.'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:38:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

verbose and debug are there and they don't have much need to influence other configurations or services. Same for rabbit_*, qpid_*, etc.

puppet-keystone implements use_syslog parameter but throws you a failure when you try to use it.

What should be the guideline?"}, {'account_id': 6859, 'date': '2013-05-09 22:44:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Agreed. There's a lot of cruft in the modules from before the parameters started getting out of line.

WRT rabbit and qpid: I raised that flag when the patch was submitted and wanted them moved to their own manifests. On the other hand, rabbit and qpid are core requirements for nova. It can't run without one.

It's a hard line to draw. IMO, if these types of options are going to be added to the module, someone might as well just go through the docs and add them all in one patch to be done with it. Otherwise it's just drawing out a long, slow inevitable process.

And then there's the work of maintaining them after each release."}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-05-14 02:56:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Dropping so we can focus on important things. Will use nova_config for now.'}]

'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 05:02:57.000000000', 'message': "libvirt: ignore NOSTATE in resume_state_on_host_boot() method.

Occasionally, libvirt would get NOSTATE from hypervisor as instance
state. Thus if we don't ignore instances in NOSTATE in
resume_state_on_host_boot() method, we would mistakenly reboot such
instances when we restart nova-compute service or on host boot. This
patch fixes this by adding NOSTATE into ignored_states.

Bug 1176897

Change-Id: I651cb043d7f97fde29b2a62e6ead8222062f01f7
(cherry picked from commit 0098f12e8b1f035c7ecdb952cfcd4bbae86b6246)
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: ignore NOSTATE in resume_state_on_host_boot() method.

Occasionally, libvirt would get NOSTATE from hypervisor as instance
state. Thus if we don't ignore instances in NOSTATE in
resume_state_on_host_boot() method, we would mistakenly reboot such
instances when we restart nova-compute service or on host boot. This
patch fixes this by adding NOSTATE into ignored_states.

Bug 1176897

Change-Id: I651cb043d7f97fde29b2a62e6ead8222062f01f7
(cherry picked from commit 0098f12e8b1f035c7ecdb952cfcd4bbae86b6246)

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1176164"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-13 18:46:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why wasn't this covered by unit tests? or even integration tests?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2013-05-13 19:39:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Joe, my guess is it's related to whether or not the Tempest runs are using fuzzy translations, which these were marked as in the nova.po file. By default, fuzzy translations are excluded from the po compile to the mo binary (if you're using babel compile_catalog). In our testing, we compiled fuzzy translations also which is how we found the error when we ran Tempest. I'm guessing Tempest that runs with Jenkins doesn't compile the catalog or if it does, it doesn't include the fuzzy translations (so it doesn't use the translated msgstr in nova.po, it just uses the English string in the source code, i.e. the msgid in nova.po).

If you changed to include fuzzy translations, you might start hitting a lot of errors in your automated Jenkins Tempest test runs - maybe that's why it is not done that way."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-05-13 20:19:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Matt, thanks for the answer.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-14 01:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Fix format error in claims.

I have now seen two bug reports today about log message formatting
in the claims code. I'm not 100% sure what's going on here, but
I've removed the use of locals() in the hope it makes it clearer.
I've also moved to treating limits as floats because I think it
makes the messages clearer, but it is not a functional change.

Resolves bug 1175923.

Change-Id: I8b7b31f2637d1ab41d0fb2f274545181f9fddd9d

messages:

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-12 09:00:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have two concerns with this fix:

It seems that there should be some protection against oversized images even if root_gb=0, so I suggest that in this case the check is against ephemeral_gb instead.   It follows that the actual resulting size of of the ephemeral disk should therefore be the ephemeral_gb from the instance_type minus the size of the image. 

As a second point I'd like to have a new vm_state (FAILED) associated with this type of error to distinguish between internal system errors (which is the current use) and user created errors (which this is).  For system mgmt and probably billing its necessary to distinguish between system problems and user induced failures, and in effect introducing a form of validation in the manager that really belongs (form a user perspective) in the API.  

Its unfortunate that none of the information presented by image-list or flavor-list is going allow a user to make a correct choice of flavor and image, so ideally we'd make this check in the API layer, but I guess that would require a full image download at that point. 

The best we can do is explain that they need to check the actions table (Assuming that extension is loaded) to see the reason for going into an Error state.  Flagging it as a failure will at least provide a bit more of a clue in the actions API that this is something the user needs to fix."}, {'account_id': 1525, 'date': '2013-05-13 17:58:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Phil, I agree with a lot of what you're saying but it's all outside of the scope of this review.

This submission is exactly what went into master.  Being destined for stable, I think the only criteria we should consider is:  a) the issue is critical enough to merit a backport and b) is the change itself low enough risk in the context of a backport."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-05-14 01:14:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Approving since I think it's good for the backport.  Phil, let's discuss your ideas on openstack-dev, or as additional patches on top of this.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-14 01:14:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Check QCOW2 image size during root disk creation

glance can only tell us the size of the file, not the virtual
size of the QCOW2. As such we need to check the virtual size of
the image once its cached and ensure it's <= to the flavor's
root disk size.

Change-Id: I833467284126557eb598b8350a84e10c06292fa9
Fixes: bug 1177830
(cherry picked from commit 44a8aba1d5da87d54db48079103fdef946666d80)

[{'created': '2013-04-14 14:53:59.000000000', 'message': 'Enable unicode error message

Keystone exceptions could only take byte string message as the
message arguments to construct exception instances because of
the way its super class StandardError implements __unicode__.
This patch can also make sure it would not unintentionally remove
line breaks and indentation in a explicitly given message argument.

Fixs bug #1168879

Change-Id: I7916efc87845cfc4dba705e9474125b275affc13
'}]
commit_message:
Enable unicode error message

Keystone exceptions could only take byte string message as the
message arguments to construct exception instances because of
the way its super class StandardError implements __unicode__.
This patch can also make sure it would not unintentionally remove
line breaks and indentation in a explicitly given message argument.

Fixs bug #1168879

Change-Id: I7916efc87845cfc4dba705e9474125b275affc13

commit_message:
Use hostname from env in heat-keystone-setup

Prints a warning if the endpoints are going to be registered as localhost URIs.

Change-Id: I32efcf826f400ca2763cb5758dce02ffdbdb9ae1

commit_message:
Use flake8 instead of pep8

flake8 is pluggable and supports running hacking checks via a plugin.

Fixes bug 1172444

Change-Id: Ie0b11544aaa3b1602ceced61941ab2cb30a7dc17

commit_message:
Move get_table() from test_migrations to sqlalchemy.utils

get_table() is very useful in different places. So it is better
to move it from test_migrations to sqlalchemy.utils.

blueprint db-common-migration-and-utils

Change-Id: I1191b95aede8688a2b38ac4dd0f2e9108dda1559

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-13 21:49:37.000000000', 'message': 'Change Daemon class to better match process command lines.

Add additional uuid argument Daemon class to help it better
match output from /proc/$id/cmdline to the correct daemon.
If there is a stale pid in the pidfile, and that process has
the same name, then it could match accidentally and not
start the daemon up properly.

Fixes bug 1177416

Change-Id: I1109ca73c539c5e96cbe3dbb55ce68c92013ee10
(cherry picked from commit 6db5b0b77d0dd8b0f5010a71c769a821881797c5)
'}]
commit_message:
Change Daemon class to better match process command lines.

Add additional uuid argument Daemon class to help it better
match output from /proc/$id/cmdline to the correct daemon.
If there is a stale pid in the pidfile, and that process has
the same name, then it could match accidentally and not
start the daemon up properly.

Fixes bug 1177416

Change-Id: I1109ca73c539c5e96cbe3dbb55ce68c92013ee10
(cherry picked from commit 6db5b0b77d0dd8b0f5010a71c769a821881797c5)
