revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-13 21:49:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix 500 raised on disassociate_floatingips when out of sync

If one deletes NAT rules directly from NVP and not through quantum,
an error will be raised when deleting a port that is associated with
the floating ip. This patch catches the NotFound exception and logs
it so that the port can successfully be deleted.

Fixes bug: 1177176

Change-Id: Ia7d0b94957d0c6b014d242439245b0e4fa9de40d
(cherry picked from commit 17336b9cb64048652bb6853fe0429699b4762a40)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix 500 raised on disassociate_floatingips when out of sync

If one deletes NAT rules directly from NVP and not through quantum,
an error will be raised when deleting a port that is associated with
the floating ip. This patch catches the NotFound exception and logs
it so that the port can successfully be deleted.

Fixes bug: 1177176

Change-Id: Ia7d0b94957d0c6b014d242439245b0e4fa9de40d
(cherry picked from commit 17336b9cb64048652bb6853fe0429699b4762a40)

[{'created': '2013-05-13 12:27:50.000000000', 'message': 'Show the cause of virt driver error

Make sure that the virt driver loading errors are shown with the
stacktrace attached. Otherwise the source of an import error can be
completely hidden. This is important here, since virt driver can fail
due to various issues, like quantum vif problem.

Change-Id: Icb90d348e4a4ddef5768ca32836bd95d94981499
'}]
commit_message:
Show the cause of virt driver error

Make sure that the virt driver loading errors are shown with the
stacktrace attached. Otherwise the source of an import error can be
completely hidden. This is important here, since virt driver can fail
due to various issues, like quantum vif problem.

Change-Id: Icb90d348e4a4ddef5768ca32836bd95d94981499

commit_message:
Removes len() on empty sequence evaluation

PEP8 suggestes, "For sequences, use the fact that empty sequences are false."

Change-Id: I4c600a7a6230a55328ee46f7c59f340f37abc18f

commit_message:
Line wrapper becomes to long when expanded.

Projects with long names, such as ceilometer, trip up on this line.

Change-Id: I51ff3f0250018215ae240f90cec6051b56aab434

commit_message:
Renames filter to base_filter and weight to base_weight

filter is a python builtin function so importing it pollutes ones name
space.

It is now renamed to base_filter.

We also rename weight to base_weight, just to be consistent in the
naming conventions.

We add a test for base_filter.

Fixes bug 1175829

Change-Id: I46e0fa696d2f39081b5568c701b0a70c54f271ab

commit_message:
Only search the lib dir for rpc_backend

The grep in rpc_backend uses . to search all files. Unfortunately
the current directory when the command is called is not the lib
directory, so change it to search the lib directory instead.
Without this fix the command is forced to grep all files under
devstack which could be very slow if one has downloaded large
images.

Fixes bug 1174718

Change-Id: Ic8a59885cd07e5d6f2e734e80824762f9ac12996

(4 inline comments)

The comment and probelm description should be fixed - see comments. Also some code change is needed.

The test you added does not make sense to me. It checks that you implemented in a certain way rather than testing the behaviour of the code. 

Please add a unit tests to the TestProxyServer and test for empty path segments such as AUTH_a//o see that it returns 412 and not 500 like the container_quotas code did.               

For example:

    def test_empty_segments(self):
        app = proxy_server.Application(None, FakeMemcache(),
                                       account_ring=FakeRing(),
                                       container_ring=FakeRing(),
                                       object_ring=FakeRing())
        set_http_connect(200,200,200)
        req = Request.blank('/v1/AUTH_a//o')
        app.update_request(req)
        resp = app.handle_request(req)
        self.assertEquals(resp.status_int, 412)

Please consider other cases (empty account ?)
Also, make sure you pass all unittests with container_quotas in the pipeline."}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2013-05-12 23:08:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 00:04:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-02 18:34:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix obscure double url bug in container quota middleware

With the container quota middleware on, if you made a request similar to the
following one you'd get a 500 response.

curl -i -X PUT -H 'X-Auth-Token: token'
http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/AUTH_testhttp://something/something_else

(Note the double url.)

This was due to a mismatch in how split_path() was called in the middleware and
in the get_container_info().

This change fixes that mismatch and the bug.

Change-Id: Ie42ab585b942b7201e13b02a0c706532952aac60

commit_message:
Fix obscure double url bug in container quota middleware

With the container quota middleware on, if you made a request similar to the
following one you'd get a 500 response.

curl -i -X PUT -H 'X-Auth-Token: token'
http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/AUTH_testhttp://something/something_else

(Note the double url.)

This was due to a mismatch in how split_path() was called in the middleware and
in the get_container_info().

This change fixes that mismatch and the bug.

Change-Id: Ie42ab585b942b7201e13b02a0c706532952aac60

commit_message:
Add the provider name as a label.

When adding a jenkins slave node, add the provider name as a
secondary label to allow its use in specifying where jobs should
run.

Change-Id: Idd611759557101563f1c38e11813f4b372f6912d

From http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html

The except exc as var syntax is now standard and except exc,
var is no longer supported.

Change-Id: Ia3a11d72c474806cc2303a7fc9cb1a390266c0fb
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-13 20:15:32.000000000', 'message': "python3: use 'as' syntax for exception assignment

From http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html

The except exc as var syntax is now standard and except exc,
var is no longer supported.

Change-Id: Ia3a11d72c474806cc2303a7fc9cb1a390266c0fb
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
"}]
commit_message:
python3: use 'as' syntax for exception assignment

From http://docs.python.org/3.1/whatsnew/3.0.html

The except exc as var syntax is now standard and except exc,
var is no longer supported.

Change-Id: Ia3a11d72c474806cc2303a7fc9cb1a390266c0fb
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 06:35:34.000000000', 'message': 'bug 1163952

Implement the SubnetId property in the Instance resource

The handle_create method in the Instance resource queries for the subnet in quantum and configures the nic entries to use the network_id of the subnet. If the Instance resource contains NetworkInterfaces, the _build_nics method configures the nic entries similarly.

Change-Id: I5a05cbe0798e6b181bf9dd3b547cda525e18480f
Fixes: bug #1163952
'}, {'created': '2013-05-09 05:02:03.000000000', 'message': 'Implement the SubnetId property in the Instance resource

The handle_create method in the Instance resource queries for the subnet in quantum and configures the nic entries to use the network_id of the subnet. If the Instance resource contains NetworkInterfaces, the _build_nics method configures the nic entries appropriately. The handle_create method for the NetworkInterface resource queries for the subnet in quantum if a Subnet resource is not included in the template.

commit_message:
Implement the SubnetId property in the Instance resource

If the SubnetId parameter is given in the template, the handle_create method
in the Instance resource verifies the subnet in quantum and configures the
NetworkInterfaces for the subnet. If no NetworkInterface is specified, a port
is created for the subnet and the nic is configured to use that port.

Change-Id: I5a05cbe0798e6b181bf9dd3b547cda525e18480f
Fixes: bug #1163952

Shame on me, I should make explicit unit tests for this. :( I'll take care of that in an update."}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-12-05 05:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I will post an update with the fix for missing method strings in the referer, as I did not dig deep enough when thinking about all the exchanges (the update should take care of call cases where http_connect() is ultimately called, even in updaters, replicators and direct clients).

The double transaction IDs appears to be a caused by the mixing of regular dictionaries and values from Request object's headers field, which is a HeaderEnvironProxy(). The HEP objects report all keys in ".title()" case, but accept any case for keys. Elsewhere, we'll construct regular dictionaries for header values, and then update those dictionaries with these HEPs. This results in a regular dictionary that now contains two keys that differ only by case. Then eventlet's wsgi HTTPConnection object's putheader() method concatenates those values together (this is a supposition, as I did not bother to read the actual sources yet). This simple fix is to use the proper case when constructing dictionaries from request objects.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-12-05 22:23:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2012-12-05 22:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 21:46:32.000000000', 'message': 'Enhance log msg to report referer and user-agent

Enhance internally logged messages to report referer and user-agent.

Pass the referering URL between internal servers, and set the
user-agent to be the server type (obj-server, container-server) with
the process PID. In conjunction with the transaction ID, it helps to
track down which PID form a given system was responsible for
initiating the request and what that server was working on to make
this request.

This has been helpful in tracking down interactions between object,
container and account servers one the proxy server has forwarded the
request.

Change-Id: Ied56a1df83ffac793ee85e796424d7d20f18f469
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2012-12-05 22:23:35.000000000', 'message': 'Enhance log msg to report referer and user-agent

Enhance internally logged messages to report referer and user-agent.

Pass the referering URL and METHOD between internal servers (when
known), and set the user-agent to be the server type (obj-server,
container-server, proxy-server, obj-updater, obj-replicator,
container-updater, direct-client, etc.) with the process PID. In
conjunction with the transaction ID, it helps to track down which PID
from a given system was responsible for initiating the request and
what that server was working on to make this request.

This has been helpful in tracking down interactions between object,
container and account servers.

We also take things a bit further performaing a bit of refactoring to
consolidate calls to transfer_headers() now that we have a helper
method for constructing them.

Finally we performed further changes to avoid header key duplication
due to string literal header key values and the various objects
representing headers for requests and responses. See below for more
details.

====

Header Keys

There seems to be a bit of a problem with the case of the various
string literals used for header keys and the interchangable way
standard Python dictionaries, HeaderKeyDict() and HeaderEnvironProxy()
objects are used.

If one is not careful, a header object of some sort (one that does not
normalize its keys, and that is not necessarily a dictionary) can be
constructed containing header keys which differ only by the case of
their string literals. E.g.:

   { 'x-trans-id': '1234', 'X-Trans-Id': '5678' }

Such an object, when passed to http_connect() will result in an
on-the-wire header where the key values are merged together, comma
separated, that looks something like:

   HTTP_X_TRANS_ID: 1234,5678

For some headers in some contexts, this is behavior is desirable. For
example, one can also use a list of tuples which enumerate the multiple
values a single header should have.

However, in almost all of the contexts used in the code base, this is
not desirable.

This behavior arises from a combination of factors:

   1. Header strings are not constants and different lower-case and
      title-case header strings values are used interchangably in the
      code at times

      It might be worth the effort to make a pass through the code to
      stop using string literals and use constants instead, but there
      are plusses and minuses to doing that, so this was not attempted
      in this effort

   2. HeaderEnvironProxy() objects report their keys in ".title()"
      case, but normalize all other key references to the form
      expected by the Request class's environ field

      swob.Request.headers fields are HeaderEnvironProxy() objects.

   3. HeaderKeyDict() objects report their keys in ".lower()" case,
      and normalize all other key references to ".lower()" case

      swob.Response.headers fields are HeaderKeyDict() objects.

Depending on which object is used and how it is used, one can end up
with such a mismatch.

This commit takes the following steps as a (PROPOSED) solution:

   1. Change HeaderKeyDict() to normalize using ".title()" case to
      match HeaderEnvironProxy()

   2. Replace standard python dictionary objects with HeaderKeyDict()
      objects where possible

      This gives us an object that normalizes key references to avoid
      fixing the code to normalize the string literals.

   3. Fix up a few places to use title case string literals to match
      the new defaults

*****

Reviewer directed comments (to be removed later when folks sign off on
this direction):

  * I don't consider the use of HeaderKeyDict(), and the change to use
    ".title()" case a good solution, as I am not sure of all the
    ramifications

  * This change should address the previous issues found in review
    where double x-trans-id headers were seen, and the method

  * This used to be two commits, the logging changes and the
    consolidation of transfer_header() calls, but with the header key
    issue above, it became part of the above solution to make the
    fixes simpler

    One can envision breaking this commit into separate commits as
    follows:

      1. Commit with the changes to HeaderKeyDict() becoming title()
         case based

      2. Commit with the changes to replace standard python
         dictionaries with HeaderKeyDict() objects

      3. Commit with the generate_headers() routine consolidating
         header construction

    I chose not to do that because the second step would be elminated
    by the third, and the first step seems reviewable in this
    context. I would be happy to take that approach and resubmit this
    work if that would be helpful to reviewers.

Change-Id: Ied56a1df83ffac793ee85e796424d7d20f18f469
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

Depending on which object is used and how it is used, one can end up
with such a mismatch.

This commit takes the following steps as a (PROPOSED) solution:

   1. Change HeaderKeyDict() to normalize using ".title()" case to
      match HeaderEnvironProxy()

   2. Replace standard python dictionary objects with HeaderKeyDict()
      objects where possible

      This gives us an object that normalizes key references to avoid
      fixing the code to normalize the string literals.

   3. Fix up a few places to use title case string literals to match
      the new defaults

*****

Reviewer directed comments (to be removed later when folks sign off on
this direction):

  * I don't consider the use of HeaderKeyDict(), and the change to use
    ".title()" case a good solution, as I am not sure of all the
    ramifications

  * This change should address the previous issues found in review
    where double x-trans-id headers were seen, and then adding the
    method use on the referring URL

  * This used to be two commits, the logging changes and the
    consolidation of transfer_header() calls, but with the header key
    issue above, it became part of the above solution to make the
    fixes simpler

    One can envision breaking this commit into separate commits as
    follows:

      1. Commit with the changes to HeaderKeyDict() becoming title()
         case based

      2. Commit with the changes to replace standard python
         dictionaries with HeaderKeyDict() objects

      3. Commit with the generate_headers() routine consolidating
         header construction

    I chose not to do that because the second step would be elminated
    by the third, and the first step seems reviewable in this
    context. I would be happy to take that approach and resubmit this
    work if that would be helpful to reviewers.

Change-Id: Ied56a1df83ffac793ee85e796424d7d20f18f469
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2013-05-02 21:21:36.000000000', 'message': 'Enhance log msg to report referer and user-agent

Enhance internally logged messages to report referer and user-agent.

Pass the referering URL and METHOD between internal servers (when
known), and set the user-agent to be the server type (obj-server,
container-server, proxy-server, obj-updater, obj-replicator,
container-updater, direct-client, etc.) with the process PID. In
conjunction with the transaction ID, it helps to track down which PID
from a given system was responsible for initiating the request and
what that server was working on to make this request.

This has been helpful in tracking down interactions between object,
container and account servers.

We also take things a bit further performaing a bit of refactoring to
consolidate calls to transfer_headers() now that we have a helper
method for constructing them.

Finally we performed further changes to avoid header key duplication
due to string literal header key values and the various objects
representing headers for requests and responses. See below for more
details.

====

Header Keys

There seems to be a bit of a problem with the case of the various
string literals used for header keys and the interchangable way
standard Python dictionaries, HeaderKeyDict() and HeaderEnvironProxy()
objects are used.

If one is not careful, a header object of some sort (one that does not
normalize its keys, and that is not necessarily a dictionary) can be
constructed containing header keys which differ only by the case of
their string literals. E.g.:

   { 'x-trans-id': '1234', 'X-Trans-Id': '5678' }

Such an object, when passed to http_connect() will result in an
on-the-wire header where the key values are merged together, comma
separated, that looks something like:

   HTTP_X_TRANS_ID: 1234,5678

For some headers in some contexts, this is behavior is desirable. For
example, one can also use a list of tuples which enumerate the multiple
values a single header should have.

However, in almost all of the contexts used in the code base, this is
not desirable.

This behavior arises from a combination of factors:

   1. Header strings are not constants and different lower-case and
      title-case header strings values are used interchangably in the
      code at times

      It might be worth the effort to make a pass through the code to
      stop using string literals and use constants instead, but there
      are plusses and minuses to doing that, so this was not attempted
      in this effort

   2. HeaderEnvironProxy() objects report their keys in ".title()"
      case, but normalize all other key references to the form
      expected by the Request class's environ field

      swob.Request.headers fields are HeaderEnvironProxy() objects.

   3. HeaderKeyDict() objects report their keys in ".lower()" case,
      and normalize all other key references to ".lower()" case

      swob.Response.headers fields are HeaderKeyDict() objects.

Depending on which object is used and how it is used, one can end up
with such a mismatch.

This commit takes the following steps as a (PROPOSED) solution:

   1. Change HeaderKeyDict() to normalize using ".title()" case to
      match HeaderEnvironProxy()

   2. Replace standard python dictionary objects with HeaderKeyDict()
      objects where possible

      This gives us an object that normalizes key references to avoid
      fixing the code to normalize the string literals.

   3. Fix up a few places to use title case string literals to match
      the new defaults

*****

Reviewer directed comments (to be removed later when folks sign off on
this direction):

  * I don't consider the use of HeaderKeyDict(), and the change to use
    ".title()" case a good solution, as I am not sure of all the
    ramifications

  * This change should address the previous issues found in review
    where double x-trans-id headers were seen, and then adding the
    method use on the referring URL

  * This used to be two commits, the logging changes and the
    consolidation of transfer_header() calls, but with the header key
    issue above, it became part of the above solution to make the
    fixes simpler

    One can envision breaking this commit into separate commits as
    follows:

      1. Commit with the changes to HeaderKeyDict() becoming title()
         case based

      2. Commit with the changes to replace standard python
         dictionaries with HeaderKeyDict() objects

      3. Commit with the generate_headers() routine consolidating
         header construction

    I chose not to do that because the second step would be elminated
    by the third, and the first step seems reviewable in this
    context. I would be happy to take that approach and resubmit this
    work if that would be helpful to reviewers.

Change-Id: Ied56a1df83ffac793ee85e796424d7d20f18f469
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Enhance log msg to report referer and user-agent

Enhance internally logged messages to report referer and user-agent.

Pass the referering URL and METHOD between internal servers (when
known), and set the user-agent to be the server type (obj-server,
container-server, proxy-server, obj-updater, obj-replicator,
container-updater, direct-client, etc.) with the process PID. In
conjunction with the transaction ID, it helps to track down which PID
from a given system was responsible for initiating the request and
what that server was working on to make this request.

This has been helpful in tracking down interactions between object,
container and account servers.

We also take things a bit further performaing a bit of refactoring to
consolidate calls to transfer_headers() now that we have a helper
method for constructing them.

Finally we performed further changes to avoid header key duplication
due to string literal header key values and the various objects
representing headers for requests and responses. See below for more
details.

====

Header Keys

There seems to be a bit of a problem with the case of the various
string literals used for header keys and the interchangable way
standard Python dictionaries, HeaderKeyDict() and HeaderEnvironProxy()
objects are used.

If one is not careful, a header object of some sort (one that does not
normalize its keys, and that is not necessarily a dictionary) can be
constructed containing header keys which differ only by the case of
their string literals. E.g.:

   { 'x-trans-id': '1234', 'X-Trans-Id': '5678' }

Such an object, when passed to http_connect() will result in an
on-the-wire header where the key values are merged together, comma
separated, that looks something like:

   HTTP_X_TRANS_ID: 1234,5678

For some headers in some contexts, this is behavior is desirable. For
example, one can also use a list of tuples which enumerate the multiple
values a single header should have.

However, in almost all of the contexts used in the code base, this is
not desirable.

This behavior arises from a combination of factors:

   1. Header strings are not constants and different lower-case and
      title-case header strings values are used interchangably in the
      code at times

      It might be worth the effort to make a pass through the code to
      stop using string literals and use constants instead, but there
      are plusses and minuses to doing that, so this was not attempted
      in this effort

   2. HeaderEnvironProxy() objects report their keys in ".title()"
      case, but normalize all other key references to the form
      expected by the Request class's environ field

      swob.Request.headers fields are HeaderEnvironProxy() objects.

   3. HeaderKeyDict() objects report their keys in ".lower()" case,
      and normalize all other key references to ".lower()" case

      swob.Response.headers fields are HeaderKeyDict() objects.

Depending on which object is used and how it is used, one can end up
with such a mismatch.

This commit takes the following steps as a (PROPOSED) solution:

   1. Change HeaderKeyDict() to normalize using ".title()" case to
      match HeaderEnvironProxy()

   2. Replace standard python dictionary objects with HeaderKeyDict()
      objects where possible

      This gives us an object that normalizes key references to avoid
      fixing the code to normalize the string literals.

   3. Fix up a few places to use title case string literals to match
      the new defaults

Change-Id: Ied56a1df83ffac793ee85e796424d7d20f18f469
Signed-off-by: Peter Portante <peter.portante@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Convert to using newly imported processutils.

This change moves nova over to using the newly imported trycmd() and
ssh_execute() implementations from oslo's processutils.

Change-Id: Ied2bb1eeb0cbdc6903a4028a60c89ca9e23656b4

subject: Import new additions to oslo's processutils.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 10:42:28.000000000', 'message': "Remove duplicate gettext.install() calls

When commit 799a925 moved us to console scripts entry points, we moved
the gettext.install() call into nova/cmd/__init__.py but forgot to
remove it from some of the commands.

Since that move, we've switched to using gettextutils.install() which
supports a $NOVA_LOCALEDIR environment variable ... so calling install()
from these commands will actually break that support.

Change-Id: I1f959704551b35e95c5470a7aef900312db2e223
"}]
commit_message:
Remove duplicate gettext.install() calls

When commit 799a925 moved us to console scripts entry points, we moved
the gettext.install() call into nova/cmd/__init__.py but forgot to
remove it from some of the commands.

Since that move, we've switched to using gettextutils.install() which
supports a $NOVA_LOCALEDIR environment variable ... so calling install()
from these commands will actually break that support.

Change-Id: I1f959704551b35e95c5470a7aef900312db2e223

`openstack.common.version` includes a dependency on `openstack.common.setup`
that wasn't captured by Nova's `openstack-common.conf`. This patch adds that

Fixes bug 1178743

"}]
commit_message:
Include `openstack.common.setup` from Oslo

`openstack.common.version` includes a dependency on `openstack.common.setup`
that wasn't captured by Nova's `openstack-common.conf`. This patch adds that
line to the conf and copies the file into the repo.

Fixes bug 1178743

Change-Id: I85c427459042592a2e788793cf6fd851e5182897

subject: Simplified stress tests.
messages:
[{'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-08 14:49:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Looks like the actions contains are contains an infinite loop, and just terminated by the parent without ensuring about the clean state.

Wouldn't be better to implement for example a signal handler which could call a stress action related clean up action.
Or at least it should change a variable, which causes the 'infinite' loop to end. The parent process should give ~60 sec to child before it kills it unconditionally."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-05-08 14:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I thought about this but I'm not sure the notion of "cleanup" for each process is meaningful. This test runs for some specified period of time. If after such time there have been no errors in the actions and no errors in the logs, the test "passes". It then tries to clean up leftover resources. There may be cases where multiple actions interact with each other in a way that it is not clear how a particular one can "clean up" without causing an error (perhaps a race condition) with other actions.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-08 15:08:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/28553/1/check/gate-tempest-pep8/3184 : SUCCESS in 00:02:55
- http://logs.openstack.org/28553/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/15022 : SUCCESS in 00:46:21
- http://logs.openstack.org/28553/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/14737 : FAILURE in 00:46:27 (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/28553/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/21259 : SUCCESS in 00:20:51
- http://logs.openstack.org/28553/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/1333 : FAILURE in 00:46:28 (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-11 22:13:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I have concerns with the multiprocessing it's needs lot of resources if we are thinking about thousands of actions.

Event/epoll(2) based solution sounds better, several python library provides it.

Lack of IPC limits the possibilities as well.

I wonder will able to add existing test cases, most likely scenarios test as an action ?"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-05-12 02:34:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You are mostly correct about the multiprocessing. I originally used green threads to do this but ran into a problem with connection sharing in the rest client. I am not an expert on python multithread/event libraries so I then just used what easily worked. It is a minor code change to substitute something else. I also think these tests would be of value  with only 10s of threads

I am really not sure why IPC is necessary but it could always be added. I really just wanted to get some tests up in a reasonable way that could start running. The create/destroy is already finding a bug that I will report once this goes in.

With regard to scenarios, I think the biggest value of these tests is focused bashing of particular related apis. If we want to do less focused stress, we could just run parts of tempest concurrently I think. If we wanted to use this stress framework to run existing tempest scenarios we would have to provide a different call interface that could use the existing class methods in tempest.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-05-12 05:38:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-12 14:38:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

I think we need this in, but we also need to do some tox adjustments to land it, because otherwise these tests are going to get picked up on a normal run. I'll work to sort that out on monday, then +2."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-05-12 15:27:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks, Sean. I thought I made sure that these tests do not run the way the gate runs using nose. With tox, what magic determines which tests get run?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-12 15:31:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

once this lands - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28582/, we'll be fine, as that changes the test runner to only do the tempest/tests and tempest/cli directories explicitly (instead of all of tempest)."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-12 15:32:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

and this was all late breaking stuff, went in after this patch was proposed, we changed the gate on friday night to call back into tox in tempest.

Anyway, I just think it's an ordering thing, then we'll be good."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-13 16:32:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-13 16:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck no bug'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-13 16:32:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

once this rechecks fine given the other repository changes, I'm ok with +Aing it."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-13 17:19:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

Remove swift::params include

This class does not need swift::params. Furthermore,
swift::params is already provided by parent class swift.

Change-Id: I351331b01f81e224a37c4f5df64aa09d17939605

commit_message:
Honor $DIB_IMAGE_SIZE.

The recent change to use loopdev instead of nbd stopped
honoring the DIB_IMAGE_SIZE setting.

This change adds it back, by resizing the image to
DIB_IMAGE_SIZE GB, if specified. If unspecified, it resizes
the image to (actual usage + 20%), as it did before this change.

Change-Id: I69afd9584e644ddacc948619100f153d3d8713a4

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-07 16:56:10.000000000', 'message': 'Nova evacuate failed when VM is in SHUTOFF status

When the VM is in SHUTOFF status and the original compute host is
down, issue the "nova evacuate" command to rebuild the VM on
another host, it is failed due to a type error: string indices
must be integers.

Fix bug 1176773
Change-Id: I76ebce6882198365717167f29a484e4ec994db0c
(cherry picked from commit 2c1bd79a202c868bfeee7ca92e817ad19ef06b76)
'}]
commit_message:
Nova evacuate failed when VM is in SHUTOFF status

When the VM is in SHUTOFF status and the original compute host is
down, issue the "nova evacuate" command to rebuild the VM on
another host, it is failed due to a type error: string indices
must be integers.

Fix bug 1176773
Change-Id: I76ebce6882198365717167f29a484e4ec994db0c
(cherry picked from commit 2c1bd79a202c868bfeee7ca92e817ad19ef06b76)

commit_message:
api : Fix template-show partial URL redirect

All other API actions will provide a redirect if you only provide the
stack ID or name (rather than both), the template URL currently doesn't
because the template subpath is missing from the mapper lookup

Fixes bug #1178705

Change-Id: Ib8e8dd7691bc48587c9d91e937ac2c2c35ac3ce6

commit_message:
collapse tox.ini test commands for readability

instead of specifying the test runs on seperate lines, just make
them a series of args on a single line.

Part of bp:tempest-repo-restructure

Change-Id: I1250c1ba6e2e8edf38bb32abb450cd3ce03c1dd3

commit_message:
move cli directory into new tree structure

this nests cli under the existing tempest directory, a symlink is
provided as a work around for the gate until we make the gate
aware of the move.

Part of bp:tempest-repo-restructure

Change-Id: I2db2d500de7b0c32cfd3733fbbecd6c057c84da3

commit_message:
Rename bin package into cmd

Most projects are migrating to entry_points now and the name of the
package is cmd. I renamed bin into cmd to keep consistency with other
projects.

Change-Id: Iab889123fb4836a42ed0ef52986ffa7648a140fa

[{'created': '2013-05-13 13:49:28.000000000', 'message': 'engine : rename check_active to make it more generic

Rename check_active to check_create_complete, since "active" is
really a detail of Instance state, and so it seems wrong for other
resources which take a long time to create but are not Instance
based (e.g WaitConditions).  This change will also allow us to
align other stack "state check" functions with the state we're
checking for in a consistent way (e.g check_delete_complete etc)

Fixes bug #1178591

Change-Id: I55a824e6ba3de87cedd0b844e7f4e1294917533a
'}]
commit_message:
engine : rename check_active to make it more generic

Rename check_active to check_create_complete, since "active" is
really a detail of Instance state, and so it seems wrong for other
resources which take a long time to create but are not Instance
based (e.g WaitConditions).  This change will also allow us to
align other stack "state check" functions with the state we're
checking for in a consistent way (e.g check_delete_complete etc)

Fixes bug #1178591

Change-Id: I55a824e6ba3de87cedd0b844e7f4e1294917533a

This patch configures the compute API to take the metadata passed
from the volume api and add it to the instance.  This means that
metadata contained within a glance image and passed to a cinder
volume will also be passed to an instance booted from that volume.

I realise that there are no tests submitted with this patch,
they will follow however I would appreciate comments on this
approach.

Fixes bug 1166770

Change-Id: Ie252b9426f216ebe8a59936be6c3c8fabb597b64
'}]
commit_message:
Use metadata from volume on instance

This patch configures the compute API to take the metadata passed
from the volume api and add it to the instance.  This means that
metadata contained within a glance image and passed to a cinder
volume will also be passed to an instance booted from that volume.

I realise that there are no tests submitted with this patch,
they will follow however I would appreciate comments on this
approach.

Fixes bug 1166770

Change-Id: Ie252b9426f216ebe8a59936be6c3c8fabb597b64

commit_message:
xenapi - cleanup

Add error on unitialised variable to the scripts. This way some issues
were identified. Also modify README with fresh variables. The patch
includes:
 - Add SWIFT_HASH to the README
 - Add XENAPI_CONNECTION_URL to the README
 - Add VNCSERVER_PROXYCLIENT_ADDRESS to the README
 - Introduce UBUNTU_INST_IFACE which is the OpenStack VM interface used
   for the netinstall. It defaults to eth3. Previously this parameter
   was set by the combination of HOST_IP_IFACE and the undocumented
   NETINSTALL_IP
 - get rid of NETINSTALL_IP
 - xenrc includes CLEAN_TEMPLATES
 - xenrc no longer tries to change directory
 - remove chrooting from prepare_guest.sh (STAGING_DIR was always / )
 - remove DO_TGZ variable from prepare_guest.sh
 - use arguments to call prepare_guest.sh, instead of env vars
 - Fix backslash escaping in prepare_guest_template.sh

NOTE: networking is about to be addressed in a separate change.

Related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

Change-Id: Ie9a75321c7f41cc9a0cc051398d1e6ec2c88adfa

commit_message:
Basic cells support

Adds support for running a region and child cell within a single
devstack environment.

README.md has been updated with some info on getting started.

Rebased/updated from initial work by Andrew Laski <andrew.laski@rackspace.com>.

Change-Id: Ic181da2180ccaa51df7efc9d66f7ccb820aac19b

[{'created': '2013-04-30 10:54:29.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to noun-verb command forms

Reverse the commands to use nouns followed by
verbs to allow users to take full advantage of
tab completion.

Compound nouns (e.g., "floating-ip") are also
reversed (e.g., "ip floating list" and "ip fixed list").

blueprint nouns-vs-verbs

Change-Id: Icf09fb8d7dbd09772bddbbeb74f9a379d9189b72
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Switch to noun-verb command forms

Reverse the commands to use nouns followed by
verbs to allow users to take full advantage of
tab completion.

Compound nouns (e.g., "floating-ip") are also
reversed (e.g., "ip floating list" and "ip fixed list").

blueprint nouns-vs-verbs

Change-Id: Icf09fb8d7dbd09772bddbbeb74f9a379d9189b72
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2013-05-13 07:43:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

My 2c: This seems most likely to lead to bugs due to implementations not actually checking the value of the desired state (both examples in this patch IMHO already do the wrong thing - one plunges blindly ahead and one returns None when an unexpected state is passed). Flexibility of the plugin doesn't strike me as nearly so important as correctness.

I would be more inclined to support renaming it to check_create_complete() or something, and adding a separate check_delete_complete() for deletion.

Happy to discuss more, because I don't really have any idea what you have planned for stack suspend/resume. In any event, however, setting -1 due to the issue noted inline."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-05-13 13:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Replaced with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/28948/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 10:28:14.000000000', 'message': 'engine : make check_active more generic

Make the check_active interface into check_status, which is more generic
and will be more flexible when reusing the handle_create/check_active
pattern for non CREATE_COMPLETE transitions (e.g update, delete, suspend)

This interface adds a state variable to the check_status arguments, so
resources can potentially check different things depending on the state
we're expecting to transition to - e.g "active" is really an artefact of
the instance implementation for CREATE_COMPLETE transistions

Fixes bug #1178591

Change-Id: I6cc22b6913fa1227a024ba064b6e5c282275592e
'}]
commit_message:
engine : make check_active more generic

Make the check_active interface into check_status, which is more generic
and will be more flexible when reusing the handle_create/check_active
pattern for non CREATE_COMPLETE transitions (e.g update, delete, suspend)

This interface adds a state variable to the check_status arguments, so
resources can potentially check different things depending on the state
we're expecting to transition to - e.g "active" is really an artefact of
the instance implementation for CREATE_COMPLETE transistions

Fixes bug #1178591

Change-Id: I6cc22b6913fa1227a024ba064b6e5c282275592e

I have just some minor comments on the implementation.
I felt like something is missing, as I was expecting a change in port binding api. But then I found out host_id was always there, albeit unused. This is really yucky!

Anyway, I think it makes sense to move all the port bindings handling in this mixin. It just feel strange that it's partly done directly in the plugin and partly in the mixin; I do not see it optimal from a maintainanability perspective, and also we're using more db tables than needed, which an impact on performance and scalability.

I understand the reason for your approach might be that you want to support ovs plugin only, but on the other hand I'd say that:
- host_id has always been in the port bindings API
- if the other plugins save host_id and then don't do anything with it, that would not be a big deal"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-05-13 13:50:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

In my previous review I forgot the port binding extension so far where pretty much constants added to the response. commit_message:
add db to save host for port

blueprint portbinding-ex-db

related patch in nova:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/21141/

Only OVS and linux bridge plugins now support this feature.

Change-Id: I42d9bc59130e2758dd6a221d8953d63ec10e1f3c

commit_message:
blueprint mellanox-quantum-plugin

Implements Mellanox Quantum plugin.
This plugin implements Quantum v2 APIs with support for Mellanox embedded
switch functionality as part of the VPI (Ethernet/InfiniBand) HCA.

Change-Id: I22907dfec5b6cb8f6ad8c3b6e390abc4f8e0ac10

commit_message:
Use sqlalchemy session code from oslo.

The session code in ceilometer was copied in from an old version of
nova which has since fallen out of date.

Change-Id: I6de3d6488a0cfe5943db144ca2f4924a2bfb8310

Fixes bug 1179007

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-08 11:08:49.000000000', 'message': 'Configurable fixed network name

The fixed network gets his name when you use the:
nova-manage network create "$PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME" $FIXED_RANGE 1 $FIXED_NETWORK_SIZE $NETWORK_CREATE_ARGS
command.

It can be different in every deployment, so it must be configurable.

Change-Id: I5c724565561b1a230372b8fc1693cb81fea3117e
'}]
commit_message:
Configurable fixed network name

The fixed network gets his name when you use the:
nova-manage network create "$PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME" $FIXED_RANGE 1 $FIXED_NETWORK_SIZE $NETWORK_CREATE_ARGS
command.

It can be different in every deployment, so it must be configurable.

Change-Id: I5c724565561b1a230372b8fc1693cb81fea3117e

commit_message:
Do the same auth checks in the v2 API as in the v1 API

- Don't limit access to admin.
- Reuse the get_limit_to_project() function from v1/acl.py

This requires some patches to wsme to fix the Response status (so we
can set it to a 401). We don't have this yet, so I am posting an
interim patch. Once we have the next version of wsme I'll fix the
status_code that is returned (see the TODO comments).

Change-Id: Ib39f045b3f9c4ff1f851e13d528fd117aed45c34

commit_message:
Add RBD support with the location option

Currently only 's3', 'swift', 'http' are supported
with the --location option of glance client.

Change-Id: I8300314cf246d7ad42c2353d4c122c4ff2b831f7
Fixes: bug #1176994

commit_message:
perf: Decrease time to create a claim by ~1 us

A simple change to the way kwargs was constructed made a signficant
change in efficiency. Other places where the helpers.purge function
are used will be optimized once Falcon releases support for storing
results directly in a dict, unless they are None, making the purge
function unnecessary.

Implements: Blueprint bp/v1-obvious-optimizations
Change-Id: I9abe4d497cedd7963ae0cccd85bc1096d20994a1
